review: This roguelike is one of those games where, if you really invest time and effort into it, the rewards are exponential. Great plot, and not too difficult at the beginning as to ward off those new to the genre. Although the UI is a bit dated, the in-game lore makes up for it 10 fold.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969406290', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 988, 'last_played': 1657408771}
review:
Don't know why I keep coming back to this. It's so unfair.

Edit:
So. It seems this game is a pretty cool character builder. Levels come pretty fast and the choices you have when leveling up really feel varied and meaningful.

Regular mobs are fairly easy but the quest bosses offer a bit of a challenge, although not too much.

The problem is it feels like a game of skill, but at the end of the day it's really not. It's just about luck. It's about how far you can get before the game drops something in front of you that one-hits you and you're back at the menu deciding if you'd like to start over or not.

I've played other roguelikes where it feels like if I had done something differently, utilized my skills in a wiser fashion, I may have survived. So play, lose, learn from it and don't make the same mistakes again. But I don't get that feeling here, it just feels unfair. The game will spawn something that is so far beyond your ability to deal with there's nothing you can do but lose. Nothing to learn.

So I've had a lot of fun with this and for it's price I think it's worth it. But if you get frustrated when games are blatantly unfair you might want to stay away from this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038991683', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3165, 'last_played': 1685397651}

review:
Terrible roguelike designed by someone who gives 0 effort to actually balance the game. 

I'll save you some time. The game will be a complete breeze until you encounter one special enemy that will out damage and outlast your character regardless of your skills/items. The only advice people will give you is "get escape items lol". Don't play this garbage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047941619', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1709078183}
review: ToME is an extremely well made game by a small indie project, with lots of love and attention given to details and balance. The only problem is that the balance that the dev has decided would be most fun is to have every single dungeon filled with literally hundreds of trash enemies that can be killed by any attack in the game effortlessly, intersparsed with occassional rare enemies that frequently instantly stunlock or one hit kill you. Some of these rare enemies, depending on your build, can be mathematically impossible to kill. Why this was thought to be the most fun scenario for balance is absolutely baffling to me, because it's nothing short of infuriating to die without having learned anything except 'haha get luckier next time'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198406124338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2057, 'last_played': 1595303483}
review: Best game I've played in my life. So many classes, so many different builds, so many possibilities. The lore is so rich and enchanting that I find myself reading every book I find therein. I just ask dark god that he may never abandon this work of art, that he may continue to strive to push more amazing high fantasy expansions, new classes, new races.. please continue to ever expand this masterpiece.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117176465', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 96062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6204, 'last_played': 1635772163}
review:
※1分で読めそうに*見える*長文レビューです。
※Steamワークショップにて日本語化アドオン有ります(作者さんが更新作業中

■継続プレイなんと8年超の長寿ローグライク。アドオン、MODも豊富。
共有保管庫、無限コンティニュー、追加DLCが視野になければ
無料版も公式サイトにあるので、Steam課金前にお試しする場合はまずそちらからどうぞ。
公式サイトでプレイアカウントを作成してあれば後からでもSteam実績なども連動可能。

■ローグライトではない、正統派ローグライク
*band/Rogueの血を受け継いだ正統派進化系なのでアスキー版ももちろんあります。
タイル対応の綺麗なゲーム画面に、エフェクト効果は3Dでよく動くので見栄えもなかなか。
硬派なゲームバランスに豊富なアップデートと不遇職などの定期的なテコ入れ。

■難しい、だが無理ではないバランス
初心者なら年に1度クリアできればいい方、という絶妙な難易度。
不思議のダンジョンの数倍は難しいと思われるため、
DLC含め16種族x35職業xスキルx装備でゴリゴリのローグライクをやりたい人にオススメ。

■懐かしくも、オリジナリティ溢れる世界観
正統派ファンタジーなのにDLCで銃や機械も登場。
普通の人から定番エルフにオーク、ネクロマンサーからガンナーまで選べます。
どんなプレイスタイルも思いのまま。

■全然不思議じゃない、大人のローグライク
Steam版の無限復活モードでもない限り、酔っぱらいながらクリアできる難易度ではない。
偽りのない戦果を公式サイトURLで共有したり、自慢したりできる。
不思議なダンジョンに飽きたなら、ToME4の無死亡スコアに挑んでみては？

■もっさりしてない、快適な操作感
ローグライクのキー配列から解放されたマウスメインの基本操作。1-9キーだけ押せれば困らない。
自動探索できる快適さで、もう他のローグライクには戻れない。
敵もプレイヤーと同じ基礎ステータス、装備、スキルを使用する公平なゲーム性と戦略。

■おまけ？
熊ばかり出るレアダンジョンからクリスマスイベントなどもたまにあり、開発者の遊び心満載。
お洒落がしたければこだわったりもできる、装備で変わる見た目。
いつまでも遊びたい貴方の為に、ちゃんとあります無限ダンジョン。

ローグライクが苦手なローグライトユーザーにも優しい無限コンティニューモード搭載。

author: {'steamid': '76561198073166394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 117693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61960, 'last_played': 1709314920}

review: One of the best roguelikes I've ever played.  So many choices for your character class , race , skills.  Super customizable , and the unlock system gives you goals and surprised as you play.   Graphics are nice and constantly being updated .  Whether you want a relaxing rpg grind or a extreme challenge it has difficulty levels to accommodate your play style.  The combat involves using skills and innate abilities instead of just moving into your foes so you are constantly engaged.  I can't recommend this game more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005196504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4839, 'last_played': 1591316169}
review:
Read all these positive reviews.  This is a game for people that like depth, challenge, and high replayability.  There are sooo many races, classes, skill trees, and ways to explore building a character.  Even after you've beaten the game, each fresh start with a new character is like a whole new experience.

I can't stop playing this game.   Hands down, one of the best roguelike RPGs out there and the creator keeps making new content to keep even old veteran players interested.  Each new class is a completely new challenge and play style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098925571', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1637847287}

author: {'steamid': '76561198261805143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 15981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8702, 'last_played': 1699174275}
review:
为什么值得玩：
1） 30+以上的职业，类dnd系统
2） 200+以上的技能，既有成熟的老派技能，也有思路跳脱的非线性技能
3） 16+的种族
5）100+的怪物类型，挑战不断
6）暗黑类的装备系统
7）主支线任务，随机地城，随机宝库，事件丰富，抉择困难
8）nightmare难度及之下平衡已经相当不错
9）近20年的持续开发，整体历史30年以上
10） 社区仍然活跃，还有mod，游戏内甚至支持聊天
11）官网下载免费版本
这是一个rouguelike，dndlike，diblolike下你梦寐以求的游戏。
TO BUILD, TO KILL, AND TO DIE.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038472838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1865, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1865, 'last_played': 1590572202}
review:
It just seems to be a very standard roguelike with no particularly interesting mechanics that stand out.

Most of the game is a slog of combat where you easily destroy hordes of weak monsters until at some point 10-15 hours into your run you encounter some boss monster that's far more powerful than anything you've seen before that kills you.

Most of the game being combat would be fine if the combat was engaging, but it's not. There are no interesting decisions to make. It's mostly clicking on a monster until it's dead, then moving on to the next monster and clicking on it until it's dead. There are some basic strategies that you always want to use, like backing into a narrow hallway so that they need to come at you one at a time, but there are never any novel situations that require or reward innovative solutions. After 20-ish hours I got an achievement for killing 1000 monsters, which says something about just how much of the game is this boring and mindless combat.

One notable thing about the game that's a little different from most other roguelikes is that is doesn't include consumables, inventory management, hunger, or really any other kind of resource management. Even your health bar refills very quickly over time, and there's no cost for resting between battles, so health management is a non-issue. Apparently the developers thought that those mechanics were onerous, and wanted to liberate their players from them. But they didn't utilize any of that space they freed up to add in any other mechanics.

So without the interesting battle tactics, resource-management, or difficult trade-off decisions, the game is basically Sword of the Stars: The Pit (another roguelike), minus all the things that make that game so compelling.

There's a story, but it feels uninspired. There's nothing particularly engaging about the world or its atmosphere.

I kept at this game for as long as I did because I thought that there must be some reason it had such a high proportion of positive reviews that I would come to see. And maybe there is, but I'm not going to put any more time into trying to find it. I still don't understand why so many people appear to like this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026973217', 'num_games_owned': 1729, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 2526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2526, 'last_played': 1664808397}
review:
This game is so freaking difficult. It's also so freaking wonderful. 

I'm not articulate enough to describe the wonderful intracacies in this game, so I instead shall leave you with these questions three:

Do you like Roguelikes? Do you like difficult games? Do you like wonderful stories?

If you answered yes to all of these, buy this damn game. If you don't have the money, or want to try it out for free, look up Tales' website. Play it, fall in love with it, immediately save every penny to buy it and support the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040796843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 16593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12729, 'last_played': 1692107681}
review:
Excellent, excellent, excellent game that I just keep coming back to. Intermittent continual updates means the game constantly gets better - but it really doesn't have to as it is a gem as it is.

If you like fantasy roguelikes then you should LOVE this game as much as I do. It's UI is great with a whole bunch of QOL features. I will say a *few* more obscure QOL features could do with being more apparent as you may play the game for a while and then suddenly realise that there was a simpler way to do things. But really that is splitting hairs at trying to find something wrong with the game. Rich lore, unlimitted replayability, many diverse classes with each class being able to be played in different ways, many diverse creatures, some customizability in difficulty - you don't have to play on Hardcore setting if you don't want to.

This game rocks. I'm going to fire up a game :)

EDIT: 270.4 hours and I've finally beaten this game for the first time! Now that's value for money!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018456622', 'num_games_owned': 1071, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 18368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13426, 'last_played': 1700895435}
review:
I don't usually write reviews, but this game has a way of siphoning away weeks of my time without me fully realizing it. This game is INCREDIBLY fun - others have likened it to other hack-and-slash and loot-based games like Diablo despite being turn-based, and while that might be a little hard to believe on paper, it really does feel like this game hits the sweet spot that those kinds of games strive for. That's partly because ToME will always flow at your pace, and the mechanics are deep as hell.

Just to get this out of the way really quickly: although the game doesn't look the prettiest, the visuals are still quite indicative of what you're supposed to be looking at. I quite like the tileset's look, and it's much better than looking at ASCII characters like you'd have seen in other roguelikes IMO (I guess they're fine, but I have a hard time adapting to them). Music and sound is generally pretty good, too, and they add to the game quite a lot. My only complaint is that you do hear certain sound effects way too much, especially if you're playing certain types of characters (breaths and lightning much?), but that's more a nitpick than a criticism considering how unbelievably expansive the scope of the game's other aspects are.

Also, I love the class and character build depth of this game. While some races feel a lot better than others in several cases, and a handful of classes lack depth of choice in their skill trees (looking at you Bulwark), I can't deny that each race and class I've tried has been fun and unique in their own right. Gear and various story events also help contribute to build diversity in a more dynamic, often unpredictable way, and can either round out a build that's lacking in certain areas or build upon your class fantasy in an intriguing way (the rare one-off runes/inscriptions come to mind). This is especially true now, it feels like, with a decent amount of early equipment now sporting unique or activatable effects compared to earlier patch cycles. The lore and setting bits are well written and established, too, often providing unique, creative, and sometimes comedic glimpses into various aspects of the world without projecting a long info dump about them in the middle of your play session. 

In terms of gameplay, almost every movement and action you take on the field will shift time forward by a single turn, and those actions take only one or two keystrokes or clicks of the mouse. Walking into an enemy or clicking on one that's next to you will instead 'bump' your character into them, dealing your weapon's damage to them for that turn. You can also utilize skills, pick up loot, activate special tiles and use items in your inventory in a similar manner. It's a fairly simple yet robust system for a turn-based game that doesn't waste your time waiting; as soon as you use an action that takes up time, everything around you takes their actions instantly, and control returns to you for the next turn. This means you can explore and cut through easier mobs very quickly (especially with the help of auto-explore), and this pace can feel rather familiar to Diablo and its contemporaries. On the other hand, more difficult enemies and bosses will usually require more thought on your approach and will require more time spent thinking and deciding on your actions each turn. This game can be incredibly difficult and punishing, even if you're prepared for its more dangerous fights, so planning out your build and picking through your well-earned loot will greatly contribute to the success of your character. Even then, expect to die and remake your characters... a lot.

For my perspective, I started this game a few years ago on Easier/Adventure, which is basically the easiest difficulty and allows your character a growing stock of up to 7 lives as you level up. I played a Rogue a couple of times, with one of them reaching the mid-level 40's towards the end of the game after a couple dozen hours, but I sunk a lot of my extra lives on silly deaths while learning the game. Feeling a little more confident, I immediately started over on Normal difficulty as a Shadowblade. Despite the added challenge, I had an easier time of it and enjoyed the familiar setup to Rogue with shadow-based spellcasting thrown in, and I even reached the final boss fight with a couple extra lives in tow. Even so, I couldn't do enough damage to take the win, and my character ultimately lost the remainder of his lives in a few vain attempts. I was a little bit frustrated at that point; though I felt I had learned a lot and managed to defeat most of the content I came across at that point, I still struggled against the tankier bosses and felt my options ran low in the middle of some fights. I hadn't used any guides up to that point, so I had been focusing on maxing a few skills and didn't fully grasp the tactical usefulness of all my options. I took a different approach on my third try: having just unlocked Temporal Warden, I took the character into Normal with a character build in mind, one I had found on the ToME forums. It's still probably my favorite run of all time, not just for being my first win against the dastardly final bosses, but with how much fun the concept of a time-travelling warrior was, being very different from the Rogue and Shadowblade I previously played. The guide I read had also helped me understand to look for useful increases from your skill points and taught me the value of saving skills and inscriptions for escaping difficult situations. 

I still haven't played the game enough to feel like an expert or anything, but few games feel so challenging yet so satisfying when you manage to conquer a difficult boss or situation. I took a long break after beating the game with my Warden and came back to the game somewhat recently, and I'm happy to see the game still going strong with new content consistently being released. Since then, I've played a Bulwark on Normal for a (surprisingly easy) win against the final boss, then turned around and went through the 2nd campaign for EoR as a Sawbutcher. At the time of this review, I'm going through on Nightmare difficulty as a magic-oriented Wyrmic, and it feels like a whole new *terrifying* experience. Currently on my last life though... wish me luck!

PS: This game is free on te4.org if you want to try it out. If you do and end up liking it, please give your support and buy the DLCs! Our DarkGod made a fantastic game and more than deserves our dark tidings, plus it's just a really good deal for what you get out of them (imho). Also, Copper Mage when?

author: {'steamid': '76561198001935907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1587, 'last_played': 1710366089}
review:
Takes many basics of the roguelike formula and twists them out, gently, in nice ways to make a really engaging and rewarding game.

The game has loads of hand-crafted content & loads of procedurally generated stuff wrapped around what seems to be an impenetrably large list of character classes, stats, damage types etc.

Something with such a wild variety of content should not be as much fun to play as this game is - It's clear the amount of work and fine-tuning that has been put into this game to sidestep the many traps that could be present given the broad scope.

It's fun, and it remains fun after however many runs (in some ways the fun gets better; building for known checkpoints over a longer term of the character build).

It's balanced well; some character classes will be a bit stronger or weaker than others; but the development of each character involves genuine (and mostly fun) choices; and when you inevitably DO die; normally you can put it down to some kind of error (even if that is just not running away quick enough).

Nothing feels grindy, progression is positive & clear, and lots of it is even pretty funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076302278', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 166177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51898, 'last_played': 1707536098}
review:
[h2]I 100% recommend this game and I feel like I am still not giving it enough praise in that statement. BEST. GAME. EVER.[/h2]

Not a whole lot I can say that hasn't been said before over the 20 or so years this game has been around. I didn't start playing it until last year and the first dozen or so runs I thought this game was 'overhyped garbo'. It took many deaths and about 60-80 hours of 'off & on' play (mainly when buzzed) before I was able to begin seeing the sheer beauty this game has to offer, hidden behind it's incredibly retro graphics and at times obtuse UI/stat boxes. 

Simply put after I'v amassed over 800+ hours thanks to Covid 19--it's the BEST game I've ever played. PERIOD. Everything I like about my games, the way I feel when playing them and how it fits into my life is here in ToME--checks all the boxes and then some. 

Just a small list off top of my head of why I love ToME..

[h2]replayability[/h2] infinite? numerous race/classes to mix and match, difficulty settings and more
[h2]lore[/h2] best ever in a game in my opinion/abundant and 800+ hours in and still learning it all
[h2]awesome loots to find[/h2]gives you the same rush casino's do without throwing money away!
[h2]easy to play, hard to master[/h2]every game session has meaning. you never stop learning. ToME also has some a lot of neat features compared to other classic roguelikes in terms of inventory management, storing loot, selling loot and more--all of which is done seamlessly in an easy way that doesn't require DOS like coding knowledge to understand. 
[h2]achievements[/h2] my goal is to unlock them all 1770+ before I die irl, wish me luck!
[h2]environment[/h2]unique and interesting. best described as tolkien meets star wars. (want to kill medieval orcs in a mech suit or with chainsaws? sure, why not!)
[h2]plays like MMO but is single player melding the two perfectly.[/h2] ToME online community is the greatest folks on this planet. seriously. never met a nicer community that's always willing to help you, motivate you or be there for you if you die or just have a bad day!
[h2]stat tracking.[/h2] characters get logged on te4.org to be viewed forever for better or worse. Not only cool just to look back on your guys but a powerful tool to get better or help others get better. 
[h2]Still supported with Updates and even DLC[/h2] that is LEGIT, no funny business even after 20 years! Looking forward to a possible Switch Port, then I'd be in heaven!!! 
[h2]music[/h2]mostly top notch. Newer stuff from the DLC campaign Embers of Rage though, that music for it is insanely good. 
[h2]perfect anytime to play![/h2] quick sessions or long sessions--whatever you want. multiple game modes, multiple ways to die. there is a way to play and mode to play that will fit whatever time you have to game. it's perfect for pick up anytime, anyday and play. 

I mean.. Overall. I think this game should belong in every man, woman and childs gaming library. It's not only the KING of roguelikes, it's the best RPG/ARPG mashup I've ever romped around with.. It's original, unique, difficult and habit forming because of the fun you have. So much fun! 

Don't let the old retro graphics put you off. Real gamers know it's not on the outside that matters, it's the gameplay and holy **** the gameplay for ToME is SOLID Gold. Doesn't get any better and probably won't, this game is the last of it's kind and deserves your patronage on sale, off sale, free, w/e. Get it. Die. Learn. Die More. Win. Taste Victory Hero. Turn up Difficulty. Repeat. 

I mean I just love ToME. So much I even donate to the cause on the monthly through Patreon because I figure--I used to buy games left and right but not nearly as much these days lol Have been saving loads of cash thanks to this game. Seems fair to throw devs of ToME something for the amount of time I get out of this game each month all things considered. 

But the cool thing is for new players? You can go download the WHOLE freaking game for free at te4.org and play it 100% without missing any of the basegame stuff. It's incredible. On the fence? Check it out. Ask for help in-game too, we are there to support your journey hero. 

Kind of a sloppy review I know but I just felt inclined to write something since lately this is ALL I play anymore and you know what? I don't feel like I am missing anything. I've found an enlightenment I didn't know existed. It's bliss and can be for you too should you give this game a fair shake! 

-ZA

author: {'steamid': '76561198031669193', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4577, 'last_played': 1620087284}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal, or ToME, was my first roguelike game, and continues to be my favorite by far. It is a turn based RPG that operates on a grid where you and most enemies take up 1 square. You operate a character that has numerous spells and abilities at their disposable. The main gameply loop is taking your character thru dungeons in the game, level-by-level, defeating monsters and becoming stronger by acquiring loot and experience to grow stronger. The game has an insane amount of classes and races that you can unlock by achieving in-game goals. The randomized dungeon layouts, diablo-esque loot system, diverse skill trees, and unique enemies, all add to an awesome amount of replayability that never gets boring. It also has a slew of difficulty options so if permadeath is not your thing, you can turn it off and play how you want. The game is also available for free on the game's website but I highly recommend buying the base and game and it's DLC to support the creator.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977112365', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 60423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57199, 'last_played': 1690670180}
review: If you're a fan of roguelikes you will probably enjoy this. It has a lot of interesting classes and many modern gameplay features - talent trees,  cooldowns on abilities, etc. It also has meta-progression; you unlock new classes and races through in game achievements. This is a game that has a huge amount of replay value. If you're a little interested, the game is available for free from the website. The steam version does add a few things but I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy traditional roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988319173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 3255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1693, 'last_played': 1597596830}
review: Don't be deceived by the simple graphics; ToME is essentially the best version of Diablo. Theres a wide variety of classes and builds, tons of hack/slash action, and an endless stream of loot. The mechanics are quite deep, so there is a LOT of information to sift through, but once you spend some time with the game you start to appreciate the nuance of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054818292', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2165, 'last_played': 1662457398}
review:
Le meilleur RPG disponible sur le marché. 
Une fois en votre possesion vous pouvez le re télacharger sur le site officiel. Ce qui permet donc d'y jouer sur n'importe quel ordi, sans avoir a passer par steam.
Donc les heures des joueurs affiché n'est pas toujours la bonne ^^ (pensez a ceux qui en ont plus de 400h).

La qualité du jeux est, 
la rejouabilité énorme, 
les evolutions du personnages peuvent vous surprendre,
tout comme l'evolution des quetes.

Et plus on avance dans le jeux, plus on découvre le lore. 
Les découvertes ne sont pas juste la pour le RP qui est top. Elle débloque de nouvelle race, classe, histoire, voir meme mode de jeux.

Donc en gros : Jouer au jeux, si ca vous tente biensur.

Ah : niveau graphisme : Ca peut avoir l'air "moche" mais vous découvivrez une certaine subtilité des graphismes. Des monstres originaux, armure et stuff plutot cool, beau et original. Mais surtout les sorts, certains en jette. 

Bref une perle.

Soyez bienvenu dans cette perle caché :) 

A plus sur le tchat en ligne permetant de communiquer avec tous les joueurs de TOME.
Aussi bien pour partager des trouvailles que pour qu'on puisse vous aider <3 

Rogue like, rpg, choissisez votre tasse de thé.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014874473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1670194734}
review: This is the first rougelike I've played that has managed to balance difficulty and fun. You never feel safe, everything can kill you, but yet you feel like you have control over most situations. Proper planning, strategy and items are key. I like the use of runes and inscriptions over potions and scrolls. They add variety and eliminate the need for grinding/hoarding consumables.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189324129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 12762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10332, 'last_played': 1685586456}
review: one of my top roguelikes + top videogames. Very gameplay focused: level up and collect items, no grinding, just well-paced, challenging battles. Very complicated character/skill/combat systems that are generally fun to work out over time. Well-written and clever world in the background :)

review: Обширная механника игры и наличие неплохого числа  классов являетля лишь иллюзией сложности так, как играешь всеравно  против генератора рандомных чисел, Пробираясь через орды однотипных болванчиков рано или поздно встретишь случайного моба который убьет тебя с 1 удара, хотя видимо автор этой игры считает что нужно смотреть за каждым мобом, которых ты убиваешь ТЫСЯЧИ и это не преувеличение. Хотите сыграть в интересный рогалик попробуйте Dungeons of Dredmor. Не рекомендую эту игру никому, слишком перегруженная по механникам, и  слишком скучная по геймплею.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072031591', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 6565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2529, 'last_played': 1654037314}
review:
Incrível como um game que, no primeiro momento, pode parecer feio e sem graça pode se tornar um dos jogos mais divertidos que já joguei.

Tales of Maj'eyal é um rogue-like Tradicional (Assim como ADOM, DOOMRL, Ananias e etc.) onde tu escolhe uma dentre as várias espécies de personagens e uma das diversas e criativas classes. Você segue explorando a história do game entrando em dugeons, conhecendo o mundo ao seu redor, matando milhares de monstros (e esse número não é um exagero). Luta contra monstros únicos, lida com cenários que sempre mudam conforme a gameplay e por ai segue.

Tome possui gráficos bem simples, mas não se engane, esse é um rpg de alta qualidade, dificil e complexo.
Ele funciona em um sistema de turno, onde, dependendo da ação que você faz, um turno acontece. É uma dinâmica que eu gosto, mas sou suspeito por gostar do gênero.
Você tem centenas de builds possíveis por conta das centenas de variáveis que esse game possuí. Tu pode fazer um morto-vivo arqueiro, um anão rogue, um Halfling necromante. Enfim, opção é o que não falta.

Além disso, o game possuí uma boa história e dinâmica. Você acompanha tudo no meio da ação, tu vive a história conforme ela acontece e isso é um detalhe simples mas muito divertido. Exemplo disso é quando você entra em uma dungeon localizada na cidade dos anões e você vai acompanhando a história de um anão que nara sua história se tornando um monstro. Em outro exemplo, tu lê cartazes engraçados de um necromante lidando com seus minions. Onde todos cartazes começam com um energético: MY MINIONS.

Por enquanto eu tenho apenas o jogo base, e provavelmente estou longe de termina-lo. Eu acho incrível como a cara run eu aprendo mais e vou ficando cada vez melhor, indo cada vez mais longe. Ou seja, o game possuí um fator replay excelente.

Do meu ponto de visto, esse é um dos Rogue likes tradicionais mais acessíveis que há atualmente. No começo ele pode assustar, mas comparado a um ADOM, ele é muito mais noob friendly e você realmente consegue aprender com o tempo. Se quiser explorar esse gênero, recomendo começar por aqui.

O game é atulizado até hoje e possuí comunidade ativa em foruns e no canal do discord deles.

Por fim, existe um site oficial do Tome e vocês podem baixar o jogo de graça por la se estiver na dúvida. Recomendo baixar primeiro, experimente. Se curtir, compre e apoio o desenvolvedor. (Por sinal, ele sempre entra no chat global e conversa com os jogadores, eu tive essa experiencia pelo menos três vezes. E eu nunca tinha visto isso acontecer.)

Eu simplesmente não tenho como não recomendar Tome.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1679045187}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#367 out of 612)... it's time for Tales of Maj'Eyal.

Arguably one of the very best, if not the best, roguelike RPGs currently on the market, Tales of Maj'Eyal is an enormous and deeply complex game that will consistently challenge and delight fans of the genre. What it may lack in terms of visual fidelity, Maj'Eyal easily makes up for in ambition. Here is a game you can play dozens of times, trying something new, discovering whole new ways to play the game—and break the game, and be broken by the game—each time.

The main appeal of Maj'Eyal is, I think, there sheer variety of potential character builds as well as the enormous repository of areas/worlds to explore and conquer—or, if I'm being totally honest, survive. The UI and core mechanics can take a little getting used to (this isn't exactly the most accessible roguelike out there) but once you do, you'll find yourself in one of the finest roguelikes to date.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970527351', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 15000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 992, 'playtime_at_review': 1307, 'last_played': 1712276523}
review:
I found myself completely addicted to this game.

It all started with reading some Let's Plays of old classic roguelikes; Nethack, Angband, and Troubles of Middle Earth. Curiosity set in and these games are free to play, so I looked into the rebuilt ToME.

Holy crap! A roguelike with an interface? Graphics, music, and sound effects are just the icing on the game. I've played Dwarf Fortress for over a decade and I'll argue I'm still an utter newbie, that game has no UI, it's a pain in the ass to play. This game makes sense, you have a nice hotbar for all your skills, spells, and items. You can move with a click, inspect an enemy, cast said spells and whatnot with the right mouse.

So many class and race options. I've only unlocked three classes and I'm desperately looking for more. There's a bunch of different resources to keep your mages and druids from being the same guy with a different spellbook. I've really only scratched the surface of ToME's classes have to offer.

Simple as it may be, it's really a dungeon crawl for loot, I'm captivated. I get excited when I see good gear and let down when it's for other classes. 

Already bought the expansions. The free version had no problems being merged with the Steam release and all my progress was saved.

It's a game where one of my best characters died and my first response was to be mad because it was an unfair situation. Only to realize a few mintues later that I had options and tools I didn't use, that death was completely on me and I immediately dove back in on a new character.

Get the free version and give it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031010042', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 846, 'last_played': 1487465236}
review:
This game isn't for everyone.  Try the free version from te4.org before you buy.  That way you won't be able to leave a bad review if you find out it's not for you.  There's definitely a community for this game though, and it's still being updated.

Loot: This is/was probably my favorite part of the game.  No gripes there.

Controls and UI:  Pretty decent.  Easy to figure out and use.  No gripes.

Graphics: It's like an old-school roguelike but with higher resolution bitmap graphics instead of text-based/ASCII sprites.  It's so much like an old-school roguelike that you can actually play it in text/ASCII mode instead of bitmap mode.  I wish the sprites had animations for walking, idle, attacks, and extra sprite variations for the direction sprites are facing.  This is probably my biggest gripe.

Character progression: The character classes are very complex and there are so many classes, potentially overwhelming to new players.  I wish the character progression was metered a bit better, introducing smaller sets of skill selections and character progression relevant to as-you-go progression in the campaigns or maps.  I felt a bit of analysis paralysis when choosing how to allocate points.

Story: I didn't find the story in the campaigns especially immersive or engaging; a few walls of text here and there.  I didn't expect much or anything here, so I wasn't disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999467764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9400, 'last_played': 1654143949}
review:
I have no experience reviewing games on this website, but I feel confident to reccomend this one.

 It is endless.

Contained in this retro ass machine of a game is a fantastically varied game design of a true master. Each class feeling distinct and new, each new playthrough feeling fresh. It's a rougelike of course, and it meets the name handily. Everything is threatening and intense, even rendered in the strange 2d gridmap the game plays in. It's a serious tabletop experience. It is a Fum Game. Play it if you can.

Anyway, I've rambled on a while. Have Fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056109052', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 68872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 157, 'playtime_at_review': 6610, 'last_played': 1711939117}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is a game with a [b]STEEP[/b] learning curve. At 110 hours in I've only just learned how to recognize when I'm strong enough to head to Dreadfell ([spoiler]90% of the time, I'm still wrong and I die[/spoiler]). This game requires massive dedication and an uncountable toll of death and loss, as with any roguelike worth its' salt. Once you understand the game's mechanics and flow, the amount of customization to each run is limitless and beautiful, and your ability to finagle your way out of every seemingly impossible situation will hit on an adrenaline rush like no other.  Much like Elite Dangerous, this is not a game for everybody, or even most people. But it is a game that everyone should try, to see if they have what it takes to become a Champion of Maj'Eyal and land a spot on those coveted leaderboards.

EDIT: Use Addons.

review:
Souvent copié, jamais égalé !
Son seul et unique défaut : Pas de version française. Une connaissance correct de l'anglais (un bon niveau 3°) devrait aider à faire ses premiers pas, mais je vous encourage à la développer car le jeu en vaut LARGEMENT la chandelle. Tant par ses superbes histoires que par ses quêtes ou souvent les écrits apportent en partie la solution.
Vous savez ce qu'il vous reste à faire : Bossez votre anglais ça vous servira... et pas que pour jouer d'ailleurs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992347632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 70602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6112, 'last_played': 1709408654}
review:
Review Spanish/English

Tras mas de 800h y contando, sigo recomendando este JUEGAZO.

Tienes un montón de clases y builds de las mismas, razas, equipo, dificultades etc.. una vez te pasas las 2 dificultades "tutoriales" (normal y pesadilla) empieza el verdadero juego en Insane.. menuda experiencia, aprender paso a paso los entresijos del mismo es una delicia. 

El juego puedes probarlo en su pagina web (juego base) y ya si ves que te gusta, apoya con sus varios DLCs (expansiones), estos los recomiendo comprar si te gusta el juego y quieres apoyar al dev, añade mas contenido y desafios. 

De verdad es un pasote, dale un try, eso si.. mucha paciencia, pregunta por el chat in-game o Discord oficial, merece cada centavo y tiempo de tu vida. El dev actualiza cada X tiempo, con parches grandisimos y expansiones. (si te vas a anuncios, podras ver los planes que tiene para el juego, en el Discord podras ver sneak peaks de lo que tiene preparado etc).

En lo personal me ayuda bastante, ya que paso todo el tiempo en casa debido a una enfermedad desde hace años y esto es lo mejor que me pudo pasar.. Gracias Dark God y gracias a la comunidad.

After more than 800h and counting, I still recommend this GAME.

You have a lot of classes and builds of the same, races, equipment, difficulties modes etc ... once you pass the 2 difficulties "tutorials" (normal and nightmare) begins the real game in Insane ... what an experience, learn step by step the intricacies of it is a pleasure. 

You can try the game on their website (base game) + I recommend buying its various DLCs (expansions) if you like the game and want to support the dev, they adds more content and challenges. 

Srly is a great game, give it a try, but... you need a lot of patience, ask for help in-game chat or official Discord, it deserves every penny and time of your life. The dev updates every X time, with great patches and expansions (if you go to announcements of the game on Steam, you can see the plans he has for the game, in the Discord you can see sneak peaks of what he has prepared for years to come etc).

Personally it helps me a lot, since I spend all my time at home due to an disease for many years and this is the best thing that could have happened to me... Thanks Dark God and thanks to the community.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995973525', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4627, 'last_played': 1681846761}
review: This is the best traditional roguelike RPG I've played, and it's a travesty that it took me so long to sink my teeth into ToME. Surprisingly deep and full of stats and numbers (almost to the point of being overwhelming at first), this game perfectly manages to capture what a turn-based game should be. I haven't even touched on the sheer replayability that ToME offers - as of writing this, I've spent 70+ hours just playing a rogue/shadowblade and figuring out their respective nuances. There are TONS of classes/races and talent trees that put other RPGs to shame. If you're on the fence about whether to buy and support the devs, you can download the game completely free from its website. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198052120751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 57261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4465, 'last_played': 1677913093}
review:
ゲーム自体は面白いですがとにかくバグが多いです、普通のRPGなどならまだ良いですがリセットが効かないローグライクで自分のミス以外の要因でプレイが台無しにされると本当に萎えます。
その上プレイヤーが少ないのか日本語wikiはまだしも本家の海外wikiも情報が少なかったり古かったりで元々セオリーを覚えるのが大変な事も相まって取っ付きにくさが物凄いです、ゲーム内で細かい事柄に対してほとんど説明が無い外部サイト前提なゲーム性も拍車をかけています。
ローグライク初体験という方などには絶対にオススメできませんし、ローグライク経験者でどうしてもやりたいという方でもsteam外で無料版が有るので時間とお金を無駄にしないためにも一度そちらで試してみることを強くすすめます。

author: {'steamid': '76561197966692029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 2883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2169, 'last_played': 1593717338}
review:
Take a look at the graphics of this game in the few videos you'll see on its store page.  Pretty old-school Sega Dreamcast, ey?

Don't be fooled.  This is a a surprisingly well-developed and deeply-engaging game.

You'll die.  You'll lose characters you've invested some time in, and be frustrated by it.  You'll be penalized for taking one wrong step in a game where movement is deceptively casual.  You'll wonder why Maj'Eyal has gotten so many overwhelmingly positive reviews.

And then you'll find yourself coming back to it, over and over again...

This game can be played in short bursts or in huge life-wasting swaths of time.  The chat is surprisingly active, and it wont take long before you notice that developers appear in it.  Real-world holidays are often accompanied by in-game events (bonuses, opportunities to complete elusive achievements, etc).  While Maj'Eyal is a roguelike, there are modes for more casual gamers; modes which let you survive past the accidental deaths a few times (but not indefinitely).  You'll discover that talent synergy is a key component to surviving those deaths, such that gear (while important) takes a bit of a backseat.

The game is very obviously a labor of love.  It's updated and expanded by developers who enjoy doing so.  There's so much variety to the character creation / growth process that May'Eyal will seem almost endlessly replayable.

Plus, it's a huge entertainment value for the money.  You'll slowly find yourself willing to buy all the DLCs just to show support for the developers.  

Try it, and find out why so many people have given it such glowing reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117774176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1613000030}

review: One of those classics that you can reliably come back to and enjoy through the years. Diablo style loot, procedurally generated dungeons, and an active online community (including in game). Play it in true roguelike mode for the full effect and experience the variety of character building choices/replayability. Other characters and classes become unlocked through game progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985144471', 'num_games_owned': 236, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 32194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14009, 'last_played': 1631828833}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065846893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 18666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14872, 'last_played': 1709072752}
review:
Turn-based fantasy adventure dungeon crawling done right. The ultimate in single-player strategy and tactics: 

where "infinite replay value" means your character build matters equally with how you use it against an infinitely variable enemy set, 

where the "Roguelike" single-life challenge is offset by more forgiving modes for the casual gamer, 

and where enduring support from its developer earns the enduring support of its players.

Buy ToME for all your friends, and tell the market that we want more like this; that quality, customization, and dev support are what we spend our money on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033677926', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 7009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3810, 'last_played': 1641270521}
review: Great game go play it, my favorite Roguelike. Good DLCs, even without them many things to unlock. Has steam Workshop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032613245', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1598888927}
review:
玩過的Roguelike最推薦的一款
雖然遊戲機制是回合制
畫面也簡單不像一些現代的Roguelike遊戲
但這款的內容絕對多到掩蓋上面那些缺點

正常的遊戲難度是一開始會有一兩條命 每升級到特定等級會再得到生命
要是不幸用完的話角色就會死亡(刪除)
這點可能有人會不習慣
但我認為這才是這類遊戲的精隨
謹慎的思考每一步 計畫角色的培養
經過這樣的努力後 在地城戰鬥獲得更好的裝備 慢慢解開這片大陸的故事
幾次的死亡是對於探索這個世界是遠遠不夠的
每個職業每個種族都有一些各自的故事
我光是一隻角色就玩上好幾個小時了
(剛剛不小心死了 所以才來寫個評論XD)

review: I love the character creation depth. They even have a viable class which can focus on dual shields, and it's for dwarves: out of my own head.

review:
as a character customization nut, really glad they allowed more character customization with the last major patch. i love being able to make me in video games tbh, and now i can die in all sorts of strange ways.

edit: okay this game has a unique feeling of flow and i find myself draining hours into this game hitting the z key and zooming through zones and shitting myself when i come into contact with rares and elites and such because they're usually the end of my playthrough. good game will play again after i've done raging from my last death.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031205864', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 8986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5480, 'last_played': 1677348558}
review: Could be a really good game, definitely has an in depth character creation and lots of content. What holds it back strongly is the absolutely atrocious UX when it comes to not communicating anything that happens in combat properly. Enemys will either be irrelevant or just kill you in 3 turns and you won't be able to really tell why or how. Some of them have a huge laundry list of 15-25 abilities and you're somehow supposed to figure out exactly why you died. You can look at the ability that killed you and see it dealt 200 damage, when looking at the sheet of the monster it's only supposed to do 60. Well, "you figure it out" says the game. I say, bad excuse for wasting peoples time with what effectively is RNG (since it's impossible to tell what actually happens). At this point I'm half convinced the game is just bugged one way or another but because it's so convoluted no one can tell and it will never get fixed. Shame, as there's a really fun game and character creator in there somewhere, hopefully someday someone will make something of it

author: {'steamid': '76561198012828546', 'num_games_owned': 2225, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1078, 'last_played': 1582176253}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal has pulled me away from my only Witcher 3 playthrough; it's that good. 

Wildly imaginative, deeply complex, and so much variety packed into a polished traditional roguelike of the Berlin Interpretation flavor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066559299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2372, 'last_played': 1690505818}
review:
If you enjoy rougelikes this one is a true classic so buy it plain and simple. If your new too rougelikes and wanna give them a try TOME is the best in place too start in my opinion. If your not sure if you'll enjoy it you can also download TOME from it's website for free and give it a try. If you have fun with it I still suggest buying on steam too support the developer.

These are just a few of the reasons Tales of Maj'Eyal is my favorite rougelike.

+ It's a classic game with a modern UI
+ No secret doors (God I hate secret doors)
+ I've been playing for years even before buying it on steam and i'm still finding new stuff.
+Multiple difficulty settings

author: {'steamid': '76561198006442724', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 7580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6167, 'last_played': 1581801221}
review: I am loving this game. I am impressed with so many things about this game but probably my favorite is the character building and how well the abilities  work together.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965600454', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 15912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5238, 'last_played': 1650784577}
review: If you like DCSS or any of the old school roguelikes, you will enjoy this game. There's a lot to learn and you will die over and over again, but that's the beauty of a real roguelike. If you're new to roguelikes, I'd say this is a solid introduction too. There's lots of beginner help on the web or you can dive right in and figure things out. The UI is extremely informative and things are fairly easy to understand. It's a more modern, but still pretty old school, dungeon crawler that you can really enjoy at any pace.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048280303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 176689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17467, 'last_played': 1710651354}
review: It is rare I write a review but sometimes I just have to. Started playing this game then went on a hiatus for a while. I usually play games like DS3, but this little gem keeps pulling me away. Back from my hiatus, i am averaging 60hrs per 2 weeks and although I miss my other games no ragerts. In my approx 300hrs i have beat one campaign once (there are 2 campaigns) maybe I suck, Maybe it is just that hard (i tell myself) but 1 campaign beat out of 2, with one class now a winner (death knight op) in 300 hrs... oh dear there is how many classes... 23 you say... so... that means 300x23x2= Who needs outside. And it cost how much? Gosh, now i feel rude. Could you guys release other DLCs i can pay for? Pretty close to clicking the "got this product for free" box lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198043781564', 'num_games_owned': 800, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 87734, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57606, 'last_played': 1679102441}
review:
This is absolutely THE BEST roguelike game I've ever played.  I had downloaded it for free a decade ago, played hundreds and hundreds of hours and thoroughly enjoyed it.  When I saw it on steam for just a few dollars I knew I had to pick it up again and was happy to pay this time to help support the developer.  It was an amazing game 10 years ago and it's only gotten better since.  Still being actively improved after all this time, and it shows.  

This game is worth way more than the asking price.  It's amazingly slick and polished, incredibly well-balanced, easy to pick up yet with enough depth, detail, lore, and options to keep it fresh and interesting even after many hundreds of hours played.  At nearly 1000 hours into this version I have yet to unlock anywhere near all the unlockables or even played every race and class available.  The huge number of available mods just make it that much better.  I can't say enough good things about this game.  It's one of just a handful of games which I use to measure all others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142381580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 31776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26084, 'last_played': 1631039707}
review:
This roguelike, while hard, harsh and with a learning curve, is relatively forgiving for players both casual and those who want a moderate challenge - both through the several difficulties, and though the different game modes which are Explorer, with an unlimited amount of lives, Adventurer where you start with a few lives and occasionally gain one upon levelling up, and Roguelike, where you start with only one life and can only gain more though rare items which are not guaranteed to show up during one playthrough.

This game is full of varied, unique classes (my personal favorites are Anorithil, Doombringer, and the Chronomancer classes) each with unique skills (and weaknesses). Unlocking a paticular class can take time and effort, and after over 400 hours playtime I still has a few classes to unlock.

Overall, this is a solid game, and both the base game and the expansions can definitely be recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966447704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2181, 'last_played': 1606447146}
review:
This is a game with fantastic depth. It furthermore solves many problems people thought were inherent to the roguelike genre.

1) "Adventure mode" gives you a very limited amount of resurrections. You get one additional life per 10 levels. This lets you make a few mistakes without losing a character, but still keeps the game hardcore.

2) Very visually expressive graphics... avoids the problem with ASCII-type roguelikes where you wonder "WTF is an @?" and then get killed randomly. Lightning bolts go off, zones of the map with some evil enchantment are clearly marked. Furthermore, has full mouse support so you can actually just mouseover anything and find out what it is. Customizable and very clear drag-and-drop UI. 

3) Tons of unlocks, some of which are easy and some of which are complicated and rare. This gives you goals beyond the simplistic "Find the amulet of Yendor" you see in most RLs. You actually get gains from each playthrough rather than starting from 0. In ways it feels like Tony Hawk Pro Skater (unlocking Rob Mullen is a joke, unlocking Darth Maul is damn hard).

4) Really diverse classes. A Possessor (possess monsters) plays completely differently than a Fighter, which plays completely differently from a Rogue. Position yourself, set traps, summon decoys... Lots of tactics beyond "press 1 for this ability, press 2 for this ability".

5) Excellent music.

All in all, buy this game.

review: TOM'E a rouge-like fantasy game. The game has a lot of stuff that is up to the player. You can save people. help people, destroy people. do nothing for them, be evil, go to the warped future, Fight yourself, learn of how magic came to be, learn the past, learn of the daemons, learn of the gods who taught mortals what power is, and many more things. There is a lot to this game. A lot of lore that I haven't got a chance to fully see. Remember its a rouge-like so you are bound to see it in a run. The main campaign is fun, long, and there are consequences to actions. There are several endings concerning races, factions, and classes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036621387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 11058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5332, 'last_played': 1655872357}
review:
The best class design of any RPG, bar none. I have been immersed in games my whole life and I've never seen anything that plays like the Temporal Warden - where games have traditionally balanced hybrid classes by penalizing their effectiveness at each, the developer (that's *the* developer, one guy) has managed to engineer a class that actively rewards you for switching between melee and ranged combat as frequently as possible without forcing your hand.

Also, in a genre full of "bumping"-based combat with maybe an ability or two, ToME is refreshingly rich. You will have an MMO-style hotbar, and you will need multiple rows. It's surprising that other combat-heavy roguelikes haven't made similar strides towards engaging combat, but the developer again shows originality and mastery.

Did I mention the game is jam-packed with lore, in a surprisingly original setting? While the world of ToME might look like generic fantasy at first glance, it has a way of unfolding its setting and story to you, a layer at a time, like a slowly-blooming orchid. If you give the game time to get to know you, it will get delightfully weird once you're ready.

In fact, the entire game has that same unfolding quality - all the most interesting classes, races and ability trees are locked when you start out, and that's probably for the best. ToME is *enormously* complex, with a community just small enough to give you a general idea of how to build your character without keeping any important information fully up to date. The default classes will stretch you plenty, and by the time you unlock the truly unique options you'll be ready to wrap your head around ToME's mad genius. This game is far from solved, and the 1.6 update shook up the meta in a way that is either frustrating or exciting, depending on whether you like your puzzle boxes pre-opened. Luckily, all previous incarnations of the game are available for download and play, and the base game is completely free on the developer's website.

ToME is not for everyone. The UI is opaque, the mechanics are dense, and enemies are punishing. But ToME also wants you to figure out how it works. The default permadeath option gives you a limited number of "lives", perfect for giving you space to learn from your mistakes without compromising the tension roguelikes are founded on (yet another way the game stands head and shoulders above its competition), and the difficulty sets in gradually once you enter the midgame. If you have ever wanted to play a roguelike, ToME is the best game to start struggling with and failing at. Just don't forget to read the wiki.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064505094', 'num_games_owned': 580, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 58767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13310, 'last_played': 1691266154}
review:
By far, the best game (not just "the best roguelike") I've ever played along with "Dwarf Fortress" and Illwinter's "Dominions" saga. 

If you already know them, buy "ToME" too. If not, "ToME" is a good place to start. 

You'll not regret it, worth every cent.

PS. Don't take my "hours on record" as a real measure. I've played A LOT offline. Two hundred hours don't even scratch the surface of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144670122', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 15430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9393, 'last_played': 1662797009}
review:
어려운 건 모르겠고, 전반적으로 불합리한 게임
애써 키운 캐릭터를 아차하는 사이에 -다음장- 하고 싶지 않다면 아머와 저항을 빠방하게 챙겨야 하고,
거기에 고난이도로 넘어가면 강력한 1:1 공격도 요구하는 만큼, 고난도 클리어가 가능한 캐릭은 손에 꼽는다
물론 그 이전에 뇌 비우고 오탭할 생각은 접어두는 게 좋겠지만.

그래도 나름 빌드 짜는 재미도 쏠쏠하고, 통상적인 퍼마데스 대신에 무한으로 죽을 수 있는 탐험 모드도 지원한다
언어 장벽 문제는 1.7 업데이트 때 번역 '툴'을 지원한다고 했으니 조금만 더 기다려보자

author: {'steamid': '76561198018569066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1673, 'last_played': 1580011718}
review:
TOME was really fun and I was happy to come back to it but 1.6 fucked absolutely everything and now the entire game is super grindy and prone to oneshotting you out of nowhere with overclocked rare mobs that have 20+ effective skill level in class abilities, level scaling now works like Oblivion so you can't ever be overleveled which means that a lot of chaff-clearing talents (like Cursed's "debuff anything 3+ levels under you") are now utterly worthless, and the AI is prone to retreating and forcing you to chase down mobs you can already provably mulch making everything even more of an exercise in attrition.

And what's worse is DarkGod clearly has obviously stopped listening to the community- who told him that a full overhaul was an awful idea and, hey look it totally was- about this so the likelyhood of these balance issues continuing is pretty high.
developer_response:
Heya

It is true that the 1.6.0 patch had indeed some scaling problems (thought not what you describe, level scaling "now working like in Oblivion" is false, it never changed how it works, there is a min & max per zone as it ever was and NPC skills have always scaled higher in talent levels than the player, because they don't have much equipment to compensate like the player do).
They have been and are being addressed with each of the next patches, same with the AI that was too good. For example the 1.6.6 release deeply altered how the AIs talk to one an other and how they try to find you so that it become much more fair.

In a more general context, I not only do listen to the community but I *enjoy* it, it has over the years been the source of many great improvements to the game and I intend to keep it that way :) Do I miss some feedback? For sure, I can only listen to so many people in the time I have, but I try to and all the 1.6.x releases should be proof as that as many of the highlighted problems has been looked at.

To finish, I want to make it clear that 1.6 however was simply too big (as I've already stated multiple times elsewhere), I crammed so many new things inside that it got out of hands and took a few patches to fix indeed. It was a mistake to do such a gigantic content patch and it most certainly will not happen again. So I'll keep doing like I've always done: making new free content updates, but I'll try to do them in smaller batches and more often instead :)

I really do hope you'll check out the latest changes, and in any cases I wish you fun in whatever games you end up playing :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198026782701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 3038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2427, 'last_played': 1688458504}
review:
tl;dr: If you claim to like "Roguelikes" but you dont have this game, you're either just getting into the genre, in which case go buy it. Or you're one of those people who thinks "Roguelike" means "procgen and permadeath". In which case buy ToME so you can see what an *actual* Roguelike is.
Review:
(Steam hours is nowhere near accurate)
When people talk about classic fantasy Roguelikes, theres two main "branches" 'hacks and 'angbands.  Out of those, theres two main games everyone who's into the genre considers the "must owns": ADoM and ToME. ADoM is a 'hack. ToME is an 'angband. They are different, so its hard to say one is "better" than the other. Both are amazing in their own right. I'm partial to 'hacks mechanics wise. But ToME is *the best* classic Roguelike out there as far as UI and depth. Great tiles, sounds, and the UI is *amazing*, with a webpage which logs all your stuff, a vault to keep items, multiple hotkeys, and in game chat so you can chat with other players (and it broadcasts your deaths and achievements too). Theres a zillion classes and races to unlock, amazing world lore, quests, multiple game settings - Dont like permadeath? Turn it off. Want multiple lives to give yourself a chance, but still permadiedie after they are used up? Straight permadeath? Difficulty sliders? Its all there.
This game is hands down amazing and everything awesome about a *real* roguelike, and thats even before you get the DLC expansions. If you at all like roguelikes, this is it - the cream of the crop of fantasy roguelikes. Get it. Right now.

About the microtransactions-
There was a big deal about "microtransactions" but there isnt actually microtransactions. DarkGod always accepted donations. Now you get a currency in return for them, which you can use to buy future DLC, cosmetics, let everyone play a special zone, unlock more vault slots. Basically, its as it always was, but now when you donate, you get something in return. Believe me, I'd be the first to be screaming if there was actually real microtransactions - but this is just a way to say "Thanks for supporting ToME" from the dev himself. Its not microtransactions the way most people think of them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999589693', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 23270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12949, 'last_played': 1704687233}

author: {'steamid': '76561198056166466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 25642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1175, 'last_played': 1698958182}
review:
Good potential with all the different classes and races that actually feel different when played. The chest for auto-converting loot at the end of the level that can hold infinite items is amazing. Story seems more interesting than in most games of the similar style.

Unfortunately ruined by unfun deaths and not communicating to the player (areas can have same level requirement, but starkly different difficulties; certain elemental resistances are key to surviving early on which you can't really find out before it's too late)

author: {'steamid': '76561198065027186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 38654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2572, 'playtime_at_review': 38654, 'last_played': 1711735857}
review:
''This game has deep tactical complexity'' - no, it doesn't. Instead I would describe it as pointlessly, inelegantly, increasingly overcomplicated. There's a difference.

''This game is a roguelike'' - yes. In practice this means you will start a run, set a goal, die for no particular reason and with no particular lesson learned, and be expected both to repeat the process and to enjoy it. What on earth?

''This game is continually actively developed'' - so don't get too attached to any particular class or game feature, because it will probably be changed beyond all recognition or removed entirely. My favourite is the item for Necromancer that forces you to wait 30+ seconds of real time for it to recharge if you want to play optimally.

''This game has a great community'' - I'm unconvinced. It seems to contain the same mix you'd find most places on the internet - some people are friendly and helpful, some are arrogant and argumentative. There are better, healthier ways to make friends.

''This game has great lore and storytelling'' - It's pretty good if you like to read about horrible things being done to people. I don't. Also some of it is at best old-fashioned in its view of women and at worst misogynistic.

Finally, this game is surprisingly laggy considering it's turn-based and tile-based and the graphics and animations are nothing exciting. I've had games with physics engines run far better.

TL;DR: Game is an infuriating, bleak, laggy mess. Would not recommend.

EDIT 2024: Everything above has become more accurate

author: {'steamid': '76561198058849689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 17000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1767, 'last_played': 1705982135}
review:
Update at 140h (on Steam, 200h+ off steam): I'm pretty sure this game is ruining my life. It's so, so, so addicting.

Original review at 20h+:
Challenging, rewarding, and interesting.
If you like a game that challenges you at every turn, this is it.
If you like a game with an extremely active developer, this it.
If you like a game where you have to learn from your mistakes to have any chance of proceeding, this it.
The story is pretty good, too, if that's your thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062945757', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1578306448}
review: 问了个报错问题没人解答我就自己来解决吧，首先你的电脑上不能有两个版本（官方版，steam版）的数据，很容易出问题，然后实在解决不了就删除个人文档你的账户名里的T-engine文件夹里的文件。最好备份下save，防止还能用。MOD冲突什么的。尽量都装最新版从工房里装吧，人物建立好就确定了用哪些MOD，玩了一半再添加MOD很容易报错。大概就这样，祝各位玩的开心，不要熬夜~

author: {'steamid': '76561197966726141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1604453640}
review:
As a long term roguelike player, I found TOME to be an excellent game. It cuts down on the item management and streamlines health and mana regen (among many other things) in a way that simply improves the flow of the game. An outstanding success.

I played the free version of this game for many, many hours and when it became available on steam, I took the step of buying it simply because I had played so many hours of it and the developer really seems like a good guy and is deserving of a bit of coin for his works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020969919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 5146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4578, 'last_played': 1677902428}
review: I'm not, by definition, a rogue-like fan, but ToME has me smitten. I think it's very approachable and friendly to new players, yet offers depth to satisfy hardcore players as well. The other aspect I like is that it has a fun "RPG" aspect to me. I know my review is not very in-depth, but these are the reasons why I love it. I never cared much for rogue-like games, but this game really feels like it is the king of the genre. It is so much fun to play because of many characters I can create and the levels of difficulty I can adjust. Yet there is substance in the game as you play through story and tons of items to collect, enhance, sell and explore.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978769189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 2434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1578775983}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is a roguelike that, while good, kind of defeats a lot of the purpose of being a roguelike. Allow me to explain.

ToME is heavily based on a game called Angband, which is both free and also quite old, dating back to the mid-1990s. It makes a bunch of changes to streamline Angband's core gameplay loop: Angband had a lot of grinding and also some really crap things the RNG could do to you, like disenchanting your weapons or draining experience on hit. They also took out things like potions, wands, and spellbooks - these were all mostly survivability options that got destroyed if you were hit by magic, which could be game-ending solely based on that and let to a lot of dumb behaviors like dropping all of your stuff at the start of a level.

The positives it has over Angband are numerous: the first is the streamlining, while the second is the addition of a mode in which permadeath doesn't exist - either you have a limited number of lives or an unlimited number, which prevents you losing simply because the RNG generated an enemy that instakilled you. There's also the fact that you're guaranteed access to all of your class's core abilities without needing to find certain items to learn them (this was one reason why magic users were basically non-viable in Angband).

Now, here's the bad part: for whatever godforsaken reason, the developers decided to put in an unlock system and lock about 75% of the character classes and racial options behind it, which can make or break viability for a lot of builds. The best example I can give is the Archmage class, which is one of the first classes you're likely to unlock. Archmages right now are basically non-viable past a certain point unless you also unlock a bunch of skill trees for them (unlockable skill trees basically only apply to the Archmage) that require an insane amount of grinding. 

Another problem I have is that the game.. has character builds. The problem is that each class really has one or two viable builds (if that) and doing anything but the most viable build is a one-way ticket to losing. The problem is that a lot of the viable builds require unlocks, usually of a particular racial option. I kind of wish that builds weren't a thing, because all it really does is restrict you to using the developer's forums to look up what the most viable build is. I get that not every build can be necessarily viable, but it seems like an extra wall to new players where a set progression tree would be much easier.

Overall, I think I could only recommend this game if you're a hardcore Nethack or Angband/Zangband fan, and even then it might be better to try those first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038121331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 2995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1671238606}
review:
Amazing game, easily worthy of it's "overwhelmingly positive" reviews.
Honestly I put off trying it for a long time due to how basic it looks in the screen shots above but once you start playing it actually grows on you really quickly. 
Tiles are easy to distinguish, spell/ability effects look nice, attack sounds are satisfying, monsters and areas are varied, lots of ways to adjust your build with random skills gained from quests, items and magic tattoos without being overwhelming or redundant.

If you are on the fence you can download the full base version FOR FREE on the developers website, it only takes like ~2 minutes to download the full game.
(any saves will carry over to the steam version)

Nice community too, people were willing to help me out with noob questions in chat.

My first character died to a rat necromancer. Yes I didn't take him seriously. The little sh!t had some powerful spells.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971368362', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 54900, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28369, 'last_played': 1655949686}
review:
Game balance has been completely wrecked by 1.7.  Tome4 was always a game of "will the monster generate with random abilities that synergize to kill me instantly".  As of 1.7, how monsters are assigned abilities makes that answer far too often a yes.

I've played the game extensively and I have to admit that my clears of nightmare/insane roguelike difficulty settings were half luck, half skill.  Luck part is gone, now.  Higher difficulty settings are minefields of instant deaths from monsters that just so happened to roll a few abilities that can instantly delete a well-defended player.

Don't buy until this gets fixed (again).

author: {'steamid': '76561197966957892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 4511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1434, 'last_played': 1676637704}
review:
The perfect roguelike for the casual and hardcore player alike.

You can tune the difficulty and even turn off permadeath if you hate the idea of losing progress, or turn it up to super-difficult where every skill use, movement and attribute point needs to be carefully considered.

The game also features unlockable classes and races, though if you hate that there's a mod that unlocks everything.

It also features many quality of life improvements over other rogue-likes, in regard to inventory management and combat. Debuffs can be critically debilitating, but are always temporary and let you keep full control of your character.

Well worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996739487', 'num_games_owned': 587, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 2476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1628387021}
review:
Let me start off by saying I like more modern roguelikes and I played a similar game Rogue Empire before this. It had consumables, a death clock and similar gameplay.

Then I found TOME. Stumbled upon it in a sale and after nine hours I know I am BARELY scraping the surface.

First off there is mechanical detail everywhere you look in your stats, skills, and abilities. I've played as mostly some of what I'm assuming are newer DLC classes? The Doombringer, Writhing, Possessed, Alchemist, and an Archer.

Combat is intense, choices are hard, the map is gigantic and as I approach near level 10-12 in a playthrough I see gear starting to evolve that I can barely get my hands on. 

There is no spamming magic potions, hope you inscribed some defensive/healing abilities or found some charms, or gear that can save your ass. Defensive utilities are a must to survive this game!

All sorts of fun abilities like having a tentacle for an arm, a magical golem that you can equip with gear. HELL EVEN A MASS OF WORMS IS MY SUMMON... but wait, hes humanoid and walking and has his OWN gear slots? and I can take control of him?

Traps, dungeons, an overworld to explore and a TON of classes I am yet to unlock. I hear rumors of time manipulation, I see skills and prodigies of great power I'm nowhere near achieving. I look forward to many more hours in this game and I'll update this review as I play it more. 

A total pleasant surprise, and for the winter, its on sale for a few bucks ( or about 10$ for all the dlcs )
