author: {'steamid': '76561198077726203', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 48092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29369, 'last_played': 1699936314}
review:
I bought this game because it reminded me of Pokemon Mystery Dungeon. I was right, but the complexity (and difficulty) was ramped up to 11. This game will bash in your skull from the start. Then it will beat you into submission once you get comfortable.

There are so many points of praise for this game, but I'll start with the developer Darkgod. A true legend, oversees the game, constantly makes balance changes, reads the forums, and makes a real effort. This has to be my #1 reason for why this game is great. It's a work of love and dedication.

The content of this game is deceptively deep. At first you'll have a couple basic classes: some warriors, rogues, an alchemist class, but that's about it. On your first couple playthroughs that will change quickly. You can pick up all sorts of other classes. But the real beauty of it is that not only does each class play inherently different, most usually have several ways to play them. The rogue for example, you can run a sneaky assassin type, or a throwing knife, trap dropping, poison applying trickster. Or something in between, whatever floats your boat. My friend suggested using heavy armour and forgoing mobility for defense. TRY ALL THE CLASSES.

The lore is unbelievable. There is so much lore. You'll pick up a scroll and suddenly be assaulted with a wall of text. Some people might get annoyed, but it's not like you have to read it, you can just skip it (what a shame though). The unique items all have unique descriptions, bosses all have unique descriptions, even regular stuff has flavour text.

The achievement list is massive, toting a whopping total of 1700+, but they're mostly duplicates from 6-8 different difficulties. Not that there aren't 200+ unique ones anyway. The flavour text on them is pretty funny too, and some of them are really no joke.

I guess if I'm going to give the downsides, the obvious one is the graphics are very retro-esque. Simple. If that turns you away I'm sorry to hear that. The sprites are impressively complex, and the animations are satisfying most of the time.

The second downside is how difficult the game is for beginners in the genre of strategy, turn-based roguelikes. I came in as a newbie and it ate me up. I'm thankful I stuck with it. There is a lot to learn about strategies and builds that work in this game. All I can offer is try all the dumb sh*t you can think of until something works. 

If a 95% review rate doesn't sell you after all this, let me offer you a story.

My latest run was a run of desperation. I recently built a new computer, but that meant that when I booted ToME, I had lost all of my characters. I was sad, but I figured it wouldn't take too long to unlock a character I'd like to play more, so I booted up a Thalore Berserker. Very basic. I played for about an hour, going decently, running a crit-based build. Next time I logged in the characters were all fixed so I could use all the classes I had before, but I kept with the berserker thinking, "may as well play this out to see where it goes". I pick up a couple items with high resistances, I learn a couple skills from escort missions (importantly lots of mobility), and then I pick up a prodigy (high power talents, you only get 2 per character) for my dash that lets me hop around on the battlefield quickly and violently. This quickly gets out of hand. I'm suddenly in the second half of the game, and find that my character has 50% damage reduction to all damage. This was my most recent winning run, out of seemingly the most basic class, I played it a way I thought was mostly a meme, and took it all the way. I did however lose the character trying to complete the 500 enemies of the sludgenest, since that challenge gets way out of hand very quickly.

Excuses aside I still suck at this game, and have only beaten it 4 times at the time of this review. (489 hours)

Also you don't have to pay for the game, you can get it for free from the website. https://te4.org/download (just google it if you don't trust the link) The cost that you're paying from steam is the "donator" benefits, which aren't a lot, some cosmetics, some item vault slots (which are only available after you're about 2/5ths of the way through the game if you can find it :) ) and a class I think? But I've never regretted it, and there's no other dev that deserves the money as much as Darkgod does. PLAY THE GAME, TRY THE DLC IT'S NUTS TOO.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042054632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7494, 'last_played': 1576724199}
review:
This game is so hard that it often feels like the computer is cheating.

So you use synergies to perfect your build over several unsuccessful playthroughs until it feels like you're the one who's cheating.

The system in this game works on a global time system, where the ticks only happen when you take an action or move. It's incredibly robust, and you can make decisions as fast or as slow as you'd like. I 100% recommend this game for anybody who enjoys theorycrafting and metagaming in their RPG's.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109141848', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1576464480}
review: This game is a shining example of what good user interface can do. Full control by keyboard alone, using the mouse only when its faster, soon becomes second nature. Even though its a 2D, tile-based, turn-based RPG, this fluidity and responsiveness becomes immersive in its own right. The baby steps will take you an hour or so, but soon you'll be zipping around like you were born for it. Even though some tricks feel unfair the first time they kill you, that trick then becomes something you can learn about and put in your own toolbox! As you progress, learning the mechanics of new enemies and classes through observation and experimentation is another echelon of character growth. You'll never get all the achievements, so don't worry about that. Just enjoy the adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026559664', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 11732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 47, 'playtime_at_review': 7760, 'last_played': 1711251720}
review: Tales of Maj Eyal is absolutely one of the best roguelike games out there. The complexity, skill variety, creativity in design, it's all there. Lots of lore as well, if you care about that kind of thing, but even if you don't, it's not necessary for the game experience. I think the thing I love the most about this game is that even if you make it a long way, the danger never really drops. There's always the chance that you're going to come up against new foes that you're not sure how to handle. ToME is such a great game because it gets what is most important thing in a roguelike (IMO): consistent challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023812775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9961, 'last_played': 1649737563}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal is, in my opinion, one of the most complete games out there. While story often takes the back seat (though many pieces of lore to be found), the gameplay really shines through with tons of unlockable classes and races. Though some classes play similarly, minor nuances to how you tackle combat really make a difference, especially in the mid game. This is easily my GOLD STANDARD for roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168821093', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2619, 'last_played': 1591453641}
review: TOME is a mod of Angband, which is a mod to Moria, and the whole thing was already big in 1990. If you like old-style roguelikes, such as Angband, you probably know this game already. If you don't, imagine an infinite dungeon-crawler with countless character and race combinations, million skills and different ways to die with the permadeath.  The good thing is that TOME is constantly updated, and even if you played it in the days of ole, you can be tempted to return to see what's new and try a new class or race. Unlike its predecessors, which were ASCII, this one even got graphics (some would say it's an improvement, I suppose), but it's still possible to play it from the keyboard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004095908', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 8274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2391, 'last_played': 1697510779}
review:
I've been playing ToME since I think 2003? It was a character graphics Angband variant set in Middle Earth, with a cool magic and skill system. I went many years without playing it, but happily picked up the Donator Edition here on Steam simply to support many hours of quality dungeon crawling in the past.

It took me a few hours to get to what makes ToME 4 so creative and expansive and cool. At first it felt a little clunky, with early maps mostly full of wolves and bears. But once I got a character up to around level 5-8 and started opening the skill tree, it got harder to put down. Even basic fighty types have a good assortment of moves to combo and buffs/debuffs, and some of the more exotic classes get pretty creative (like Alchemist, which has a full suite of pyromancy tools, itemcrafting skills, and an upgradable golem servitor).

Permadeath is how I've always played roguelikes, but if that's not your thing there is a gentler "Adventurer" difficulty with multiple lives, or a unlimited life "Explorer" mode. There's also multiple difficulties (which I think populates easier/harder monsters).

I was happy to discover the world of ToME 4 wasn't just a bland M*ddle E*rth with the trademarks filed off. The lore of Eyal is colorful, creative, and sometimes takes genuinely surprising turns. I've learned about a half-deaf (from explosions) halfling alchemist, a necromancer forcing his undead minions to enter a poetry contest, and gotten fashion assistance from a tentacled alien hologram. Eyal is a fun place to explore without getting mired in silliness — it's not super serious, but it maintains a cool pop-fantasy-horror-scifi sensibility.

ToME's difficulty curve can be, let's say old school. Things can go from trivial to OH NO within a couple of steps. You cannot just click an arrow key against a pack of monsters, this is a game that expects you to use all the tools at your disposal. I've had good runs come to an end REAL fast, but looking at it afterwards I've always been able to identify things I could have done better or more carefully.

Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup might be the best-balanced modern roguelike, which is important for a competitive community, but ToME has its own thing, an open world / sightseeing aspect, and the relatively slower pacing of the early game gives it kind of a Sims feel almost.

ToME 4 represents literal decades of development and if you enjoy clicking on monsters to kill them and take their loot, ToME is a wonderfully huge value.

review: Best roguelike out there. Favors tactical play and management of cooldowns over "I better keep this Potion of Resist Fire for the one specific encounter I'll need it, and if it hadn't dropped my character would have been dead regardless of what I'd done." The deaths are always your fault, and if that's too much stress for you, there's a non-permadeath mode for you to wallow in your failures.

review: Absolutely incredible. The online chat service makes the world feel even more alive and totally removes that lonely feeling some single-player games can have, particularly those without cutting-edge graphics to distract you. The depth and breadth of classes is astounding, turning what could easily have been a simplistic/repetitive combat system into something bursting with meaningful, tactical decisions and interesting strategic gameplay, while never getting bogged down by it's own systems. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198007233194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 10963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9093, 'last_played': 1661703143}
review:
Certainement le RPG / roguelike le plus complet qui existe à ce jour  ! Je ne dis pas cela en paroles en l'air. Je parle en connaissance de cause puisque plutôt fan du genre et avec des milliers de jeux, et Maj'Eyal, un jeu que j'avais abordé pour ensuite y revenir, n'a jamais eu son pareil en matière de richesse.

Le jeu se déroule en "tour par tour en pause active". C'est-à-dire que le monde s'anime et les monstres se déplacent dès que vous accomplissez des actions. Le jeu gère d'ailleurs très bien un système de vitesse capable de vous faire exécuter plusieurs actions avant que les monstres ne jouent les leurs, comme vous le verrez par exemple si vous jouez un Chronomancien (des sortes de combattant agissant en créant des paradoxes, comme dans l'univers de Matrix).

Vous pouvez jouer à la campagne principale, ou débloquer d'autres modes de jeu comme l'arène ou le donjon infini. Chaque mode recèle ses propres dangers.

En matière de roguelike, les modes exploration (sans mort permanente) sont disponibles (avec des succès propres !) et le mode normal lui, avec sa mort permanente, est présent mais avec plusieurs vies, ce qui est très adapté au style de jeu. En effet, si vous tombez sur plus fort que vous en prenant trop de risques, c'est très agréable de pouvoir reprendre et mieux gérer ! Et pour les plus durs à cuire, le full hardcore est aussi là.

Même si le jeu n'est pas multijoueur, il l'est tout de même, puisque vous pouvez parler à un tas de joueurs depuis le chat international ingame. Plus amusant encore, les morts de tous les joueurs et les succès exceptionnels sont annoncées hauts en couleur sur ce canal, avec de petites tournures drôles.  

Les races et classes de personnage sont nombreuses, on peut jouer des mort-vivants différents, des elfes ou nains classiques, des démons, toutes sortes de choses. Mon dernier aventurier est un Champion Squelette maniant épée et bouclier, et ayant appris un tout petit peu de magie.

Mais surtout, toutes les classes du jeu sont extrêmement détaillées. 

C'est même un modèle du genre avec une exploration de compétences variées réellement propres au thème de la classe, et très efficaces mécaniquement.

Tales of Maj'Eyal est un modèle de game design mais aussi un modèle de suivi par le développeur.  Vous ne serez pas déçu !

Vous y découvrirez votre propre forteresse, le cube de transformation qui fonctionne automatiquement et vous permet de ne jamais être encombré par le loot, et toute l'histoire du jeu. Par contre, vous serez peut-être intimidé par le nombre de choix possibles, ou la difficulté du jeu par moments. 

Essayons de brosser tout de même quelque défauts :

Le look du jeu est très adapté en somme, mais n'est pas le plus vendeur visuellement.
Le jeu contient d'innombrables bons écrits, et des quêtes intéressantes comme celles des Alchimistes, mais l'histoire principale n'est pas toujours engageante.

Les équipements finissent par procurer des effets de dégâts arc-en-ciel (càd de tous types de dégâts) et on ne gère plus vraiment le type de dégâts que l'on cause. On ne s'y intéresse plus trop. De même, résister à un type de dégât précis n'a d'importance réelle que contre certains boss. Pour moi cela contribue à moins apprécier le loot. Cela manque aussi de set items. 

A un certain stade du jeu vous trouverez ça trop difficile, jusqu'à bien maîtriser certains aspects. Ensuite, il est possible que cela soit un peu trop répétitif.

Cependant le jeu arrivera souvent à vous placer dans cette "zone de décision", là où vous êtes seul à gérer votre risque, le combat actuel, utilisant vos différents tampons et skills pour occire les ennemis les plus dangereux, ou vous enfuir; que ce soit via un town portal, ou en vous rendant invisible, ou en traversant les murs... tout est possible ici !

author: {'steamid': '76561198007573631', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 76848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17359, 'last_played': 1710054027}
review: I've been pc gaming since my family bought our first commadore 64.  This game is the absolute best rogue-like game I have ever played. The graphics aren't going to win any modern awards but they ooze nostalgic charm. The character development and massive range of races and classes are an absolute joy to use. The ingame systems are super tight and easy to read. There is a fairly steep learning curve but once you overcome that curve you are going to have a good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019868828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 39994, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26418, 'last_played': 1634374875}
review: One of the best roguelikes on Steam

author: {'steamid': '76561198344904307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1576082776}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal is an oldschool roguelike RPG with turn-based tactics. The game is characterized by many classes to attribute its character traits. You enter the world of Eyal in turn-based battles in an incredibly big world. Like every rogulike you should think about what you want to do before every step, because if you haven't paid attention a quest can fail very fast. There also no saving of the game score helps, because this is not considered by the computer game. Just that, the loving graphics and the fact that the game is not a grinding game, makes Tales of Maj'Eyal a good choice to increase your game collection. For beginners the game is rather unsuitable because the statistics and descriptions are very detailed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021914922', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2423, 'last_played': 1677463064}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019896699', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 8959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7231, 'last_played': 1644123307}
review: An interesting and deep roguelike with a set story. Each class feels carefully crafted and immensely creative, and manage to feel cohesive and tight while also allowing an incredibly big build variety. Lots of replayability, although it is hindered by tedium in some of the game systems, and an inflexible story-based progression. The gameplay can become very tedious very quickly, but since the focus is on character progression, I can forgive this, since the latter is quite good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031339397', 'num_games_owned': 89, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 24613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18308, 'last_played': 1676907935}
review: Recommended to anyone who has enjoyed classic dungeon divers such as Nethack or Angband. This has a similar feel to it, though the graphics are better than the old ASCII art. There are enough variations between character races & classes to provide a lot of replay-ability. I enjoyed the process of unlocking new character options. For those who don't care for the "die once & your game is over" aspect of old roguelikes, there are additional play modes that allow for exploration and are a bit more forgiving of mistakes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991003690', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 40255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33512, 'last_played': 1616149913}
review:
I have been playing all sorts of RPGs for nearly three decades. ToME has more build options than the next ten combined.

It's not the most story / plot-decision rich, because it's a roguelike. The setting is pretty interesting, though, and the story that is there is serviceable enough. But really, if you're playing ToME, it's for the incredibly deep and flexible combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109041809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2420, 'last_played': 1705847669}
review:
Great roguelike, so if you like these kinds of games this is a no-brainer. Just get it. And this is coming from a Nethack/Adom-junkie. ;)

At first I felt the game was pretty bland, and to be honest, after my first time playing I uninstalled it. A year or so later I installed it again and retried, and found that it was quite nice, with a lot of character and class options, plus unlockables. Right now I'm playing a skeleton brawler, which is totally different from anything I've played before. 

I can recommend this to people who like roguelikes or are new to the genre and want to try it (there is an explorer mode which will disable permadeath), just remember that there are probably some situations you won't be able to handle so back out while you can and come back later!

author: {'steamid': '76561197978028608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 38141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37380, 'last_played': 1677966108}
review:
I've played this for years and still come back time and time again because it is exceptionally well maintained and receives free updates/revisions constantly. The creator is putting all of his heart into the game and it shows. 

Highly recommended for people who enjoy tinkering with builds and gear to master the tactical combat challenges.

review: Best roguelike I've ever played. Still under development by a very passionate individual :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197982751561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 36078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32243, 'last_played': 1677530860}
review: A true classic for roguelike fans - I'm not sure you can find a better one out there! Worth every penny. Endless replayability with many races and classes to unlock and experiment with, and the freedom to customize each character's build as you see fit. Adjustable difficulty, so it can be friendly for newcomers, yet punishing for veterans seeking a challenge. Still being updated after all these years, and still going strong!

author: {'steamid': '76561198134445376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1697237794}
review:
Замечательная игра с массой достоинств. Недостатки есть конечно, но по большей части лишь из разряда вкусовщины.
В мощный плюс к игре приведу момент, который как-то упускается из ряда других обзоров - а именно работа разработчика над своим проектом, такой прилежности к обновлению и улучшению TOME мало где встретишь! Сколько уже прошло лет, но для нее все так же появляется что-то новенькое и интересное!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048584200', 'num_games_owned': 2987, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 12236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12235, 'last_played': 1575348451}
review:
Ottime dinamiche di gioco e tanti contenuti lo rendono vario e stimolante.
I nemici di ogni livello vengono generati tutti al primo ingresso e restano quelli, evitando il grinding. Se proprio si vuole accumulare esperienza ed equipaggiamento in più ci sono alcune aree opzionali e si trova sempre qualche nemico in giro per la mappa del mondo in alcune fasi di gioco.
Le varie classi sono molto diverse fra loro e già di per sé altamente personalizzabili.
All'inizio sono disponibili solo alcune classi e razze, le altre si scoprono in gioco e offrono dinamiche complesse.
Ci sono diversi tocchi personali rispetto al fantasy classico che ho apprezzato.
Il livello di difficoltà è regolabile, la modalità normale è una bella sfida.
Ci ho giocato molto anche prima che arrivasse su Steam e ancora mi diverte!

review:
This is not a normal Classic-Rogue like.
You will...
 ... find races and classes that can be unlocked and played. (Replayable)
 ... write mods is LUA. (Learn to code)
 ... click on 'Z': auto walk around and grab stuff in the dungeon, until find a enemy. (Quick game)
 ... You die A LOT. ("Losing is fun" <= Dwarf fortress motto)

All hail to DarkGod our saviour!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985685663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 9555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5205, 'last_played': 1706167757}
review:
The game has so much depth, and so much replayability - honestly, it's the top tier Rogue-like that should be in everyone's game list at this point. The main selling point of this game is the flexibility in every playthrough - its up to the player to decide how they want to set up their character, their difficulty settings, and even 'campaign'. 
It got me through college. I love this game. Just an FYI though, you can get the main game for free from the website. If you buy it here, you're helping support the developer. (https://te4.org/)

author: {'steamid': '76561197996125564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 60759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41920, 'last_played': 1686325306}
review: This is a classic roguelike, refined and optimised. The many dungeons all feel genuinely different, and most are only three levels deep, so you never feel like you're just slogging through the same map repeated. There is no grinding. There are no consumables, which encourages you to use all your skills and abilities, rather than hoarding. There are many different classes, with interesting and different playing styles. You don't have to like all of them, and that's ok! I don't! because you should be able to find something that you do like.

review:
Great game! Learning curve is a little steep but it is fun once you figure out what the game is all about. Give it a few dozen deaths before you really grasp the game. The unique classes and builds is what draws me to this game. I LOVE VARIETY. So if you want to try many different flavors of play style this game is for you. Don't mind the graphics, enjoy the gameplay.

Honestly I only wrote this because steam required me to review a game for some reward, but honestly this game deserves extra attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970650315', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 32573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19997, 'last_played': 1706451775}
review:
A turn-based roguelike with randomised loot and enemies. Fun if you are patient and like planning/learning from your failures. Immensely satisfying when you win, lots of unlocks, classes, races and cheevos (1755 achievements as of typing). 
 If you don't like games that delete your character when you die, you can also play exploration mode which gives you infinite lives; if you feel so inclined.

Also, it's cheap as hell right now, and well worth the dosh.

Also also, I wish I wouldn't get too greedy with the chests.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023828387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 137711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1724, 'last_played': 1709233394}
review:
Пожалуй, самый крутой рогалик в стиме, каждый найдет что-то свое: сотни талантов, умений, экипировки..
Вариации классов, часть доступна изначально, остальные нужно "открывать" выполняя хитрые (без гугла не разберешь) условия
Единственный минус, игра на чистом инглише, информации много, но в целом все понятно
Вариативность - это все :)

Upd. 1.7 принес много нового, удивительно - как такая, казалось бы "простенькая" игра на первый взгляд, содержит в себе столько тайн и загадок

Кстати, умельцы завезли русский язык, правда пока в виде аддона, возможно DarkGod когда нить включить в полноценный релиз)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003423374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 112170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79356, 'last_played': 1700598933}
review: One of my all-time favorite games. Tons of replayability, A dedicated developer who keeps releasing updates. It's available for free to try out (entire game, no dlcs though). What's not to love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106500666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4149, 'last_played': 1703719512}
review:
Amazing rogue-like, with the best implementation of live-die-repeat I've experienced so far, enough content and possible builds to keep you coming back every time, and one of the best indie devs in the industry when it comes to content, player interaction and attitude. Overall 8,5/10

Pros:
-Simple yet satisfying combat
-Particles that fly everywhere, but doesn't trigger epilepsy headaches, always nice
-HUGE amounts of contents, builds and dungeons
-Amazingly priced, would buy base game at 22$, but you can get that + DLC for less
-Dev is phenomenal, listens carefully to what the community wants, consistently updates and makes fun rework

Cons:
-Balance can be weird, classes with innate regen and/or AoE dominate, while classes without like Rogus and Rangers kinda suck
-Random bosses are very random, would prefer consistent difficulty over 2-shotting one and then being 2-shot the next time
-Easy to burn out if you play for hours upon end
-Most cool non-basic classes are either end-game or DLC

author: {'steamid': '76561198097738062', 'num_games_owned': 759, 'num_reviews': 128, 'playtime_forever': 5354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3722, 'last_played': 1621674406}
review: ToME looks awesome at first glance - so many features! - but I dunno. It's somewhat widely acknowledged that the early game is boring, and most of your more promising runs will just be ended by some BS one-shot out of nowhere by an enemy that spawned with particularly nasty skills. Really, none of my deaths ever felt fair or taught me anything, besides "don't get bored and walk fast." Also, it has none of the resource management of typical roguelikes - items are shoved to the side as much as possible, healing is free outside of combat, etc. It's pretty much all about skill trees and builds, of which there are tons. If you're into that, it can be a good game, but when I reinstall it I always end up disappointed. It looks more impressive than it is to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010331526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 20459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16579, 'last_played': 1622971749}
review:
I've given this game every opportunity to make me like it, and I want to like this game. However, ToME will never be a good game as long as it relies on a formula of trudging through legions of trash mobs only to have your game ended by a mob with a perfect mathematical combination for destroying you in one or two hits or stunlocking you until you're dead. The game is poorly paced and doesn't really pick up and get interesting until the mid-game. The early levels are quite dull, but you'll spend 99% of your time there as cheap deaths will send you back to start again and again and again. While there is a lot of work put into this game considering the lore, worldbuilding and incredible depth of character development, all of it is undercut by the aforementioned mechanics ruining the game experience.

I give up trying to enjoy this game, it clearly doesn't want to be enjoyed. It just wants to snicker like Mutley as it adds another character sheet to the dead character pile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131447704', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 7356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6990, 'last_played': 1709790754}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025582477', 'num_games_owned': 965, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 24665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14532, 'last_played': 1696191925}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995451654', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 31205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27528, 'last_played': 1636851397}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is admittedly a game available for free through the website, though a purchase over steam affords some additional features normally only available to donators. I have spent enough time on this game to say it's very worth the small investment, and each major DLC tends to add its own campaign or new content worth at least 5-10 hours, depending on your personal luck and experience, and far more replayability.

Though overall positive, I would say it does have a few downsides, including questionable documentation and some basic features (like planning out a character) are only avaialble through mods available on the website, many of which may be out of date.

On the flip side, mods for this game are in LUA and are comparatively prevalent. If you have a problem, there very well may be a tweak, new class, or what have you to make your experience what you want to play.

Pros

author: {'steamid': '76561198035964558', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2000, 'last_played': 1686898974}
review:
Excellent game. I highly recommend you try out "Exploration Mode" when creating your first character. It gives you unlimited lives and more importantly - unlimited respeccing of Generic Points and Class Points. It helps you learn the game as it can be very unforgiving at times. Perhaps even downright brutal.

While the graphics are lackluster, the combat and the combat system is nothing short of excellent. I have no complaints about the AI either. They seem to be quite intelligent in killing you effectively. 

Tips: Just because you have good AOE does NOT mean you should try to take on a horde of enemies at once. 

Overall 9/10 - as high as I can rate a game with graphics that leave something left to be desired.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990822782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4964, 'last_played': 1503249342}
review:
Очень хорошая игра, рекомендую всем, у кого есть много свободного времени и желания играть в пошаговые RPG и рогалики. Я даже не знаю, что здесь писать, игра совершенно необъятная — сотни жизнеспособных билдов, различные способы играть, различные режимы игры, которые меняют абсолютно всё, отличный, хотя и местами неочевидный баланс (иногда неясно, что нужно всё бросать и на максимальной скорости бежать из локации, бросая квесты и лут). Существует ещё бесплатная версия, в которую я играл раз в 10 больше, пока игра не воявилась в Steam, по крайней мере зацените её, она практически ничем не хуже.
Кстати, основной квест довольно интересный в плане сюжета.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044820400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 18903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16809, 'last_played': 1694705434}
review:
I've played this game mostly out of steam, don't let the hours fool you.

Absolutely amazing game. If you like turn based rpgs and interesting character builds, this is for you. Classes in this game are something really unique, can't compare to anything I've played before. You can play one class in many ways, which gives you alot of replayability, and talking about replayability.. randomized loot, enemies, layouts.. and you can unlock f tons of new classes and races by playing, or if you feel lazy, just grab unlock all classes/races from steam workshop.

Learning curve is steep in some ways, but if you can get past that, you are looking at a masterpiece.
All hail DarkGod! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198046539157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 31276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5842, 'last_played': 1699331886}
review:
2019: Best roguelike I've played in 30 years. Eat it, Nethack!

2021: Changing the vote to thumbs down. The game is solid, but the developer thinks that constant development and meta-shifting for an oldschool inspired rogue-like is a good idea.

I'll give it another spin when he's done developing it. Until then, don't bother.

It's been two years, and the game isn't a finished product. Continually shifting his vision for what this game wants to be, the developer refuses to give you a final version.

2023: It has been two more years, and I have returned a more patient man. The game is good. Thumbs up, DarkGod. Keep on doing what you do.

review: Tales of Maj'Eyal is one of the better fantasy style roguelikes I've ever seen.  There are some issues, like the completely pathetic micro-transaction shop, poorly written lore pieces, and inaccurate 'min level' indicators.  But, ignoring all that, the classes are varied and interesting, there are unlockable race/classes, and a huge list of achievements.  It's definitely worth the time, even if it does some things completely incorrectly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994290215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 116759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52668, 'last_played': 1696687711}
review: Really fantastic game, although the learning curve is steep and like all games some classes are more powerful and easier to play than others. However with enough experience and skill you can do even the most "impossible" things such as play an Archmage with anti-magic which makes the class skills all but useless and beat the game. Really worth the $ my play time explains it all, i have yet to master this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993185244', 'num_games_owned': 661, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 31556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12422, 'last_played': 1702465551}
review:
EDIT BECAUSE I JUST DISCOVERED THIS ABOUT THE GAME:
IF YOU BUY THE DLC YOU CAN BE A SKELETON WITH A TENTACLE ARM AND BARF BLOOD ALL OVER YOUR ENEMIES AND HAVE A BUDDY MADE OF WORMS
IF NOBODY FINDS THAT INFORMATION HELPFUL I WILL BE PROFOUNDLY SAD

it's a roguelike. but it's a better one than most of the ones that get on here.

if you're worried about difficulty, don't be, there's several game modes and permadeath options, including explorer which straight up gives you infinite lives, though i prefer adventure which just gives you a life every couple of experience levels. 

the game itself is fun. there's a variety of classes that play differently, and you can play them in different ways. you can unlock new classes and races by playing the game. It's a roguelike, but things like scrolls and potions have been cut out and replaced with "infusions" that are tattooed on to your characters skin and can be reused. you'll still find random loot but generally you'll find useful things, and theres stores to buy things from too. don't worry about being stuck in store menus for ages selling everything you found, you can choose what things you found to keep, and the rest are automatically turned into gold when you change areas. the game's developers seem to really hate grinding, so once you go through an area, that's basically it, you're not getting more enemies. if there's something you don't like, the game has a lot of add-ons and modifications players made for you to find in the workshop, which are definite quality of life additions worth looking through. i definitely recommend "escorts enhanced" because there are nine random escort missions with great rewards and they're really hard to do without it since they'll move forward with considerable disregard for actually being safe if you don't "escorts enhanced."

the lore is pretty cool too, so that's nice.

this really is a good game and i recommend it if you like turn-based roguelikes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992216244', 'num_games_owned': 3055, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 27938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12151, 'last_played': 1668756413}
review:
While it may appear rough around the edges (and still sport some of the flaws that it did back when I started playing years ago), Tales of Maj'Eyal is an excellent game that is somehow elegant for all its clunkiness. It is an extremely deep, challenging, and more than occasionally unfair game. 

You will die. Often. If you're like me, you'll keep coming back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009176302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 26642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19185, 'last_played': 1655683814}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020850565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 147074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105510, 'last_played': 1660146044}
review: Tales of Maj'eyal has been one of the most accessible roguelikes I've ever played.  Plentiful tuning to adjust to player preference from difficulty and amount of lives, a variety of different routes to take and sometimes random dungeon and event availability.  A lot of mixtures of classes and races for interesting different twists.  Generally each class has 2-3 reasonably valid main approaches as well, so a lot of variety right in the base game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987041850', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1639400447}
review: Świetna i trudna gra, nie dla słabych ludzi :) Pozwala na setki godzin gry i zabawy, a także na dosyć proste tworzenie własnych addonów do niej. Początek jest dosyć łatwy z dobrą klasą, ale i tak nie ominie was śmierć. W skrócie taktyczna gra z możliwością customizacji UI i dobrze napisaną historią świata, polecam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973608628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 16400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6289, 'last_played': 1709760716}
review: This is an amazing game accept for one glaring issue. That is the fact that you can be killed instantly with almost no possible solution for preventing it and at any level at any time. Games like Dark Souls give you a chance to learn and adjust each time you die however in this game each run many of the elite enemies are random in the abilities, level, gear etc. so it is almost impossible to prepare for anything. This is the only thing that can potentially leave players hating the game. With that said there are many options available for the player to sort of build a character around certain styles but like i said if the enemies are all random then there really is no point in all of the ways a player can focus their builds. In all it is a very fun game but it its like pounding your head against a wall.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981435013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 1379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1700064515}

review: The best Roguelike around for me... (i cannot play the ones with ASCII graphics, it burns my eyes - and my soul) Lots of character options to unlock, tons of powers, interesting campaign. Dev keep pouring love into this, years after. A true work of passion. One grippe only: i'd like more randomization in the campaign. after playing trough it for 20 times, the fixed order and always having to go trough same locations gets a bit boring. Especially the beginning... Looking forward for more!

review:
character choices include:
-faceless dwarf who hates everything to death
-ghoul that vomits on their zombie friends as a healthy snack
-elf that is here to help out their wizard friends by removing the magic from their bones with helpful acid
-halfling that sips mommy juice while their golem is beaten to death by rats
-sickass skeleton that punches good
-ogre jesus freak
-tiny dragon monkey covered in moss
-brain wizard whose mum lets him have two swords
-orc (featuring gun)

please enjoy playing these engaging characters for 17 hours of interesting tactical combat before being murdered by a snake with throwing knives

this game good

10/10

review: My favorite Rogue-Like overall. I enjoy the class/race system and I like the combat quite a bit. It is more based around skills/abilities than it is just bumping. There is plenty of bumping if you want to do that, but it makes everything more fun. Normally only casters get fun abilities, but in ToME all of the classes do. It's great, and the developer is still patching the game with content!

author: {'steamid': '76561198047134353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 43102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31606, 'last_played': 1671165886}
review:
Every patch has some gamebreaking bugs, whether it's a memory leak that makes the game unplayable after a couple hours, or suddenly losing 5 turns in a row for no apparent reason, or a frozen copy of you that shares your HP spawning on the level, resulting in some unseen and unseeable enemy killing you or you accidentally killing you if you don't pay attention.

That said, out of all the roguelikes I've played  and liked - Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup, Dungeons of Dredmor, Cogmind, CataclysmDDA and more - this is the one I keep coming back to. The class variety is real, from spacetime-abusing Chronomancers, to the massively aggressive Doombringers, to the body-stealing Possessors, it makes most other games look like half-hearted attempts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145186284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 32097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 145, 'playtime_at_review': 25939, 'last_played': 1712259656}
review:
For a game within its genre of rougelikes, this is one of if not the best I have experienced. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone with a fondness for "classic" rougelikes.

More legitimate pros I can number are:
-no tedious systems like hunger or ammo count
-a wide selection of exotic classes and races (no boring pick between 3 archetypes every single fantasy game sees)
-control over difficulty (suitable for both those who want hardcore difficulty or a leisure experience)
-good lore
-replayability (see the previous list of classes and races, plus a long chain of patches that kept things fresh for years)
-majority of content is available for free
-no pay2win (the game depends on donations, which can net you cosmetic bonuses and nothing else)

As for the cons:
-roguelike

I am aware that the genre isn't for everyone, and that is fine. I just hope the game recieves the recognition it deserves- the people working on it are passionate, especially the dev, and have stuck to working on it for a couple years now. The players are all welcoming and helpful, and make good addons (mods) on top of that.





Are they gone? The admins, I mean. 
They are?
Good. Post yeek

author: {'steamid': '76561198259208594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 11071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5218, 'last_played': 1691901496}
review:
Having played Rogue, Nethack and Angband among others since release I was sceptical of a new game being able to encompass what the classics did with all fancy new things they introduced (yep, when it comes to roguelikes a decade old game is still new - sorry kids). 

This game exceeded all expectations and the quality of life things introduced simply makes an old style game even better. Play in the mode it's meant to be played in (rogue) and expect at a minimum 80-100 hours before you finish it. The first time; With one race/class combo.  You unlock other playable classes as you go along and it's a really nice touch and doesn't limit the game because you will still be trying to finish it on your first class. After all that there is still nightmare, insane, and madness rogue difficulties.

 There are also easier modes to those new to the genre where you can get extra lives and dead doesn't meant dead if that sort of thing interests you.  

Something I didn't see mentioned when I was scanning through the reviews before I bought the game was that even though it's a single player game, there is an in game chat that not only allows people playing to interact if they wish, but also displays when someone dies (showing their level, class, and where), along with when someone gets an achievement, and allows item posting. A really nice touch for a single player game. All of this is of course optional so if it's not your thing you can just turn it off... but I feel for the people when I see for example a level 47 rogue difficulty player dying heh.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962983409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 26803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12276, 'last_played': 1688679508}
review: This game is badass.  Its a hugely complicated, very intense roguelike that will kill you at each and every opportunity.  The game isn't about winning, its about going on sick adventures in a very detailed world and getting tons of cool items and abilities, seeing neat monsters and cool graphics given the limitations inherent to tile-based systems (which just means it run on dang near anything).  You become a strong warrior or mage or whatever you are, things that defy description and are super fun, and you reach Olympian heights of power and prestige and then are annihilated after you get hit for a million from across the map by something you couldn't see or even know existed.  You may never know what the hell just ground you into paste in like three turns, and that's okay.  You deserve this.  All of those sins... the game knows.  The game is watching.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019541635', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3249, 'last_played': 1657333129}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976575880', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 122641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57749, 'last_played': 1710031501}
review:
Look at my playtime.  Now realize I played the free version of this game outside of steam for over a year before i bought it, and frequently after that in various places where it is inconvenient to sync my steam account, probably doubling that number.  This is, simply, undeniably, a fantastic game.  For the price ( >75% of the content is FREE) there is none better in the lexicon of gaming, certainly within the genre, and arguably anywhere.

Why is it so addictive and delightful?  It is, at its heart, a tactical decision making game.  You pick a class and build its talents and gearset to accumulate resources that allow you to win battles.  The game throws randomly generated (within a predictable subset, for the campaign, or truly random, if you unlock that feature) dungeons at you to challenge your build and your skills at resource management.  I could gush endlessly about the finely-tuned balance, about how every class has multiple viable builds presenting you with playstyle variety galore, and about the fascinating and challenging enemies and lore to spice up the indefinitely variable tactical puzzles presented by combat -- but that would take way too long.

Instead, I'll just end with this:

Randomly bumbling into an extremely challenging tactical situation where your death is nearly assured is honestly chilling and gut-wrenching, especially in a game you have already spent 5+ hours progressing through, much less one where you are 20 hours in and nearly done with the campaign.  Multiply that extensively if you are in rogue-like mode and won't get another chance should you die.  Commensurate with that tension--taxing your tactical skills to the limit, squeezing out every resource of your build and inventory and then overcoming certain death by the seat of your pants brings a rush of victory like little else I have felt in all my years of gaming.  Even when you lose, there is enduring additional entertainment to be had from reviewing where you went wrong, kicking yourself for mismanaging your resources, and developing ever more-detailed strategies to get you further on your next run.  And this entertaining strategy-building is PER CLASS.  This game has 30+ CLASSES.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys tactical thinking.  It is the only game I played longer than World of Warcraft.  It is the only game I've ever played that I loved so much, I was legitimately angry it didn't cost more, and sent the developer an extra donation in gratitude for innumerable hours of enjoyment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033456030', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 54842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15712, 'last_played': 1708391671}
review:
Old school RPG with a LOT of classes/race combinations. Complex but not hard mechanics to understand, TONS of items, KILOTONS of achievements (repeated ones based on difficult settings but still!) and a pinch of humor :D

To old gamers like me - If you loved Castle of the Winds just buy this. It's the same playstyle but they have AUTO-EXPLORE! (screams of happiness). The auto-explore (z key) makes your character roam the whole map picking up items and it stops when a POI or monster is in sight. Very well done feature!

review:
By and Large one of the best roguelikes, for me it strikes the right balance of randomness and planning, being punishing but not in a way that feels brutally unfair.

I mean just look at the amount of hours I've put into it, hard to describe, but has an extensive amount of lore too if you're into finding that sort of stuff. Also the DLC are all worth I'd say, even if some complain about some making the game harder, it's in a good way trust me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970639618', 'num_games_owned': 402, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 14209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7539, 'last_played': 1604960830}
review:
I've been playing ToME for over 10 years.  The game just keeps pulling me back into it through it's depth of mechanics, turn-based play-style and RNG elements that allow for some wonderful runs (or some heart-breaking ones).  Awesome developer (the DarkGod, unhallowed be His name) who keeps things fresh by fixing, re-tooling and adding to his masterpiece, year-over-year.  

Give this game a try if you enjoy a deep class- and skill-based roguelike!  It has plenty to offer both the casual and hardcore out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198881279948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1709583985}
review:
I recently bought this game on steam to support the developer, my actual play time is over 120h and I'm sure its going to be many more hours in the future. 

This game is just amazing and very unique, there's nothing quite like it. The diversity of classes and talents to try out is staggering, and there are so many fun and diverse character builds to discover that this game just never gets old. 
The game mechanics are very well thought out and balanced, so if you die (which you will A LOT), it's never because the game placed you in an unbeatable situation, but rather due to a mistake you made (in my entire playtime, there was just a single exception to this pattern, where a very high level monster spawned in one of the early dungeons and I was one-shotted on sight). There is so much depth to the game that I still consider myself kind of noob after more than 120h, I can pretty reliably clear the game on normal difficulty, but I'm still not good enough to make it through one of the higher difficulties (I'm pretty sure I could with one of the better classes, but I'm still having so much fun trying to clear normal difficulty with every class that I didn't seriously try it yet). 

Even if you've never played a roguelike before (I didn't before discovering this gem), if you like fantasy RPGs and tactical combat, then PLEASE do yourself a favor and give this game a shot - I'm certain you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999170406', 'num_games_owned': 1344, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 36819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20379, 'last_played': 1581768757}
review:
最优秀的Roguelike游戏之一，只专注于战斗，更像是一款难度超高的战棋游戏，对策略、走位、引怪以及角色的天赋技能养成，施法极其考究。
9.1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197975785141', 'num_games_owned': 850, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 5584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5553, 'last_played': 1601934287}
review:
ToME is one of the best roguelikes I've ever played, and I'd even dare to say one of the best roguelikes ever made. 

TL:DR - buy this game. Right now: There's a huge variety in builds that can keep you entertained for hours, the writing is good, the game-play is challenging and fun, and oh boy will you get hooked

I could go on and on about ToME, I've played nearly 100 hours. But I think I can sum my love of this game up best with a simple story:

My first character who got even remotely good was a brawler. I was enjoying the heck out of playing him. He was super powerful, a veritable one man army. Played for many hours, got all the way through the story, got to the VERY FINAL ENDGAME FIGHT.

Died.

Like a chump. Wasted, barely even scratched the Big Bad.

I was devastated - it felt like a kick in the stomach, I was so invested in this character, all the unique and rare artefacts they'd gathered. And now they were dead. Rogue-like-deleted-save-dead.

And then I had to go to bed for work, so I did... 

But I couldn't sleep, because I was plotting my revenge.

So I went to work the next day, ridiculously tired...

And plotted my revenge some more.

Then I got home, and I put all that plotted desire for vengeance into building a pure, rage-fuelled abomination of a rogue-like machine character - and I went through the game again, having a harder time because instead of spec'ing power at that moment, my every choice was dedicated to killing the Big Bad. I played like a demon, until I got back to that final Big Bad Boss Chamber, and I still had a tough fight, and with maybe 4 HP remaining out of several thousand, I beat them to death with my specially crafted Beating The Boss To Death weapon. And I felt so much vindicated joy it was like my first play-through of Dark Souls all over again, but with the added knowledge that I didn't have infinite lives to bash against the brick wall head first. I'd beaten them fair and square with my limited supply of chances and it felt amazing.

The moral of this story? I was so invested in this game, I spent a full day and night plotting revenge against a robot for "killing" the maybe-30mb text file that was my last character. And I enjoyed every second of it.

That kind of immersion doesn't come along every day.

Buy this game.

Buy it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124738753', 'num_games_owned': 3682, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 121996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40653, 'last_played': 1702806021}
review:
This is probably long overdue from me, considering my playtime. 

ToME is a deep, technical and complex true rogue-like. There's a ton of lore, a ton of classes and a ton of achievements, all of them accomplishments. The 1700+ achievements are not spam, there's just that much to do. There are several difficulty options, a lot of races and classes, plus you are given the ability to make an adventurer class after beating the game on normal difficulty -- handing you the power to make a truly powerful or weird gimmicky character. 

There are 2 campaigns, many things to unlock, from extra classes, to races and talent trees; and a lot of ways to play the game. All the DLCs add great content and the devs/mods are great. 1.6 just launched at the time of writing this review, and the game is still being updated and going strong after several years. Dev darkgod is always working on things, and the community is small but active. (It's a fully single player classic rogue-like rpg, but there is a general chat for all things ToME and its pleasant and helpful towards new and experienced players alike).

I'm almost at 700 hours playtime at the time of writing this, and I fully expect to play 700 more. One of my all time favorite games, and one I always eventually return to. Its hard as nails, a bit confusing at first and definitely niche, but is obviously a huge labor of love and is a world that rewards you for your time invested in playing it. I'm still learning new approaches and coming up with different strategies this late in. 

And maybe one day I'll beat Madness difficulty... or just die trying. A lot.

Edit: I still haven't beaten Madness but I haven't been playing that setting at all. I have gotten a couple of Insane roguelike wins under my belt, though. And I've also nominated this game for the 2023 steam awards under the "labor of love" category as it most certainly is — and the magic still hasn't worn off for me as I check back in at almost 2,000 hours clocked now. A true masterpiece, and no doubt I'lll be back here again in due time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027334723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1378, 'last_played': 1688869145}
review:
8.6 / 10

A hidden gem & better than FTL.
Looks horrible but is fun to play.  Is designed & works surprisingly well for a Rogue RPG hybrid.  The creator took a lot of lessons learned from similar games and stuffed them neatly into this title.  I feel bad for how little i payed & will probably pick up the DLC / other titles.  I put more playtime on my second PC (non-Steam version). 

PS; you can get the full game for free on the developers website... But i still purchased this game   :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197965901721', 'num_games_owned': 1156, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 2671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2625, 'last_played': 1675339640}
review:
Recommended but with a caveat.

An enormous game that, even after playing tens of hours, I barely feel I've dipped my toes into. I really like the combination of grid-based roguelike mechanics with more modern RPG spells/skills and loot, it's a winning formula. The only thing that tempers my enthusiasm a little is the way enemies are thrown at you in massive hordes. Where most traditional roguelikes use fewer, more deadly enemies to make you exercise extreme caution, Maj'Eyal can feel almost like a musou game at times with how many weaker enemies will swarm you. This makes for a sometimes awkward dynamic where you want to be careful and put thought into every move (it's still very challenging), but the amount of ability spam you have to use to clear out groups of enemies can very easily lead to carelessness. I've often found myself pinned into a corner by weak enemies while a tougher boss creature pelts me from afar, which can be frustrating.

This isn't necessarily a negative point, just something to be aware of, especially for people who've played and enjoyed traditional roguelikes before. Still really enjoyable, regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064954707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1779, 'last_played': 1693623986}
review: I am not going to go into detail about what other people have covered. If you can overlook the eyesore graphics, this is a game with depth and sophistication. In fact, you're lucky to have a community to help you out, because you will need to ask questions! The last time I was faced with a challenge like this was when I was still playing text-based dungeons through Telnet. What impressed me the most, beyond the intricate RPG systems, was how this game managed to continually surprise me, even late into the run! By the time I got to the sandworm lair, where the tunnels collapse on you after the sandworms pass through them, I was hooked! This is what separates an excellent game from an average game--the ability of the mechanics to introduce, and drip-feed you, new concepts. At no time did I feel overwhelmed, or unfairly challenged; instead, I felt intrigued...and dare I say it...stimulated to try harder and git gud. The game only costs $6.99, but I would have easily payed double that, or more, for this kind of challenge. There are also unlockable races and character classes, and multiple modes (there is a mode where you get more than one life, so you can afford to make a few mistakes...) to choose from, though you can just as easily download a mod to unlock those locked classes. Overall, 9.5/10. And I am a graphics whore, so I do not give this rating lightly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011209000', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 14007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13973, 'last_played': 1574871829}
review:
If you enjoy Rogue-likes, or even Rogue-lites, check this game out.  The various difficulty settings can accommodate all preferences, from infinite lives to "Dead is Dead".

Too many race and class combos to try them all, many of them must be unlocked, lots of randomly spawning powerful artifacts, plenty of replayability.  You will probably tire a bit of repeatedly running the early-game maps, but there are at least different spawn points for certain races and classes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046169748', 'num_games_owned': 933, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 14479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6296, 'last_played': 1709912935}

author: {'steamid': '76561198171011909', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 9929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8610, 'last_played': 1695500421}
review:
Don't know what to write so here's some noob tips:

-If you see a sealed door, it has dangerous enemies, don't open it unless you're overleveled or very tough

-If you see a digestive sack, come back to it after clearing the ENTIRE dungeon. Then use your rod of recall. go next to the sack and wait for your rod timer to get down to 3 turns. Activate any instant buffs, open the sack, pick up the item, then you should be safe from the horror you unleashed.

-That green guy going super saiyan on your hotbar removes debuffs, VERY USEFUL INDEED.

-You can spend category points to gain an inscription slot. Very useful

The game is fun and free, buy it if you want even more content and A COOL GREEN NAME

author: {'steamid': '76561198058416955', 'num_games_owned': 466, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12536, 'last_played': 1710568465}
review: This game has very high replay value and has in-depth character classes.  It's an amazing rogue like with a nice background story, peaceful music.  As a rogue like fan, is one of the best of its genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064776605', 'num_games_owned': 911, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1696674903}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042941966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 18965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 793, 'playtime_at_review': 9532, 'last_played': 1712021874}
review:
Just a wonderful "old school" fantasy rpg game.  I didn't think I would like something like this because of it's "dated" feel, but I couldn't of been more wrong.  There's so much detail in this game, lots of lore, and lots of numbers to consider.  Very much for those who love all kinds of stats.

I'm close to 200 hrs of gameplay, but I haven't even scratched the surface yet.  I keep dying, but I get a little better each time I play.  I've only played a few classes and races, so that means there are a lot of others to try out. 

This game is super cheap for the amount of love that has been put into this, and the dev is still working on new things.  This will easily consume thousands of hours of my time with all that there is to do and different difficulty settings.  I can't recommend this game enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044205078', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1635804939}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal es un Roguelike puro y duro de los más influyentes en el género. Detrás de sus gráficos sencillos (por no decirlo de otro modo) se oculta un video juego impresionantemente enorme y complejo, en el que muchos jugadores pasan cientos o miles de horas y no terminan nunca de develar todas sus minucias. El juego tiene 35 clases, y con cada una de ellas existen infinidad de posibilidades y formas de jugar, el mapa es gigante y lleno de secretos, y la mitología del juego no tiene nada que enviadiarle a los grandes rpgs.

Los únicos defectos que tiene el juego son sus gráficos (para quien le moleste esa estética simplista y hecha en casa) y su gran complejidad y dificultad que pueden ser intimidantes para muchos. 
El juego es un software de fuente libre que se encuentra en la página de los desarrolladores (te4.org), de modo que a quien le interese lo puede probar (sin dlc) antes de decidirse comprarlo para apoyar a sus creadores (yo lo jugué un buen rato antes de comprarlo para apoyar).

review: Easily the deepest roguelike experience I have had. The world is immense, and has a lot of history to it, with pacing you can change to fit your mood. author: {'steamid': '76561198028171467', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 56491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31884, 'last_played': 1705414244}
review:
A free, open source roguelike RPG which is heavily focused on charachter building. Game has it is own setting. It is high fantasy world mixed with lots of stuff like steampunk and [spoiler] psycology [/spoiler]. Most things you'll encounter are very generic, like orcs, elfes, dragons, righteous paladins, vile mages. And then you run into a ninja-gunsliner-treant, bear psychic or slime demonologist. Main plot is also typical for high fantasy. Most of the lore you encounter is contained within books or scrolls which you can find in shops or in dungeons. 
Interface is very customizable. Game mechanics are easy to learn, not so easy to master. There is decent amount of different stats and charachteristics. Some of them are a bit vague, but you can always ask in game chat what a specific stat does, how it stacks or when it caps. People often help with advice, but generally chat is slow, unless dev joins. Which happens unsually often compared to any other game. When present, dev also can directly act upon gameplay, adding events or giving you 10 turns of invulnerability for no reason. Is patched and has updates from time to time. ToME's sound and graphics are simple. 
Game has very adjustable difficulty. If you have never tried a roguelike I am encouragin you to make it your first one, gameplay isn't that oldschool. There are many classes to choose from (35 classes), they differ very much from each other and the same class can have several ways of playing. Every class is deeply thought out. 16 races with upsides and downsides.  Most of them are closed when you start, so there are META-GOALS, you can progress by opening new classes and races. Loot variety is also good, you can find all kinds of stuff. Lots of unique gear too, which can change the style of play. Game is close to being perfect for anyone who likes replayability. What I dislike personally is that every run you have to run into same dungeons almost in the same order. There is also a feeling that much more endings are intended. Endless mode map variety is poor. Enemy variety is very low if you don't have DLCs. Mix ToME's gameplay with Dungeon Crawl stone soup dungeons variety and it is perfect. 
Verdict: Play the free version first and see if you enjoy it as much as many other people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138980273', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3568, 'last_played': 1678779132}
review:
A very interesting take on the old classic rogue-like, whilst the changes might not be to every ones taste, I feel like it makes a refreshing change from all the others I've played.

I find it has plenty of options for character customisation, and in game world content, which I do not want to go into detail about and possible spoil the discovery for new players.
I'm personally not keen on the art style having been more used to ascii, but the spell graphics are super pretty.

it removes the normal boring jobs of scroll, potion and loot management, with cooldowns for the former two and at the end of each map screen converting unwanted items into gold without the need to wander back to town sell, top up on supplies and come back, I find this streamlined approach much better for the player in keeping up with the sense of exploration and discovery

Overall this is one of my favourite rogue-likes, with many more hours played on it before it's steam release.
If you enjoy rogue-likes for the sense of adventure and discovery then try this for a couple of hours and see what you think.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100972699', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 832, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1588495855}
review:
I'm only just scratching the surface with Tales of Maj'Eyal, but it's drawing me in with a powerful grip. Simple graphics, very in depth gameplay and the option to play on as low or as high a difficulty as you want.

I played a little while on easy difficulty to get a feel for the game before diving into normal (I'm a slow, anxious person) and so far I've only tried a melee class, but there's huge scope for re-playability as there are opportunities to unlock several different classes as you play. The classes and a very small number of items are the only things that carry over between playthroughs, everything else is lost upon death/your last death. There is also the ability to play with unlimited lives, limited lives, or just one life.

A very enjoyable experience with plenty of world lore to uncover as you play as well as enjoyable, non-real time gameplay. Wonderful to kick back with and spend some time exploring this weird and wonderful world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055503792', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1700862772}

author: {'steamid': '76561198067590014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 19051, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 17, 'playtime_at_review': 8466, 'last_played': 1712277569}
review: I've played this game for over a hundred hours, and here I am kicking myself for not playing it sooner.  There's still so much I have yet to see and do in this game, and that isn't even talking about how I've mostly only played one mode and difficulty.  The game could use some more variety with its areas, seeing as they only have one or two options each time you play through, but that isn't something I care about most of the time.  With a massive system and tons of mechanics and character options, Tales of Maj'Eyal has plenty for someone to do if they like turn-based RPGs.  9.5/10, would die again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198285336164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 33586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32251, 'last_played': 1709364506}
review:
A fantastic rogue-like game. If you've played rogue-likes you'll know what to expect. For those that haven't it's [i]explore, kill, kill then die and try again[/i]. 

It's worth noting there isn't a progression system to make following tries easier, by unlocking a new super weapons that can be spawned for example. But new character classes are unlocked as you play through and hit different conditions (a couple irritating).

The biggest criticism is the artwork. While it isn't terrible it is perhaps showing it's age. But it's easy to overlook once you get playing. Also on low-end systems performance can to be an issue. Things can slow down especially when playing a long session, requiring a game restart to return to normal.

It is a hard but rewarding game that you can easy sink 100s of hours into. It has lots of classes to try and master with interesting lore to read, it all that makes this one of my favourite games.

[Note: I recommend Tales of Maj'Eyal and all DLC it’s well worth the price. But if you’re feeling unsure try the main game free here: https://te4.org/]

author: {'steamid': '76561198028642124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 13322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10966, 'last_played': 1704677374}
review:
The developer DarkGod actually made this game 100% on his own which is amazing to me. The graphics are wanting, but the core game play is phenomenal and there are many many different races/classes to try and experiment with. If you enjoy the game there are also several expansions but it should be noted the base game is available 100% free on DarkGod's website te4.org. I played it for 10-20 hours there and I have to say I was convinced the purchase was worth it. This developer is amazing and you do get access to a shared storage space between your characters when you make the purchase... the more DLC's you buy the larger the space is as well. 

Try it and have fun!
