author: {'steamid': '76561197970343817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11076, 'last_played': 1626175643}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is a fantastic classical roguelike that I always end up coming back to.  It's definitely not for everyone, but if you're interested in this sort of game, I can't see why you wouldn't like it.

If the gameplay videos haven't turned you off, you can download and play a free version of the game from its official website.  The free version is quite extensive, the only things it truly lacks aside from all of the DLC content are modes and features that make the game easier (Exploration mode, which gives you infinite lives without restricting your ability to unlock new classes and races, and the item vault, which lets you save and transfer items between characters), unlockable cosmetic options and a single class (possessor).  I personally played the free version for upwards of 60 hours, unlocking all non-DLC content before deciding to buy the game.

The game itself is extremely replayable, more so than any other game I've played.  There are an absurd number of classes, each of which has multiple builds.  Even with simple classes, like berserker and bulwark, there are extremely important decisions to make.  Do you want to go anti-magic and lose access to a number of useful items in exchange for an extremely useful skill tree?  Which category do you want to unlock first?  What race are you, and whats the best way to exploit your racial skill tree with your chosen class?  All that combined with the standard roguelike random loot ensures that your runs, even with the exact same class will be wildly different from one another.  If you find the game engaging at the start you'll probably still be engaged 50+ hours later and then will randomly come back in a few months only to get hooked again.  Or at least that's how it usually works for me.

I heavily recommend checking out the free version if the game seems at all interesting, then coming back and buying the steam version + DLC's if you like it.  The DLC's are all really good, by the way.  Plus they give you more item vault space, which is nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044010204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 19600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6096, 'last_played': 1690686390}
review: By far one of my favorite Rouge-like games. The various unlock options make it a truly rewarding game that warrants multiple play throughs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970661562', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1640812817}
review:
An enjoyable mix of rogue-like mechanics and an open world RPG that's forgiving enough to support casual play, Tales is the kind of game I like to fire up when I have a few spare minutes to fill. When the game session may be cut short at any moment. When I know I'm between other things and I need something simple to dip in and out of. This isn't to say Tales is shallow or simplistic, it's just that the underlying game is well documented through tooltips, info screens and clear metrics. The tropes are borrowed from 100 other games, expanded upon (mostly clearly) and not so important that it's life or death if you don't completely understand the difference between the various armour bonuses, or exactly how a doohickey interacts with a thinymabob. 

Overall, a winner. I've never been a big rogue-like fan, but Tales hits the spot. (It doesn't hurt that the price is right and development is eternally on-going.)

review: Take the RNG loot party of diablo and the build-centered, skillspam of World of Warcraft and put that in a roguelike and you basicly have TOME. The lore is neat i suppose but your mainly there to unlock shit and try to get as far as possible in the game before dieing. This game is very difficult overall though. Enemies can and will reduce your HP to half in one shot very easily but you are about as busted if not more busted than the enemies and as such your goal is basicly to outcheese your opponnents. most important thing is to THINK before acting. Its a roguelike, you have all the time in the world.

review: My few complaints from this game have to do with the initial beginnings of runs being a little unbalanced levels wise (Something the dev is working on right now. Touching on that later.) and that you don't start with very many class/race options. However the gameplay is fun, complex enough to be interesting but simple enough to be approachable. I'm not a story guy but the setting is right up my alley and the music is pretty nice as well. If you like dungeon crawlers you'll like this one. Development is still ongoing, which is wonderful to see, especially considering the dev seems to be very active and communicative from posts I've seen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999024409', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 17406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15503, 'last_played': 1652609482}
review:
Great game with a lot going for it. 
If you like character creation you will absolutely love this game. 
A lover of lore like myself? Well you will get books worth of stories and tidbits scattered throughout the game always further immersing you.
And best of all a very active developer, DarkGod only works by himself so don't expect monthly updates but there is always whispers of new content on the way (if you follow DarkGods twitter) and more than enough in the game already to tide you over until then.

If you consider yourself a fan of RPGs or Roguelikes you are doing yourself a disservice by not trying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020249653', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 11184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10198, 'last_played': 1627373892}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042538154', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10881, 'last_played': 1574749043}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal (Henceforth going to be referred to as ToME) is a Roguelike (The Nethack and Rogue kind *NOT* the Binding of Isaac kind) but with a heavier focus on story, lore, and world than other Roguelike games. It also has a heavy focus on unlockable options that you can earn through gameplay and achievements meaning even if your character doesn't beat the game (very expected for new players even on the easiest difficulties) their death can still have meaning unlocking new classes or races or other options for your next character. It also has other misc features like being able to chat with anyone else currently playing the game sometimes including developers and player deaths being broadcasted to others also playing but these features are optional and can be turned off if preferred but there are a couple of exclusive events for being online. Despite these features the game isn't an MMO by any means and you won't interact with other people besides the simple chatroom... besides maybe Darkgod (the main dev) messing around with your character occasionally. (Nothing harmful, only funny jokes or helpful buffs.) The game also has a... smorgasbord of achievements especially at first glance but many of the achievements are the same except on a different difficulty or mode. 

Overall the game is quite great especially if you want a more story based and interesting roguelike that isn't just a standard dungeon crawl however due to the game's more story based nature it can be quite disheartening when you die and have to repeat the same story beats but it is a bit more forgiving than other roguelikes in that there are modes where you have a limited number of lives or even an infinite number of lives (however you can't unlock things in the ladder) but the good ol' one death and you die still always exists for the more hardcore out there. Speaking of which there is also a variety of difficulty options separate from permadeath options but again no unlocking things on easy mode. I also want to commend this game's classes, there's a large variety and many have unique and interesting mechanics and play completely differently from each other. Lastly there is also steam workshop support with a small variety of mods to choose from but a couple of really good ones. There's also more mods on the game's website.

If you still aren't convinced you can actually play the base game for free from the developer's website but it will be missing donator features such as infinite lives mode, the adventurer class after beating the game, some classes, customization options, and other small misc things. That's what you are actually technically buying on steam, the donator features, but I recommend buying the game on steam anyway because the game is good and the developer deserves your money especially considering it is only $7 when it isn't on sale or even buying the game off of the website instead if you prefer no DRM.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009824215', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 12790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8074, 'last_played': 1686833257}
review:
An amazing entry point to the genre, TOME has much of the complexity of a deep roguelike but none of the barriers to entry. Everything is usable with the mouse, UI is straightforward, inventory management is simplified, the setting is familiar, visuals are serviceable and gear stats, classes and skills are for the most part easy to understand. You can expect a plethora of varied classes, each with many possible builds, an array of legendary items with special effects, secrets to discover and lore to find.

There is a ton of replayability, but for how long it'll stay interesting varies from person to person. The campaigns do have randomly generated layouts of the combat areas, but their theme and order will always remain the same. Eventually you might start to notice the biggest problem I have with the game, and that is the pacing. After a few runs you will start to perceive long stretches of the game where you're just mowing through weak common mobs without a real challenge. Rarely, but certainly at least once in a run, the game's random miniboss generator will spit out a very broken monster at this time that can and will wipe you out within a few turns if you're not careful, which after a time you certainly won't be as these parts are long and unengaging, meaning you'll probably end up mashing buttons to get through. It is for this reason that I'd recommend playing with the multiple lives option rather than one life only, as these deaths feel very cheap. As a sidenote, the game does offer an arena or endless dungeon mode.

That said, this problem - and the other issues the game has, especially the very poor class balance, should only start to bother you dozens of hours in. The game is still receiving expansions, free balance updates and has regular events. If you're on the fence, the free vanilla version is available on the official website. I've had a great time with the game so far and I hope you will too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031445014', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 15881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6483, 'last_played': 1705096736}
review:
TOME is a fun classic Roguelike. If you love Roguelikes, you'll love TOME. It satisfies some of the cravings that DCSS does not (I love DCSS too!) in that it has a living world with an interesting history that you can discover, it has unlockables, and it has lots of quests.

If you like the idea of Roguelikes, but find the difficulty intimidating, TOME is a great choice due to its many difficulty settings. Combined with difficulty settings are different game modes: Exploration mode gives you unlimited lives, Adventure mode gives you a few lives, and Rogue mode gives you one life. I'm a seasoned DCSS player which only allows one life, but I actually enjoy playing on Adventure mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116580849', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 200119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 49, 'playtime_at_review': 60729, 'last_played': 1711799917}
review:
戦闘とレアアイテム探しが楽しいローグライクです 。
技やアイテムはクールダウン制になっており、数ターン経つと再使用可能。
食料や松明等の消耗品の管理要素をなくすことで、とても遊び易くなっています。

本編シナリオモードの他に、
・無限に続くダンジョンをどこまで進めるか挑戦するモード
・闘技場のチャンピオンを目指すモード
・本編クリア後の世界でオーク達が再起を図る新シナリオモード(要DLC)　等があります

職業や種族が豊富で3000時間以上遊べます。超面白いのでオススメです。

author: {'steamid': '76561198042860367', 'num_games_owned': 733, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 6350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5795, 'last_played': 1685513522}
review:
This is a wonderful game, plenty of depth to delve into, good sense of difficulty (It's a Roguelike, if you're not looking for difficult games, you don't usually opt for one) and lovely mechanics. The developers interact with the community a decent amount and support the game heavily. (even doing server-wide events that can effect any save loaded at the time - example that I witnessed in my most recent run: A unique dungeon caled the Lost Land of Poosh, atleast iirc thats what it was called...)

We recently got teased an upcoming expansion being in development, and even though microtransactions ARE coming, it's literally only cosmetics and PAYING FOR THE GODS TO COME KILL YOUR CHARACTER along with paying to cause those events to happen at your will - supposedly for the whole server!

The free version is on te4.org as you can go there and try the game with around 95% content FOR FREE, excluding the following: Possessor Class. Anything added by DLC. Item Vault Slots to transfer items between characters with 1 hour delay before able to withdraw. (The full bundle on steam comes with 12 slots when I bought it, not sure if it'd scale up or down depending on current price as I did so when it was on sale. Site says 2€ = 1 slot though for donations, ontop of providing 10 silver coins per 1€ to spend on the game / DLC / etc.) Shimmering Mirror! (Alter visuals of any worn item to another of the same type) Custom Tiles! (look on the site's donation section for more info on this)
Note: If you're going through the site for these purchases, the cost is 24€ for the full package from my understanding. 60 coins for the donor perks, 40 for ashes, 70 for embers, 70 for forbidden cults. So I'm pretty sure the slots are fixed rate. Slots have no extra cost from what I've seen.

It took me nearly a hundred hours in order to get my first win, going through several dozen characters. That win was on the DLC campaign from Embers, so I'm now working on getting through the regular campaign & unlocking the rest of the stuff.

Oh, and I nearly forgot to write this down: This game has mod support! (Called Addons) - You can either go through the steam workshop (which may be missing some from non-steam users) or you can go through the te4.org site for them. If you're going through the site, I'd advise browsing to it from ingame browser for simplifying the install, as the download link in the ingame browser for the addons auto-installs it for you. Addons only apply on newly made characters, to prevent any conflicts. This also applies for when disabling them, however you can completely remove it from your files if you need to on the fly. (Note in several cases doing this will cause other issues most of the time, ranging from just minor errors to making the save essentially corrupted - This is part of why they set it up where it only naturally adds or removes addons for NEW characters.)

Edit: Nominating for labor of love, still a lovely game as always and they're still supporting it to this day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198296081540', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 15241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6538, 'last_played': 1699708823}
review:
It's not often I put 100 hours into a game any more, so I've considered writing my first review. As you can see the reviews are overwhelmingly positive, and my review will be no different. If I came across this game as a teenager I would have put countless thousands of hours in. It's a game that seems daunting at first, with so many stats and you're not sure what does what, but once you get over the initial barriers to entry it's one of the more accessible rogue-likes.

The game is available for free, but at this price point, I recommend you not only buy the game at full price, but all the DLC as well, I've found them all to be more than worth it.

Though there's various modes offering various amount of lives, I only play this game on perma-death mode, I've got 100 hours and I've never made it more than halfway through the campaign.... As bad as I am, I think this says more about the games ability to keep a player engaged rather than my skill as a gamer, I always give this game serious consideration when deciding what game to play, and it's not all that often I play games any more.

Oh, and the developer is always hanging around updating and offering festive stuff for Halloween and Christmas etc.

I highly recommend this game.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197966343267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 26899, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7089, 'last_played': 1710291923}
review:
Note: I've played this game for hundreds of additional hours before the game appeared on Steam.

ToME is one of the best games I've ever played. There are lots of games out there that I love deeply and truly, for a variety of reasons, but ToME is one of the very few that I've been playing for ~6 years or more that I keep coming back to. It's almost a yearly/bi-yearly thing for me: I'll play it for 30-40 hours, drop it for a bit, then start a new character and do it again.

This is not a game for graphics or people who like them; this is a game for people who crave strategic and tactical depth and mechanical excellence. The absolute variety of classes creates an amazing breadth of playstyles and builds, and finding out how to create an absolute godcharacter as any class is one of the most fun things about this game.

tldr: I can't even think of all the ways this game is the best, because it is the best in all ways.  If you like difficult, tactical, Roguelike RPG gameplay, this is the absolute pinnacle of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063335043', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6487, 'last_played': 1666367284}
review:
The first video game I ever bought was a single 3.5 floppy from a vending machine in a bowling alley and pool hall at a university in my town. I had no idea what it was. There were no pictures and no description - just the title. It was Castle of the Winds. It was one of my all-time favorite gaming experiences. No Internet. No guides. No idea what I was doing. No instructions except in-game text and trial and error. It was really great. 

Tales of Maj'Eyal is a very fun game. It is brutal and unforgiving and smart and deep and painful and it kills you a lot so you better have a little patience with it, especially if it's a new genre to you. But it is also really fun and really rewarding and I'm real happy that it's still around. Great game. Will kill you. Some people are into that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987205117', 'num_games_owned': 615, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7912, 'last_played': 1691142033}

author: {'steamid': '76561198073915727', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 10179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6627, 'last_played': 1701951441}
review:
After doing some weird calculations about what games on steam get the most hours played per dollar spent, I came across this gem. At first glance, it looks like any other generic "I'll keep scrolling" type of thing to come across on Steam. Hell no, I was wrong to judge. If you are a fan of D&D, you already know what this is. Action, Adventure, RPG, Strategy, Roguelike, and here to mess with your emotions. I've never been so pissed at a game (and so happy with it) in years! It's deceptively complicated, absolutely fun, and it will keep you up at night. The replay value is insane, every game is different, and you will be challenged! Plus, there is a great community of very dedicated fans, and a dev team that cares about this project.

Seriously, Just spend the dollar or whatever this game goes for and get yourself immersed, the game is impressive and you won't regret it. If you don't want to buy the devs a beer, you can get it for free on their website :)


Edit: I still come back to this game all the time after owning it for years, it's no Garry's mod or Left 4 Dead but it's a classic in my book and definitely worth learning if this is your type of game. Also it works on Linux if you're wondering.

Played a Temporal Warden, placed an anti-teleportation ring around a group of enemies, then forced them to teleport multiple times until they were ripped apart. 11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198010177709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1560816685}
review:
Developer calls his own version of microtransaction a "good kind" because it's not "pay2win".
Cutting smaller contents out of an already niche genre and making it exclusive to smaller paid DLCs from their fans is rather disgraceful. Not to mention they already have a Patreon setup.

Their reasoning was that Valve's changed algorithm in storefront exposure hurt their sales. So instead of improving the product to combat it, while also planning on releasing paid expansions, they decided to receive monthly optional donating subscription to support them (Patreon) and also start adding "not pay2win" (although some straight adds an effect) microtransactions. 

I will not be supporting the developer again including their future games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045717378', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 16816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10608, 'last_played': 1677009729}
review:
177 hours in haven't beat the game once.

The game involves exploring generated zones, killing monsters with skills, looting, building your character and going as far you can until you inevitably get slapped from the shadows. There are A LOT of classes and a lot of different race/class combinations with skill trees you can opt in/out of for a HUGE amount of build possibilities. You can play a standard archer/beserker class or play a Saw butcher which will have you cosplaying sonic while you rip your foes apart.

It will make you angry and annoyed, worse than Darkest Dungeon but it is not really RNG based you just get fucked by monsters you weren't ready for.

I still know barely anything about the game either so I hang out in the discord which is very active and helpful. People in their know everything so I highly advise joining it to learn the game. Also you don't need the DLCs to have a billion hours of gameplay. 

I'll be playing this game probably forever and really looking forward to 1.6!

author: {'steamid': '76561198074125304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 20268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12025, 'last_played': 1710075210}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is probably the best rogue-like RPG I've ever played. At 200 hours I've yet to even put a dent in all of the character and skill options this game has to offer and I'm still working on the main campaign. Death comes quickly and stupid mistakes abound. True to it's roots, player skill, world knowledge and blind luck in my experience so far all play equal parts in a successful adventure. A lucky artifact might get you past a rough patch, but it's useful days are numbered and it will take skill and planning to reach the end. 

Kudos to the DGO on an amazing game and thank you for continuing to update and support this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057569713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2683, 'last_played': 1614379923}
review:
[h1] 10/10 [/h1]
So I just finished this game. After 44 hours of glorious and stuipid deaths of my characters, I finally did it. My halfiling brawler sacreficed himself in the process, but I was still really happy. .But that's not the end. It's the opposite - I'm going to buy every expansion there is going to be, and I'm going to try every class and every race possible. Because it's just so COMPLEX and FUN at the same time. Honestly, i just feel overwhelmed by the amount of things i can do here. 

[b]I'll list some of most important PROS and CONS here ( in my opinion of course ) : [/b]
+ LORE - usually comes in a form of small notes left on the floor of dungeons. It's great, because at first, when I was concerned only about being better at slashing my opponents, I could just skip it effortlesly and go on. But when i finally started reading them, I was just in awe. Everything was written well, an it was a JOURNEY. Really, I just spent my day thinking about how unfairly orcs have been treated, and how complex their situation is. I don't want to spoil anything - but just read anything that regards orcs. It's a great story. There were many others obvously, some made me laugh, and some made sad. 
+ CONTENT - There is just soooo much of it. To put it simple  : Just one class can be quite complex. Finding some combos, and exploiting them is really fun, and there are several in each class. Combine it with races ( which often have their own skill trees ) and many MANY items, and you will just always learn something new about this game. 

+ UNLOCK SYSTEM : most of the game classess and races were locked for me in the begining. But unlocking them often came naturaly, because I was curious about some book and read it, or just stumbled across some necromancer and killed him. It didn't feel as a chore, it actually felt quite rewarding. 

+ THEY CARE ABOUT THE ATMOSPHERE : I will explain this by showing an example. I breached some infamous orcish armory. In most of the games, the armory would be just 5 racks of weapons and 2 crates of unusable junk. Here, i just saw like 100-200 items i could get. Many of them were really good. It felt real, it was not only some stupid armory i have to clear, it was  [i][b]THE ORCISH ARMORY[/b][/i]

+ AND MANY OTHERS ... 

[b]But now CONS. Not many, and minor, but still [/b]
- BALANCE : I just feel like some classes are far better than others. I just defeated end game boss ( lvl. 75 ) with my 
( lvl. 42 ) Halfling Brawler. Meanwhile, playing rogue or summoner, I had trouble fighting many enemies on my lvl. Maybe I'm just bad at them, or I didn't unlock a important skill tree yet. 

- BALANCE OF ENEMIES : any character i created had problem with ranged minons. Especially casters. They can deal a LOT more damage than mele fighters, while pinning and freezing from safe distance. If you overcome those CC, they will just teleport away. That were usually intense and epic battles, especially with caster bosses, but I feel like melee minions in end game need a little bit of buff to be treated seriously. 

- NOT TOO MUCH CONVERSASION : i just feel like NPC in this world are too few. Yeah they were fun to talk to, some of them were quite unique. But there were maybe like 20 of them, that you could talk to during the playthrough. I would like to for example chat with the "Master" - a Infamous Necromancer.  Maybe there are more that I just not unlocked yet ? Probably, but the basic playthrough was quite poor in terms of NPC characters. 

That's it. Thanks for reading it and sorry for my English. I'm not a native speaker.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051316994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 286788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 750, 'playtime_at_review': 182366, 'last_played': 1711693401}
review:
To begin with, I’ll mention that the base game without dlc is available for free at te4.org, so you can always just take a look at it and decide later if you want to pay for it because it’s one of the best games you’ve ever seen.

I’m the kind of person who leaves a game on while I’m doing other things (in fact I have another game open right now), but nonetheless, my 3k hours in this game is a fair indication of how much I love it.  I’m not blind to its faults, so I will mention them later, but first I’m going to talk about what makes this game worth all the time I’ve spent in it.

To my mind, the best parts of this game are within three elements of the game design, and how they interact: the class design, the enemy design and the tactical gameplay.

[h1]Class design [/h1]

The game has 35 character classes and 16 races, most of which are locked to begin with, but you can unlock them by playing the game, except for the seven dlc classes and races.  Each class has around three to four dozen skills.

The greatness of this part of the game comes from the sheer number of well designed classes with skills that interact with each other in all sorts of interesting ways.  You’ve got your standard warrior/rogue/mage classes, and then likely every possible variation you’ve ever thought of and several that you haven’t.  Things like the Writhing One class where you play a Lovecraft inspired half-whatever-race-you-picked, half-horror, using the tentacle you have in place of an arm together with a 1h weapon, or the Time Warden which has abilities where you use time travel to attack enemies several times all at once, or the Doomed class where you have shadows that follow you around and you can do things like throw them at enemies or swap places with them.

Often classes will have more than one way to play them, and on top of all that, the first time you complete the game you unlock the adventurer class, which allows you to pick skills from any of the other classes, so you can mix and match however you like.

[h1]Enemy design [/h1]

The basic concept of enemy design is fairly simple, but very effective at creating all sorts of interesting encounters.  They have a base type, like “brown bear” or “luminous horror” or “elven mage”, which will have their own particular skills, and then you can come across rares, which are upgraded enemies with a class, as in one of the classes you can choose from, meaning that they have extra skills from that class and relevant equipment.  There are also unique and boss monsters, which only appear in particular areas (usually at the end of a zone for bosses) until you get to insane difficulty where there’s a chance of random uniques and bosses, which can have more than one class.

You can see how, with all the various classes available to you, this is a system that can keep you on your toes.

[h1]Tactical gameplay [/h1]

So the first two elements of the game that I’ve mentioned combine to give an amazing tactical gameplay experience.  You build your character and buy them equipment with the goal of being ready for any encounter, then you test your build against all the different enemies that you come across, and of course you can sometimes come across more than one rare monster at a time.

With the difficulty settings at an appropriate level, you will get many chances to really push your character, however you’ve built them, to it’s limits.  I've had fights where I'm one move away from death for dozens of turns, I've had fights where I have to eke out every bit of damage I can get from my character to out damage an enemy's heals, there are times when I've faced down half a dozen rares at once, and you get that feeling of relief when you pick off one, so you know the rest of the fight is going to be that much easier.   Because of the rng aspect of the game, you’ll always have the possibility of challenges you haven’t faced before, and the difficulty settings go down to a point where you don't really need skills and up beyond the point where most classes are even capable of winning without the game being modded, so there's very little chance that you won't be able to adjust things to your taste.

[h1]And now, the bad stuff [/h1]

The first thing is pretty obvious.  Just look at the screenshots.  If you’re looking for a game that’s pretty, this isn’t it.

Also text.  Lots and lots of text.  To be fair, if you've read to this point in the review it's probably not a problem.

Then there’s the game’s complexity, which might be a good thing or a bad thing, depending on your personality.  Fortunately all the important mechanics are actually explained in the game if you mouse over everything and read the tooltips.  However, there’s a lot to wrap your head around, especially each time you decide to learn a new class.

The above three issues are really more like obvious barriers to entry rather than flaws.  The next few points are more like actual flaws in the design.

EDIT: Just removing a criticism that was patched out in 1.6 (you can't drown friendlies for xp and loot any more and higher difficulties were adjusted so that this tedious process is no longer necessary).

I’ll also mention balance.  Some classes are simply not as strong as other classes.  To be fair it’s not like they have to fight each other, and if you want to play a more difficult class, there’s always the possibility of lowering the difficulty.  However, it’s disappointing when you look at a class and conceptually it’s everything you want, but it’s just not as strong the last class you played.

Finally I'll mention the story.  The history and lore of the setting is all great and in depth and fairly well written, but there’s not much of a personal story to be found here.  You’re an adventurer, you decide to go fight things and get more powerful because reasons.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

It’s niche, but it’s probably the best thing in its niche.  If this isn't your kind of thing then no amount of recommendation can sway you, but if this is your kind of thing then you won’t regret buying this game and its dlc’s.  You’ll probably feel like it’s worth more than what you’ve paid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078191152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 118846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 24, 'playtime_at_review': 40489, 'last_played': 1711612211}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal (ToME for short) is a fascinating and unique game. While ToME touches on many of the high fantasy RPG tropes, it also takes much of what you know and expect and throws it out the window. The end result may not work for everyone, but for me it's a wonderfully quirky and colorful experience I have come to love.

ToME was designed around the idea of giving the player possibilities. Almost anything the enemies can do you can do and vice versa. This shines through in a large and diverse set of options for your character class. And you're not just choosing what color sparks you want to shoot out of your fingers; the classes feel incredibly different. Erasing your foes from existence as a time-manipulating Paradox Mage, cleaving a hate-fueled rampage as a Cursed, and channeling fireballs through your sword as an Arcane Blade all have their own distinctive style and all are satisfying.

The downside to all this is that ToME is unbalanced (though this doesn't bother me personally) and unintuitive. Some classes are simply much more powerful than others. Since there is no competitive multiplayer, I think this is fun in a way: choose your challenge level. On the other hand, it can be a little deflating to know that a class you think sounds cool is tough to play. That being said, on the lower difficulty levels, any class can easily win the game with reasonably skilled play. It's more so if you choose to play on the higher levels that you might start to have trouble.

The bigger problem is that ToME is unintuitive. The game is highly skill based and quite challenging, especially at first. However, much of the challenge comes from understanding how ToME works. Some of the lessons you can learn just fine by experience: positioning is more important than in most games, scouting can be very useful, and sometimes yes you should run away and come back later.

On the other hand, some things you probably won't figure out on your own. For example, you have defense and saves that help you avoid taking hits and status effects. So these are important to improve, right? Well, actually because of the way the game scales, monsters are so good at hitting you and applying statuses that even if you try to boost your defense and saves, the benefits are minimal. And speaking of statuses, ToME has a ton of them and some of them matter a lot. Managing and applying statuses is more important than just blasting out damage for most classes. In particular, the "stun" status is devastating. Sometimes it feels like ToME is "Don't Get Stunned: The Game."

Fortunately, there is a good community of players to give newcomers tips. There are class guides in the ToME forums, and live chat if you play while online where people are happy to give advice. In addition despite its age, development on ToME continues. The devs work on updates and reworks to make the game a smoother experience.

It's also worth noting that while ToME has a story, graphics, characters, etc, everything is stripped down. The heart of the game is challenging tactical dungeon crawls, character builds, and loot. This gives the game a huge amount of replayability. But it also lacks some of the elements of a more traditional RPG.

Overall, while ToME is a quirky game, if you like tactical dungeon crawling and creative character builds, I think ToME is one of the best games out there to satisfy those desires. It's a game I keep coming back to and expect to still play for years to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005317715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 12597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1625022006}
review: Fantastic game. Far better than the AAA games being released today.  The fact that this is being produced by a single person is amazing. The writing alone surpasses anything being pumped out by Blizzard / Bethesda etc... as an example, I stumbled across a scroll detailing the birth of the universe through the eyes of the first sentient entity created. Soon after reading that I found a series of short 'journal entries' that laid out a story of betrayal and murder. Just awesome. Don't let the graphics deter you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132557605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 10487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1697585550}
review:
tl;dr long deep loot fantasy dungeon crawl strategy character development sim

ToME, like many other roguelikes, superficially resemble chess as a tile based strategy game. In ToME's case, there is a much larger and nuanced board, and the pieces are developed beyond movement and replacement, but this is not to portray chess as any less sophisticated; if anything, chess is more sophisticated. I am not a chess player, but I presume this sort of thing would appeal to those players who want many more visuals, actions, and a system of rules & conditions developed in a completely separate environment, which is most likely a minority. 

The depth and potential length of the gameplay rivals a 20th century russian novel. The loot & lore have a unique color & feel fitting for the epic fantasy setting. The playdoh looking models weren't preferable, to say the least, but character development possibilities are nigh infinite, and that isn't an exaggeration. 

The game offers a smorgasbord of offensive, defensive, and supportive skills, too many for me to keep up with at the moment; soon enough I have plenty of abilities to forget that I have when they would be the most useful. That isn't to say there are mostly situational abilities, or that there are too many ways to fight, I just tend to use only three or four at any given encounter, which means I'm limiting my gameplay options, which means less novelty, which means less fun. 

Roguelikes are not for everyone. ToME is not for everyone. Few games are. But the target audience will not be disappointed here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018812717', 'num_games_owned': 1014, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2572, 'last_played': 1575656940}
review: My favorite roguelike of all time. Haven't won a single game, or even come close, but it's so much fun, everything is different every run, and there are a HUGE number of class/race/skill combinations to play with until you find your preferred playstyle. If you're looking for an "old-school" style roguelike with a focus on strategy and exploration to find sidequests, items and such, this is the one for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985650673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 9512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 738, 'last_played': 1676015641}
review:
Absolutely phenomenal. Big game with a wide variety of unlockables; skills, classes, items, and the resulting builds and playstyles. It's simultaneously vast, complex, and challenging, while still being surprisingly accessible (thanks to optional lives instead of enforced permadeath) and easier to understand than many other games of the genre. It's more like a blend of roguelike with purebred RPG. There is less emphasis on item drop RNG and more on character building and skill choices.

The fact you can get it for free outside of Steam (where most of my hours have been spent) almost seems criminal, and it's easily worth several times the asking Steam price if you measured it by content value alone. Paid donor benefits are a bonus on top.

I have never been a huge fan of the roguelike genre, but ToME clicked with me in a way I never thought possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052516598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 38711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22018, 'last_played': 1707695600}
review:
This game is great if you like rogue likes. The stories, lore pickups,  and the quests are cool the first time going through them, but if you die then you'll find yourself skipping through it all again. 

You can get the free version to try it out on the developer's website, then you can consider donating or buying it on steam. Donating gives you access to a couple of features like a class, and some cosmetic options, but really it's just for supporting the developer, who seems like a cool guy. 

I personally love this game, I'm not as good at it as some other people, but the more you learn the more super powerful and fun the game gets. Try it out!

Only complaint is that there are too many trash enemies that you don't even have to think about to kill, though a patch gave them all mostly unique abilities.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985703670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 251541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69833, 'last_played': 1668292310}
review:
[i](Quick note before I begin: The base game is available for free on the game's homepage, TE4 dot org. Buying the Steam version will, however, entitle you to donator benefits along with easier access to DLC and player-made mods.)[/i]

After passing the "1,000 Hours Played" mark, it occurred to me that I never stopped to give this game a review. I could go on and on about this game, but I'll try to keep it short. Uh, [i]relatively[/i] short.
(TL;DR version: Less frustrating nonsense than other roguelikes, tons of player character options, neat story, challenging but chill.)


If I had to describe this game, it would be not quite a "Roguelike", but a variation of the "Rogue" formula. Whereas classic Roguelikes (Such as NetHack) place more emphasis on the 'survival' aspect of gameplay, ToME focuses more on aptitude in combat. Items are auto-identified when you pick them up. There is no hunger system that will starve you to death when you try to heal by resting. A clear and concise "infusion" system replaces drinking strange unlabeled potions that can either help or hinder you. Hidden traps won't oneshot you from full health. 

The game, instead, provides challenge by testing your character build. Even the most basic Berserker class can use special techniques and abilities rather than the plain "Walk into enemies until they die" approach similar games use. Your ability to understand your own talents, strengths, and weaknesses are what will determine whether you win or lose in this game. Once you understand the logistics of the game, it can be pretty relaxing in a way. I often play this while listening to something else on my tablet!

Not to say that this game will be [i]easy[/i] once you know what you're doing! HOWEVER, this game has another feature that other Roguelikes don't: Adjustable difficulty and permadeath. Changing the difficulty will change the levels of enemies encountered, along with the frequency of 'Rare' enemies that have the talents of player classes. There are also three permadeath settings:
[list]
[*] Roguelike: Your standard "One life to live" setting you're used to in other games.
[*] Adventure: You gain extra lives as you increase your experience level.
[*] Exploration: A donator-exclusive setting that gives infinite lives.
[/list]

Your potential character builds start off pretty standard, but as you unlock more content, you obtain more advanced and absurd choices. 
Human berserker? Sure.
Halfling rogue? Of course!
A dwarf channeling its inner hatred to become a cursed slasher movie villain? Absolutely!
An elf that's [i]so[/i] attuned to nature that they just start melting into a blob? Without a doubt!
A skeleton that reaches across timelines to assault foes with a squad of itselves??? YES!
PSYCHIC STEAMPUNK COWBOY ORCS??? AHAHAHAHAHA, YES, YES!!!!

...Ahem. You get the idea.

On the subject of the characters, it's easy to dismiss the plot of the game at first. A fantasy setting with humans, elves, dwarves, orcs, and so on. Dangerous dungeons are around because wizards did a bad thing a long time ago. Nothing you haven't seen before, right? But that's just the surface level. As you get deeper into the game, you will discover rather unique takes on these classic fantasy tropes, things that you never would have guessed based on your preconceptions! 

So yeah. All of that stuff ends up making for what has turned out to be a colossal time vacuum for me. Like I said, the base game is free, so there's no reason not to check this game out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198123472384', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 14973, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10266, 'last_played': 1700228431}
review:
除了画质之外找不出缺点的单机rougelikeRPG游戏（其实画风习惯了的话还是很带感的。甚至有纸娃娃系统。装备了防具和武器，人物外观也会改变）
☆十多种种族，几十种职业的自由搭配。几十个技能树包括物品和剧情总共数百种技能，数百种传奇物品，还有随机生成的普通装备和地牢，可以说是让刷子和收集党欲罢不能了
☆多种难度多种游戏模式共一千多种成就，上手难度非常高，但是超级耐玩
☆每个角色长达十几个小时的培养时间，那么不同模式，不同难度，不同职业不同种族总共有多少种玩法呢？（数手指中）
☆制作者的长期更新和完善
自由度极高，极度注重角色养成的一款游戏，看着培养的角色逐渐变强，不断更新装备是tome4一大乐趣，各方面能与tome4媲美的估计只有elona了，其中tome4更偏向战斗一点而elona偏生存。但是steam上就只此一家了，你找不到任何能与tome4相比较的roguelikeRPG游戏了。
[h1]更多的优点就不列举了。因为写再多的优点，光看steam的简介和玩家评论是没用的，只有尝试过才知道这游戏的乐趣。游戏官网有免费版，不想花钱或者观望的话可以直接去试试，相信玩不了多久你就会回来剁手的[/h1][spoiler]没错我就是这样上当的[/spoiler]
如果入手的话强烈建议至少入手兽人怒火DLC，因为解锁蒸汽系之后很多职业的可玩性大幅度增加，而且也有新战役玩，相比其它几个性价比高的多。[spoiler]当然最好的选择是我全都要.jpg[/spoiler]
另外我看评论区有些人说要求中文，我表示黑人问号.jpg  
麻烦你们去创意工坊看一下好吗，有中文补丁的。或者遇上更新补丁失效的时候加那个tome4的QQ群也有第一时间的汉化补丁玩，所以别再发we need chinese这种评论了，看着太丢人了。

author: {'steamid': '76561197974088172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 4452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4452, 'last_played': 1550587406}
review:
I swore off rogue-likes because they are addictive and frustrating, but Tales of Maj’Eyal is just addictive.  The difficulty and death options make a big difference.

Playing the game is simple: click to move around or attack.  Each action takes a turn and each turn the enemies around you will take an action too.  Kill them, collect awesome loot and level-up your character.

Soon it isn't as simple as it seemed.  There are a huge variety of enemies, requiring different tactics.  Poor positioning will result in sudden death.  Actions don't always take a turn, some are free, or take part of a turn.  Choosing which items to equip requires a careful comparison of a giant list of positive and negative effects.  The skill trees offer loads of abilities and effects to choose from.

There are heaps of character classes to unlock as you play and creating a super powerful build is very satisfying.  Until something hits you for half your health and the fear returns...

author: {'steamid': '76561198044759443', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 12066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6124, 'last_played': 1707756201}

review: Imagine you open a box. A spring loaded fist pops out and punches you square in the face. So you open the box again, and once again get hit. This repeats several times until, upon opening the box, you dodge out of the way. That's what this game is like, and I mean that in the best way possible.

review: TOME is incredibly enjoyable and while difficult, not impossible.  A wide selection of classes and races as well as unlockables makes it a joy to play and definitely increases replayability.  As someone who enjoys rogues, this one is definitely one everyone should have in their collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119264382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 108237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26917, 'last_played': 1707084534}
review: Amazing game with near infinite replay value, highly active developers, and a very friendly community. ToME is an excellent first roguelike to get introduced to the genre if you've only played roguelites before, such as Slay the Spire or the Binding of Isaac. I've played enough to get wins with 6 of the 35 total classes on insane, and I don't see myself getting tired of the game anytime soon. Each class is surprisingly diverse, and feels like a different experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995744889', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1590978222}
review: A wildly impressive bit of game design from a small developer, however, this game is certainly not for everyone. If ToME is for your, you probably already know it, and if you think it's not you're probably right. Though certainly a rogue-like, ToME is very different than something like The Binding of Isaac or Dead Cells--that is to say, it's closer to an rpg with permadeath than something you can fire off a few quick runs of in a few hours. This seems like the type of game that gives out what you're willing to put into it. ToME's advocates would no doubt say I didn't give it a chance, but for me, it was too much of an ask with so many other games out there. The early going did more to push me away than pull me in, but if you want to make this "your thing" I'm sure it could be worthwhile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011061026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 76012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74779, 'last_played': 1696904488}
review:
I have put more hours into this game than any other game I've ever played, and have put nearly double the amount of time that I have in play time modding it.

As a player who has always been 'mediocre', this game was perfect. It offered me a challenge that offered just enough wiggle room for me to win.

As a player who had ideas, this game was perfect. It is open enough to allow just about anybody to make their own mods.

10/10, would create an entire race of talking turtles again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048802455', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1652962980}
review:
白嫖了好几年的dl版付费内容，补一下。
评价贼主观，拉仇恨，别看了。




rpg的部分就一般，所以不算严格的nethack系，但比起CDDA和DOD这种没有的就优秀爆了。客观讲的话比elona剧情好，至少中规中矩，并且确实有自己的色彩，最重要的是人家做完了好吧！！
但主观讲的话更喜欢elona在伊尔瓦资料馆里写完却没做到游戏里的剧情……

不过战斗的部分ok，最大的优势是职业的自由性，和技能树的随机性。还有上手的便捷性。但也就这了，就算玩冒险者最终也是那几种套路。无尽刷多了无聊的一批，然而最终不刷无尽没事干，进了无尽就无聊爆。

不如elona和cdda好玩，主要是持久的乐趣这方面，差20%左右？但是比dod好玩，好玩大概一大半。nethack没玩很多遍不做横向对比，矮人要塞没机会玩不做横向对比。
玩家自定内容的（方便-数量-质量整体分）不如CDDA和elona-omake系，高于DOD，极高与最普及的elonaplus系这个充满了男性日式肥宅臭的次品。


所以极度推荐本作，优缺点都是回合制roguelike横向对比，因为这是世界上最好的游戏类型，所以不需要纵向对比。每一作都玩爆就行了……

author: {'steamid': '76561198045343863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 4128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3863, 'last_played': 1547333508}
review:
[h1]One of the best oldschool styled rouguelikes out there with graphics that actually dont look like yesterdays taco bell.[/h1]

Seriously though, Tales of Maj'Eyal is extraordinarly depthed, balanced, interesting, innovative, and it offers challenges that can be approached in a thousand different ways. The class system, combined with the sheer amount of items available, means you can build your characters however you would like. Want to be a typical shield and sword hero? Sure, no problem. Want to summon monsters to do your bidding? Necromancer it is. Want to kill your future self and become a paradox mage, taking control of cosmic forces to wreak havoc and chaos on armies of slimes? You got it, bud.

This, all combined with a great universe filled with curious lore for you to read and explore, an upgradable leveling system with skills you've never seen used in any other game, and side quests that are actually relevant to the plot, (I know, you probably don't believe me) makes Tales of Maj'Eyal a must-play for anyone who enjoys dungeons and Dragons, rougelike RPGs, or classics like Dwarf Fortress and Dungeon Crawl Stone soup. Like any rougelike, it takes time, patience, and intrest. Once you get going, it's very, very hard to stop. (Especially if youre a stone warden hurling boulder missles)

This is a ridiculous amount of content for $6.99. Don't be afraid to play just because theres *gasp* PERMADEATH (insert ghouls screaming above your mutilated body). You can play casually in story mode and die as much as you would like. There are also amazing, full-game-sized DLCs. I havent played these yet, as I am still exploring the different classes, but I'm defintley going to give them a go shortly. I have heard great things about them. this is an oldy but a goldy, and it is vastly underrated in the gaming community. Don't miss this oppurtunitty for an excellent adventure. Don't be afraid to ask the forums if you have questions. The community is super friendly, and there is a lot of easily accesible information out there. Get it and succumb to the fact that you are a nerd like I am. Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198204705840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 15872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1445, 'last_played': 1698552823}
review:
WOW! Believe the Overwhelmingly Positive reviews! This may be among the greatest roguelike rpgs ever made. It may seem complicated and intimidating at the very first, but before you know it, you will have the game basics down in no time flat. Then it just keeps unlocking the awesomeness! 

Massive replayability
Huge roster of character variation, both in races/ classes, and skill trees
Diverse customization- HUD, Graphics, Fonts, Difficulty, Permadeath or Multiple Lives, etc.
Deep Lore
Excellent DLCs that are worth the money, yet are not required to have 100s of hours of fun
Complicated depth but minimalist gameplay- You could play the whole game with only a mouse and 2 buttons
Far more game modes than only adventure rpg mode, such as combat arena
All classes are viable, from Barbarian to Wizard to Alchemist to Summoner to Thief and so many more
Fun, Fun, Fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044803964', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1620098978}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018627837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 12012, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7464, 'last_played': 1704053468}
review:
Lots of people seem to like this game, and honestly, I just can't recommend this. This game is so RNG is hurts, you can carry as many resistance items to counter enemies and look at plenty of guides, but it wont prepare you for when an extremely hard rare monster comes out of the woodwork and happens to freeze/stun your character even when you have plenty of stun resistance, causing insta-death.There are options to play with lives instead of straight up rogue-like, however it doesn't matter when that unique monster appears (even when playing safe and not opening any locked doors or chests), and ends up killing you 3 or 4 times in a row basically ending your run anyways. Going through every hallway manually will add on another 3 hours through uninspired setting makes every run a drag, many enemies blend together after killing so many and eventually you'll be pressing the auto-explore key more than you ignore the scrolls of exposition that are thrown everywhere on the floors of dungeons. 

So in the end, I feel like theres no sense of skill progression when playing this game. It's impossible to avoid insta-killing creatures, the settings are uninspired, and the runs last so long that its heart-breaking when you die due to situations you cant avoid. Go play Binding of Isaac or a game with better music.

EDIT: Got killed by a teleporting (cant run), 10K HP tank with a bajillion ranged damage. Lots of opportunity to outplay that.

EDIT2: Game won me over. Finally beat it after nearly 200 hours. Game can be very RNG at times tho.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063450055', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 13683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10882, 'last_played': 1658498356}
review:
So after about 186 hours of gameplay, I've managed to:
Beat the game three times for all 3 endings
Destroyed various "Impossible bosses" sometimes by the skin of my teeth
Unlocked every race and every single class possible and almost all the paths for each class
Literally suicide myself for 5% of a monsters health
Literally get killed from my future self
Sat there and watched slimes peel off of walls for 30 minutes straight
Became a pirate
Betrayed almost every neutral npc that sent me on a quest to go kill the other guy
And murdered a bunch of little elves because the world is cruel like that
10/10 would waste half my life on it again in the next itteration of the game

author: {'steamid': '76561198150145155', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 27116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2476, 'last_played': 1703643432}
review:
EDIT: This is my favorite roguelike! And I do now, in fact, know how to pronounce it.

A little while back I felt the urge to play a good classic-feeling roguelike, I scoured Steam for a bit trying to find what I was looking for. I found this game on sale and decided: "Screw it, I'll buy the Volumes edition since it's cheap." 

I really didnt expect much from the storepage, but it looked promising enough, and I had the money.
..Overwelmingly Positive reviews do not lie.

I immediately binged far more than I expected to till the sun was up. I currently have 27 total hours and I have SO much more to unlock and see. I've hardly scratched the surface, and that's just the base game. I got the Volumes edition on sale, and looking at the full prices now it still feels cheap.

Overall, very happy with my decision. 

...Now if only I knew how "Maj'Eyal" was supposed to be pronounced.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985362230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 35710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30697, 'last_played': 1657388970}
review:
ToME is, in my opinion, the best rogue-like on the market. By far what makes the game so good is the sheer number of options and unique mechanics present within the game. There are tons of races and classes, each class itself having a unique set of skills. Classes vary on mechanics, resource bars working in different ways, and so on. There's no other game out there that I can think of where you can be a typical elven mage, an orcish gunslinger, an ogre chronomancer, a dwarven entropy cultist, a halfing that turns into ooze, or a yeti with psychic powers, all in the same game. And that's just a few of the options available to you. These differences, along with the randomly generated dungeons and monsters within, help keep every game of ToME fresh and unique.

The game isn't perfectly balanced, nor can it really be with so many options available to you. There are also a few moments where the randomness can feel unfair, though not nearly to the extent that most other roguelikes have. Overall, though, there's very little to complain about.

Don't let the graphics fool you. ToME is one of the best games on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972349695', 'num_games_owned': 695, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1710909117}
review:
Awesome game in a style much like old Ultima RPGs but a better system for skills, moving and attacking. I think the "turn based" mention is over-stated, it is not like a typical turn based RPG game and everything is fluid. Every action or movement you take allows the enemies to move and perform their actions as well but the game time is not progressing unless you are actively doing something. The screenshots and videos show you pretty much how it goes. Some of the actions are mouse clicks but everything else is bound to hotkeys. I haven't played it much yet but it was fun and easy to get into. The graphics and sound are good, I look forward to unlocking more classes because you are limited in the beginning to a few classes.

One thing I really liked is that you can find items that will inscribe new spells onto you that you can then use on the hotbar just like any other spell. Different spells are boosted by different stats, so I found a rejuvenation healing spell that was boosted by strength as well as one that is boosted by magic stat. Each class has fixed spell lines that they can level up with skill points, but you can still add more cool spells that can be used in combat (not single use or limited use items).

Overall intuitive interface (except for things requiring hotkeys), and it is easy to get into exploring the land and dungeons, and fighting. Most things have left or right mouse click to bring up a menu to perform an action, but it seemed like i needed to hit '<' after standing on the box to go in and out of areas/up down stairs etc. The Alchemist has a pet, and using F1 and F2 switches you back and forth between controlling your pet and yourself. While controlling the pet you press I for inventory and you can equip items on your pet. For moving items between characters, left clicking an item in your inventory gives you a menu and one of the items was "Move to other char". Everything has been easy to learn so far, and this game seems like a fully developed RPG that is well worth the low price.

review: An unforgiving but exquisitely made Roguelike thats been around for ages(literally started as a LOTR Roguelike and evolved to this now) that'll keep you coming back. With story actions that will lead you into unlocking new Class/Race options, you'll want to come back to it every time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075976814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 28664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10532, 'last_played': 1687897232}
review:
I know this as a one-man labour of love for more than a decade. I first tried it back when it was still Tolkien-themed. Bought it when it appeared on steam to support the author - it's open source so it's not technically necessary, but there are some (small) perks too.
It's not the perfect roguelike by any means - if anything, it shows why roguelikes and long stories/open world map like in a JRPG isn't necessarily a great combination. But it's executed as well as can be done. It's all about min/maxing, but that's not bad in a game like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032457930', 'num_games_owned': 1840, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 14262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6789, 'last_played': 1693261252}
review:
General: 

Rating: N/A  (but probably E)
Price: $6.99
Genre: Rogue-like, RPG
Time played: 164.7 hours

Gameplay - 10

Turned based strategy rolled into a roguelike game. You start off by picking a class and race, options are limited at first.  Each race has pros and cons as does each class.  Depending on what you pick you’ll start in different places, with different objectives. Magic, weapons, armor it’s all there, you just have to figure out how and if you can use it.  

Story -  10

The world is alive with, well everything.  There’s ancient lore, mystic ruins, normal ruins. Necromancers and Trolls to fight. You’ll travel to distant locations, fight off various bad guys, or good guys depending.  Learn about the Spellblaze and why magic is forbidden.

A very rich and … well not inviting they are dangerous things out there. But, a world filled with adventure for sure. 

I really am underselling this.  It’s amazing. 

Graphics - 8

For a roguelike game this has pretty decent graphics. Your spells and the enemies will put off various effects and provide a very immersive feel to it.  Well at least for me anyways. 

Controls - 8 (mouse/keyboard)

Most things can be done with the mouse, however as you play more and more you’ll start looking up the keyboard commands so you can play faster… well not move your mouse hand as much I suppose. 

Repeatability - 10

Starting out you’re going to die. A lot.   Get over it. Rogue games mean you need to learn from your mistakes and try harder.  If you don’t learn, you’re gonna have a bad time. You’re not going to enjoy this game. Luckily, this is a roguelike, meaning you can earn things (races/classes/equipment) that will carry over to your later runs, making them easier and more rewarding. The zones(dungeons) don’t really change much, just your character and how you handle them.  As an alchemist, one of my favorite classes, you and your mighty Golem, yes you can summon a golem to tank for you, will probably handle things much much different than say an Archmage or different than a Warrior. Each run will be different and exciting so tons of replayability. Also looks like they recently updated the game with even more stuff, more DLC and free race/class upgrades.   Why aren’t you playing already? 





Music - 8

Atmospheric and pleasant. Unless it’s dangerous out and then not so much. Still worth it. 

Multiplayer - N/A 

Initial Thoughts: 

Ooo another rogue-like.  I first started playing this game off the T.O.M.E. Website(server? I don’t remember) so the 164 hours isn’t correct.  I played and unlocked a few classes, then life caught up to me and forgot about the game for a while.  Then found it on Steam and dove right back in, I love rogue type games and this is one of the better one. 

Soma Says: 

Fantastic game.  Love everything about it. Looks like the game recently got an update which means i need to dive back in and start playing more. Also found out that apparently I backed this game? Or donated? I don’t know. But I have the ability to use “Exploration mode”, things have changed so maybe everyone has this.  Basically you have unlimited lives and can respawn over and over.  You can also unlock various classes/races that carry over to the ‘real’ game. … why did i ever stop playing this?  

I wrote about one of my characters a long while back. Sadly too much to put here. But I wrote it all here :  https://docs.google.com/document/d/1V2h2IU5yWzG-NDsr0DXxUhvmsT-Ju_W13rrY5OUxY3s

Take a look if you want. 

If you enjoyed the review check out my curator page : https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28849369/

author: {'steamid': '76561198103907604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 29958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15338, 'last_played': 1688533688}
review: This game is almost too good to be true. Like I feel there should be a contract to sell my organs at a later date in order to get this game. But there isn't. There is no catch. It just is that good. I could have played this for free and spent the same amount of time on it, but it feels criminal to consider. This game deserves the money, plain and simple. It doesn't have the best graphics, but even they have a charm to them. And the variety is unmatched. It's the Elysium/Dominions of Roguelikes and at near a quarter the price. Seriously, play it for free if you don't believe me and many, many other reviews who say likewise. You'll join us.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993757302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 104693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77107, 'last_played': 1633764278}
review:
This is a great rogue like style turn based RPG.

It may not seem like much if you're used to more polished games, but this one of the better looking rogue likes.
If you can get past the older style of graphics you'll find a great tactical combat game.
I personally don't mind the style and prefer it over the more common 8 bit styles. 
The game also has some really good background music.

There is a great variety of monsters and zones to fight in, keeping things fresh and interesting.
Also a great many classes to choose from, some the familiar classics and other stranger ones.
Class build, I would say is a core part of the game.

The lore is mostly in scraps of paper you can pick up and is surprisingly in-depth.
 
All the DLCs are great additions that are not necessary to buy but add tons of flavour.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968649157', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 34752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11987, 'last_played': 1707936069}
review:
This game is superb. It aint pretty to look at, but if you manage to look past the graphics and actually give it a good go, there is so much depth and content to discover. 

This is a RogueLike game with a proper story campaign that can keep a single character busy for many hours. Much longer than the standard for the genre. I normally don't much care for roguelikes, as they tend to be too narrowly focused and simplistic, however, Tales of Maj'Eyal (ToME for short) manages to overcome that barrier and pull me in more than most games ever could.

In all my years of playing RPG's, no game has matched the quantity and flavor of classes that ToME possesses. There are so many unique and interesting ideas, all with varying levels of customizability. Trying new classes, making unique builds, and making attempts at higher difficulties all manage to keep me very busy. Overall, if you love trying new classes and a strong sense of progression, you should definitely give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076746842', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 31683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29126, 'last_played': 1690649537}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal - прекрасный, завораживающий рогалик. В нем вы сможете найти: большое количество разнообразных расс и классов, большое количество предметов, хорошо проработанный лор. Вы можете выбрать сложность игры для себя (будь то rougelike с insane (сложность, где ты не можешь позволить себе ошибиться, так как любая твоя ошибка может стать фатальной), будь то explorer с easy (сложность, которая, по моему скромному мнению, больше подходит для изучения Лора, чем для "игры")). Куча открываемых "вещей" (классы,расы,события,ветки,локации и т.д.), которые сделают мир Maj'Eayl более широким, а игровой процесс более разнообразным. Сюжет игры линеен (конец игры будет один и тот же), но как дойти до конца вы всегда выбираете сами (будете вы за Магов или антимагов, будете ли вы становиться личом или же нет, будете спасать tinker или же встаните на сторону головореза и т.д.). И в конце хотелось бы отметить, что разработчик до сих пор следит за своим творением: исправляет баги, добавляет новые классы, устраивает "события", выпускают DLS (которые порой добавляют новый мир и историю (Orcs: Ember of Rage)). Я полность доволен этой игрой и не жалею денег, которые потратил на неё.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055294035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 37623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17483, 'last_played': 1708737191}
review:
This game has so much depth that it is hard to be "done" with it: multiple game modes, races and classes, procedural item generation (except for legendary items/artifacts) and replayability through not being able to level every single spell and ability in a single playthrough (except if you use mods which increases replayability even more!). A classic, slow, turn-based RPG that can certainly become quite complex if you look at formulas and mechanics, but it's not like you have to min-max everywhere (especially not during your first few playthroughs). It gets really difficult on Insane difficulty though.

All in all a great game to just relax with or watch a livestream on your other monitor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198294555008', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 26703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5823, 'last_played': 1702784198}
review: Whenever I sit down to play ToME I always end up spending hours more then I've intended to, its simplicity along with its replayability is all i could ever ask for in an RPG, art style is a major sticking factor however, as much as i like the game, the loading screens and game artwork leaves something to be desired, not something that would make me not want to play the game, but something I personally find offputting. Even to this day the devs continue to update the game with new expansions, and the mod support is always a plus if your looking to personalize your experiance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055868075', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12609, 'last_played': 1661653373}
review:
"Напишите (или обновите) обзор на номинированную игру" - сделано!

А если серьезно, ребят, любите рогалики? Отлично! Любите ЭрПиДжи? Два из двух! Здесь с лихвой есть и того и другого.
Газиллион комбинаций раса/класс и отнюдь не для красоты, у каждого свои плюсы(и минусы разумеется!) и свой уникальный геймплей. Способов глупо умереть а-ля "Какая интересная статуя! Не вижу ничего плохого в том чтобы ее потрогать..." еще больше. Конечно, кого-то может отпугнуть графическая составляющая, но выбирать игры исходя только лишь из этого? Нет, спасибо, и вообще, надо ли напоминать, что воображение - лучший графический процессор? ;)

Взял полный набор без всяких там скидок и ни о чем не жалею, но при желании, можно опробовать бесплатную базовую версию на сайте(прокрутите описание игры вниз). "Здесь я закончил" - как говорил один робот, удачного дня! :P

author: {'steamid': '76561198254290399', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2154, 'last_played': 1676590349}
review: For the price that this game is at, it goes above and beyond to provide a truly riveting yet challenging experience. Very few games that i have played are as in-depth and varied as this game and as a result this game always seems to draw me in. Drifting between carefully planned and invested builds to random combinations that are equally engaging to play goes to show the level of work that went into the game being accesible to everyone. Sure its difficult and there aren't many instances in which you complete the campaign but this game, like the Soulsborne series, forces you to adapt to the challenges you face and prepare accordingly. Bought this game as a way to clear out the rest of my Steam wallet and I do not regret my decision. Keep it up Netcore, you've done a great job.

author: {'steamid': '76561198107731233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 106168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62015, 'last_played': 1708719967}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal (ToME) es, para mí, el juego más profundo y difícil al que he jugado. Más de mil horas de juego, y las que me quedan si quiero pasármelo en dificultades mayores. Este juego y The Binding of Isaac son los juegos de los que estoy más orgulloso de tener en mi biblioteca de Steam.

Pros
- Repleto de razas y clases donde elegir, cada una con múltiples opciones donde especializarse
- Estrategia por turnos donde manejas a un solo personaje
- Mecanicas de sigilo, magia, velocidad, iluminación, trampas, arcos,...etc. Siempre hay una clase del gusto de alguien. Incluso existe una clase, el Aventurero, que es capaz de combinar, al gusto, sus habilidades según tu estilo de juego
- Múltiples opciones de selección de dificultad y de regular la muerte permanente
- La mejor interfaz y la mayor calidad de vida, gráficos incluidos, en un roguelike clásico (para mi gusto)

Contras
- Puede apabullar al principio su dificultad. Demasiada información sobre la descripción de cada una de las habilidades, los atributos, etc.
- La mayoría de razas y clases se irán desbloqueando según vayas avanzando en el juego y su historia, lo que te limita al principio. Aunque a mí personalmente me gusta este sistema, ya que te desafía a seguir hasta desbloquear todo
- Morirás mucho, prepárate


En definitiva, si buscas una experiencia inmersiva y desafiante, ToMe es tu juego. Por el precio que tiene es una ganga, junto a sus expansiones, que por cierto merecen mucho la pena. Aunque si no te atreves a desembolsar ese dinero, prueba el juego, que es gratis, y si te gusta, pagarás el juego encantado, como hice yo.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198071824280', 'num_games_owned': 1134, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1637969872}
review: It is a brilliant game that will have you manage both your skills and wits. You will get punished fast if you get to agressive and forget to think about what type of environment and enemies you are encountering. You will have to be smart about how you build your character and what type of items you are using, at any time. Music and sounds effects are nice, but nothing memorable. Story elements are interfesting and if you stop and read some of the lore, you will also get some hints as to how you could play the game. The combat and character customization (items/skills) is where this game shines for me and if you are a sucker for those elements, I would highly recommend you to give the game a look:)
