author: {'steamid': '76561198032206548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 721, 'last_played': 1643939157}
review:
This is an interesting game, set in a world loosely based on the works of JRR Tolkien (Lord of the Rings). It plays as a traditional roguelike, but with a ton of streamlining and "quality of life" features. Your skills are displayed in a way reminiscent of WoW-era MMORPGs, with a skill bar where the cooldown on your moves is clearly shown. There is also an online component, but this is more or less just in the form of a chat channel that you can ask other players questions in.


The graphics are beautiful. I tend to prefer ASCII graphics in these games, but this does have very high quality art that adds to the overall setting quite nicely. The music is also nice, though somewhat generic in the grand scheme of fantasy RPG worlds.


Also, in a world where its rare to find a demo of a game... Netcore Games offers the base game for Tales of Maj'Eyal (with no DLC) at no cost. It can be downloaded here: https://te4.org/download 
This is not a timed demo, it is the full game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969858037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4976, 'last_played': 1622560172}
review: I died a lot. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198259708070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5563, 'last_played': 1670566927}
review: This game requires a good imagination on the part of the player, and offers an interesting strategic experience that can feel brutally imbalanced at times. Mages are always high-priority targets, and often have some kind of shielding. Easy enough to get through if you're using multi-hit moves or high single target damage. Snow Giant Boulder Thrower is possibly the most frustrating thing to fight in the game. While certainly beatable, there's a feeling of infuriation that comes with being flung out of range by a square of hefty damage. That being said, I played this game for free off of the website  in every bit of free time I had for about two and a half months. Then I bought the game along with the DLC on Steam. I've created incel sith lords, Heracles from the Fate franchise, Skull Knight from Berserk, and other similarly inspired characters. The game shines when you unlock the Adventurer class, which gives you access to every class and generic tree, excluding racial trees, in the game that you have unlocked. The game is a number cruncher, but you can get by without whipping out a calculator. Just assume you need your shield rune to enter any new room.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066475173', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 14645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11075, 'last_played': 1685754201}

Tales of Maj'Eyal provides an excellent variety of classes and races, an intricate gameplay and strategy experience, and an expansive world to get lost in.

Despite Tales of Maj'Eyal having started development an entire decade ago, the developer still actively updates and improves upon the game constantly, and will most definitely continue to do so for the foreseeable future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084305951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1168, 'last_played': 1543023279}
review: To me, this is the quintessencial rogue-like of nowadays. Merging the old turn-based rules  (world moves when you move) of legitimate rogue-likes, this one is held together by a truly complex attribute~skill system, capable of translating the widest, most comprehensive tabletop experiences into a model reminiscent of old D&D gameplay. Classes and races open up as you move through the world, unlocking pieces of history and uncovering a scenario where magic was forbidden on account of old transgressions. The game is constantly updated and offers a nice engine, open to modifications of all kinds. When I'm looking for a nice dungeon-crawling experience and I'm away from my PBF sites and tabletop companions, this is the game I fire up! Highly recommended for everyone and a must-play for RPG and rogue-like lovers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034443801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 51434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17801, 'last_played': 1633989324}
review: What makes a good game? Simple to learn and extremely difficult to master. There's a lot to this game. The simple graphics and controls belie a pretty interesting world with some cool lore. What really drew me in and in my opinion where this game really shines, is the classes. They all have a pretty unique feel and despite a couple of stinkers, there's some really pretty unique ones like Demonologist, Oozemancer, or Corruptor in addition to revisting some RPG staples like the Archmage and the (Sun) Paladin. This game requires some planning, some patience, and a lot of dying to really get anywhere. If you're a fan of roguelikes and you remember Angband, this is probably the strongest successor I've found. Really a great game. There are some fan-made mods out there worth checking out as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054523075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2591, 'last_played': 1666641955}
review:
I know I shouldn't go so harsh on this game, it's very humble and the devs clearly put a lot into this game, especially for the price at hand. If you're the sort of person that's conscientious about the effort a dev puts into their work or someone that doesn't get too worked up over their time being wasted for trying something new, this review isn't for you. 

With that being said, let me say straight up that the design philosophy for this game completely fails to work. As an RPG this game fails to respect the player's willingness to commit and as a roguelike it fails to provide a smooth experience to make the replayability aspect work.

In terms of gameplay it seems really simple on the surface, which can be good, simple is sweet. Unfortunately, the reality is that it simultaneously requires too much of the player's attention to be a mindless passtime, but is too uninteresting in its gameplay to compensate for the attention it demands.
As you learn the flow of the game from frequent deaths, you'll find just how much micromanagement is actually necessary  to be optimal. You have to optimise your equipment and skills, which means pouring over every bit of relevant loot and new skills after every zone and level up, but this game is awful at presenting this information so you never become familiar with it even after 20 odd playthroughs. 
The game doesn't give much context for all the stats in a game either. Platemail is hugely diminishing for energy usage, but it offers a whopping 7 armour. But what is 7 armour in this game, 7/100? What does it mitigate, is it a flat deduction from attacks or a percentage? How should good gear for my character's level look like?
The player will expend a lot of effort for what is effectively monitoring numbers and moving tiles on a map. Even then you don't ever feel in control over what's going on. Attacks occur so quickly that you'll just get confused and frustrated as to what just happened, it's punishing but not in a coherent way.

How about the replayability?
The start of every game is too repetitive to encourage a player to push on after you're familiar with it, but getting the unlockables is utterly asinine so chances are you won't have much variety to play with after you've experienced a good chunk of the original classes. 
So then you have to pigeonhole yourself into playing terrible characters just for a chance to unlock new stuff, but chances are you'll die before you can even accomplish that much because even the most thought-out minmaxed character is at risk of dying instantly from a random thunder mage.
Ultimately it doesn't end up playing differently on reruns, just gearing differently. Which all goes to waste in the end either way since you'll die. Even if you think you're fully content with losing all progress when you die, you won't be. You will be far from Okay when you die.

In conclusion, this game isn't worth the commitment it requires to succeed at it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042226688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 10195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9356, 'last_played': 1686111734}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal is tedious, repetitive, clunky, and bloated as a game, feeling as if it is barely held together by sloppy stitches. It is also visually an atrocity with an average plot. However, it makes up for this by presenting an enormous amount of long term strategic content and options to players, allowing for serious sessions of pondering and theorizing about optimization, values, and synergies. Overall, Tales of Maj'Eyal can be a magical experience at times, but all of its appeal is encompassed by the long term strategizing and not the short term tactical rewards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089443956', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 38881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18467, 'last_played': 1686656467}
review:
TOME is a rare blessing. Seriously, this game is amazing, and painfully underrated.

If you have even one bit of a gene for having fun building characters, great story and reading you will possibly find this game to be the steal of your life. The amount of replayability in this game is unreal. All while it provides you a good bit of challenge.

Depending on who you are, this might be the best game there ever was for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962082784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 493, 'playtime_forever': 7311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7311, 'last_played': 1652666658}
review:
Before I get started here, most of the issues I am about to complain about are going to only be serious issues in dozens of hours of play as you start to seriously try to clear the game. On a basic level it is still a solid, unique experience worth trying out.

Tales of Maj Eyal is really only a roguelike by inertia at this point. Stemming back to Angband mods, TOME has been in development in its current form for nearly 15 years and the author has been working on related projects for even longer. With TOME you are getting an ancient product that has been retooled and upgraded and expanded almost nonstop for most of the author's life and probably longer than most of you have even BEEN alive.

Along the way, TOME has abstracted away almost all roguelike genre conventions. Traps are nonexistent. Hunger is gone. All items are identified. No potions, no scrolls, weight management is a formality at best... Everything is focused on Diablo loot and dozens of unique skill trees for the game's over two dozen classes. There is almost nothing I have seen in the whole RPG genre that gives you the sort of variety TOME's class trees offer. Everyone from the fighter to the wizard has two hotbars full of cooldown abilities and will usually be cycling 2-4 of them in any fight. Potion equivalents in this game are runes which are simply more equippable cooldown abilities that facilitate your get out of jail functionality. This game is honestly closer to turn based Diablo at this point than Rogue, with the piles of loot to match along with the single greatest QOL upgrade I have ever seen in the genre: a to-sell box that holds all the loot you grab in a level. Before you leave, you can sort through it all, pull out anything that catches your eye, and anything left is auto-sold. More games need to rip this feature off.

The problem is this game is still bloated with 15 years worth of weight. For a game with so much class variety, runs last way too long, 10-20 hours just to clear it once. The world map is bloated with dungeons and other crap that serves no purpose except for a few side quests that you must randomly find because they give skill points for garbage busywork. You will hit the level cap before you are even 66% through the game. Even worse, some of the content is tuned so tough some insane people insist on running extra dungeons on top just for earlier leveling or to fish for more loot.

Worse still, turn based Diablo means you are constantly blasting hordes of trash enemies one at a time, slowly, one by one. ARPG hordes without ARPG speed and where bump combat is mostly discouraged in favor of alternating 1, 2, 1, 3, 1, 2... hundreds of repetitive trash enemies in far too many pointless dungeon floors there to bore you until you find the one tough enemy. You can see his abilities, but your own are a dizzying mess of numbers spread all over the perk tree, good luck reading his and being able to guess "Man that debuff sounds nasty. Can I resist it with my save stats?" (Pro tip: enemy level means almost nothing) Its a surprise and the prize is all your stuff goes on cooldown all at once and then he hits you for 3x your max hp on your second hit.

That's the other problem. You have all these interesting stat trees but the game doesn't end up giving you any useful info with them. Gear descriptions are horrific and basically require mods to present info in a useful fashion. Most of your skills are braindead picks (the only defense skill) but the ones that are not are tickets to reading online and see if in THIS version of the game is X dps route a noob trap or is Y? And even then you cannot really make a guess as to if you can take this or that boss without having died to him already or hoping your escape options can actually get you out if you got knocked down to 2 hp in one hit. All this glosses over how long you have to play as a character to finally start amassing more complicated skill combos than just defense passive and two DPS actives you alternate between.

The end result is a game that is full of contradictions. It aims high, almost to Etrian Odyssey tier in variety of class skills, a focus away from roguelike garbage and instead on tactical combat and ARPG build cobbling together, but it doesnt actually reward or engage with clever play, runs too long to let you actually enjoy the variety, does not make early game growth fun like even Battle Brothers, a game almost ENTIRELY about endlessly repeated early game growth, can. For the scope of what it offers, TOME is one of a kind and, again, a lot of these issues wont show up until you start playing to win over and over and over, but these are still significant problems for a game built around repeated play. I have tried to come back to this game over and over after my successful spite clear but I feel I have given it all the chances I can. I never even want to look at this game's awful first 6 dungeons ever again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198142579242', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 38026, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31969, 'last_played': 1558232489}
review:
This is a fantastic roguelike... I have been playing this game for years now (not all on this account and not all on steam) and still find it entertaining, even after playing the predecessors to this game, Angband and Tales of Middle Earth for many years prior. I even donate to the developer on a semi yearly basis, as I feel like I've gotten a disaportionate level of enjoyment for the cost.  It is a great game, I really want to convey this information... so I'll take a shot at it here.

Why is it so great?  A multitude of classes and races, each with many different skill trees to explore.  Tons of different dungeons. Semi-linear gameplay (don't need to do all dungeons and to some degree can choose the order they are played in). So many different strategies to explore and always a sense of discovery, whether it may be some random gear or some terrible foe.

I was not interested in the DLC, thinking the main game was good enough, but in my fashion of occassionally paying/donating to the developer, I decided to just buy the DLC time around (on another account though). To my surprise they are so far some pretty nice chunks of content for the game.  They add new classes, races, and they do some unique things not found in the main game, such as add some more engrossing narratives.

Also, love that it has Linux support (and Windows and OSX).  Finally, it should be noted that this game is open source and can be downloaded for free elsewhere.  What buying it on steam gets you is the cloud-save feature, an "items vault" that you can use to pass whatever miracles the RNG sends your way between your characters, and some other cloud features I haven't really explored.

%100 I recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198123051944', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2773, 'last_played': 1591301221}
review: Очень добротная игра в стиле старых добрых рогаликов. Если вы никогда не играли в Nethack или Rouge, вам интересно опробовать все эти диковенные игры, но символьная графика пугает вас или кажется слишом архаичной, тогда вам обязательно стоит попробовать TOME. Она проста для новичков, имеет неплохую визуализацию и при всём при это не растеряла основные признаки жанра.  Если вы не уверены, что хотите тратить на неё целых(!) 169 рублей, то я предложу вам скачать бесплатную версию с сайта разработчиков, которая практически ничем не уступает стимовской.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080216201', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 22608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20348, 'last_played': 1703504720}
review:
"Todd, what are you saying?! This can't be!"

Scribbl'doo furrowed his tightly knit eyebrows as he waited for Todd's awnser. 
His scowl deepened with every spent second.

"I'm sorry Scribbl'doo, but it's true. Zigurs...."



"The Zigurs are good people."

"No! Lies! Blasphemy! Those filthy zigurs! No one loves them! Their broodmates don't
even like eachother! The other members of the council will have your liver with onions served on 

silver platter for this!"

Todd remained stonefaced, steady in his ways. Nothing could shake him. Time passed. What
felt like minutes, no... hours, days... years? Millenia even? The very fabric of time
and reality could have warped and passed by him and Todd would still be standing still 
and untouched. That is how steady his newfound resolve is. Then Todd spoke.

"First off, Scribbl'doo, it's called a relationship. You know, like a husband and wife? Or a wife 

and a wife? Or a hungdior and a manchurian? It is the year 468xtr after all. Secondly, 

Scribbl'doo..." Todd said his name like a sarcastic prick. "Secondly... I've lived with the
ziguranth. Yeah, you know, the ziguranth? Not the Zigurs, thats wrong. Anyways, I'ved lived with 

them. Befriended them. I even considered the tabatari bonding ritual with several of their woman.
They're quite beautiful, you know".

"You're disgusting! Scribbl'doo was raving like a madman at Todd's words. He wouldn't accept it. 

yellow foam frothed ferociously from his mouth. It came out in a spurting spread of spittle with 

every word. He wouldn't accept it.
His life was rooted deep in hatred of the Ziguranth. "They hunted our magician families for 

years!" He recalled the family stories. How the Zigur's killed so many magic users, even his own 

family. 

Todd conituned. "I hearby take my leave from the council! I urge the others... no, all of 
you to follow me. This senseless bigotry cannot stand! By hilmsgoroth's beard, I will not stand 
in this country again. Goodbye Todd... My one true love". Drips of water gently flowed down his 

face. It wasn't raining out. 

Scribbl'doo's countenance changed. He stood calm, as if he just woke up from a peaceful sleep.
He looked up at Todd, and his face slowly twisted into a sinister snarl. He had but one last 
thing to say.

				"YOU FUCKING ZIGUR!"

author: {'steamid': '76561198028582889', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 5070, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2677, 'playtime_at_review': 1898, 'last_played': 1711503747}
review:
This was a game I really didn't expect to like. A friend had recommended it to me, and on a whim, I purchased it & didn't really think much of the game from the first couple of hours that I played. As time passed I was drawn back by the fantasy setting, RPG elements, and rogue-like qualities that I typically enjoy in a video game. In doing so, I found a profoundly deep and rewarding experience within this game. I really enjoyed creating the various race/class combinations and playing through their respective story lines within the main campaign.

My only gripe with the game is the monotony of progression with each campaign. Despite the changing maps, having to re-do the same quests always felt like a drag on each new character play-through. I feel like the game would be so much better if they took an "open world" approach to how their maps & campaigns work, but perhaps it simply isn't feasible with this kind of game and the engine/design they use. Despite this, however, it's a great RPG rogue-like that is well worth the buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037075807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8161, 'last_played': 1559528369}
review:
Starts out as something that seems incredibly deep in gameplay, challenging but fun to learn.

Unfortunately, this game ends up as a real chore where you must "pick the right class, get lucky" rinse and repeat game.

It is completly unreasonable what the game will put you through... let me give an example.

You will be presented with the crypt random encounter at level 24 that if you do not enter, you will never be able to enter again. Keep in mind this entire side quest and good xp is gone if you don't enter. Should you chose to enter, you are faced with enemies level 40+ that can kill you in one hit. Stack blight resist they say, and sure that can work some of the time but the game is RNG. Get a random rare enemy with physical ranged attacks and you are one shot for your entire HP despite wearing heavy plate armor and having loads of points into HP and physical defense. Too bad for you start over.

Want to have fun playing a class that utilizes mana or many of the interesting class resources? Get rekt. There are several enemies in the game that can drop your entire class resource to 0 before you can even see them from maximum distance.

For some reason, when playing a magic user on Nightmare (the difficulty after normal, not even close to the hardest difficulty), when you encounter a follower of Zigur on the world map, they are always 2X your level? Is this a joke? At almost every stage, this encounter will kill you. You will either get one shot, or two shot. Game over, try again.

This game has a huge amount of variety and a lot of charm too it. But it is too bad that you cannot enjoy it because of mechanics that screw over certain classes and some completely unbalanced encounters that get you one shot killed through no fault of your own.

All that being said, kudos to the developer for putting effort into making this game. It isn't an expensive title, and a lot of creativity can be found here. Probably has the most interesting mechanics and armchair fun gameplay you could ask for in a low budget title. But considering the tediousness of it and the unfair rare enemy one shotting you because you didn't stack resist to a single damage type, I cannot reccomend to the average gamer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014241544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 9887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8350, 'last_played': 1622181495}
review:
One of the best games on steam. Each class has loads of different abilites to use, setting it apart from most rouge likes where combat just consisits of running into you enmimes to do damage. The game is not 100% balanced, so some classes are more powerfull than others, but each has its own flavor and is worth a shot.

Gamplay remindes me a lot of World of Warcraft, just turn based. all of your abilites have a cool down, and you need to pick which one is  best suited for you at the moment. you need to keep in mind that your foes have abilites as well, so remember to pay atention to what you are fighting, lest you get suprised. 

there is perma death if you want it, or if you dont it can be turned off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098261643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 9525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9163, 'last_played': 1518980476}
review: What every review fails to touch on, is how much you will LOATHE this game. And that's what keeps you coming back. Screw you, "Snake with guns but also summons time-dogs to maul you, I'm coming back and WINNING this time"! You won't of course, but that won't stop you from trying yet again, until woops! 160 hours have passed and my wife left me. This experience will leave you hollow and full of hatred, but that's what you're here for, you masochist. 9/7

author: {'steamid': '76561197967685401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 1474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1306, 'last_played': 1664661129}
review:
This game will break you.

A roguelike with an active developer. ToMe may look prettier than Rogue and Adom, but don't be fooled. This game is just as brutal. The classes are fully fleshed out, you have entire skill trees to work your way through. Its also a fairly complex system, with everything from world speed to specific resistances. ToME is a rogue for rogue lovers. Open World? Check. Expansive Lore? Check. Rediculous amount of classes and races? Check. Want to be a time traveling defender of time? You can. Want to summon your own personal horde of monsters? Its got a class for that. Want to worship unseen terrors and turn your hand into a tentacle? Yup. Sure you have your Archer, Mage, and Beserker, but have some fun! Be a Cursed, or Oozemancer. Every class plays completely differently, and the strategies in your class build help alot. I've been playing summoner for my last ten or so runs, and I still adjust my build so my next run will go smoother. 

ToMe is MASSIVE even without the DLC, and its totally worth it. This game will kill you over, and over again, until you emerge at the top. Ignore most of our hours, as most true fans have been playing since before the game was on steam. So much gameplay here if you can overlook something as minor as graphics. If you love roguelikes, ToME is one of the best, and if you are new, this is a great starting point. Learn to love dying, and explore a massive fantasy world that only wants to make you cry. DLC is cheap, and the ones that add stuff to the main campaign are worth it. The main world is so rediculously huge that none of it is necessary however. If you get tired of the lore and story there is an infinite dungeon as well.

...and if you get stuck? If you choose to play in online mode, the game has a chat so you can ask for help or just talk strategy with folks. Messages dont stay up very long, so trolling doesn't really happen. (also the game has admins if you find a particularly nasty bug.) Have fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198275527210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 69185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52477, 'last_played': 1604173675}
review:
Easily one of the best RPGs and Roguelikes ever made. This game isn't friendly to the new player, but with a few hours you'll be hacking your way through dungeons in no time. After that you begin to realize how big the game is and how complex these battles and mechanics can be. You can indeed learn to play ToME in a few hours, but mastering this game may take you months or years. 

If you enjoy theory-crafting builds, this is the game for you, many players test and retest ideas for viable builds and then test and retest them on higher and higher difficulties. 

Some classes and builds you may play can be seemingly unbeatable at lower difficulties while being completely non-viable on harder settings.

Just a fabulous game that proves (again) that style and gameplay are more important than cutting edge graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976793342', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 9571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4458, 'last_played': 1632017455}
review: If you're looking for a simple, easy to play, very forgiving game. Prepare to be disappointed. If, however, you're looking for a challenging rogue-like that doesn't depend on graphics to wow you and maintain your interest as you crash relentlessly upon the rocky cliffsides of it's learning curve...well you're almost in luck. If you're looking for a game that uses random very high level mobs in chests to kill you, has buggy issues that cause your saves to no longer function,  doesn't work with the steam cloud (despite supposedly doing so), has little in the way of actual interesting content once you've won once, you're in luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055865745', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 76442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14886, 'last_played': 1695353757}
review:
It's rare that a game captures me as much as ToME has, where even when I've moved on for the time being I'm still thinking about what kind of character I'll play next.

A word of warning: this game is hard.  It's supposed to be.  In my (as of time of review) 250 hours (edit 11/25/2020 up to 1k hours now, still just as enjoyable and the updates that have come out and are upcoming are making it pretty easy to keep playing), I've won five times, on Normal Adventure mode (aka you're allowed a handful of deaths before it's permanent).  I've been told by the friend who got me into the game that this is a surprising number of successes in that time.  That's a lot of time not winning on the difficulty settings the game is explicitly balanced around, let alone going on to any higher difficulty.  That's a lot of charaters invested in who croaked somewhere along the way.  Unlike a tough game like Dark Souls and Cuphead, there are no infinite lives here (unless you play on Exploration which kind of defeats the point of the game in my personal opinion.)  If this sounds like a dealbreaker, you do not want to get this game.

Tl:dr:
Pros - great gameplay, amazing variety of character types, friendly community, helpful, active developers, lore deep and well-developed, but not overbearing for those who don't care, addicting despite being brutally hard.
Neutrals - Soundtrack is hit or miss
Cons - UI is mediocre on the default, free range of control fixes this but the process of fixing is in and of itself unintuitive.
Verdict - I love this game, cannot recommend it enough.

This was my first true roguelike.  I've played several roguelites before, my favorite being Crypt of the NecroDancer, but this was the first time I've ever played a game where you can lose all of your progress 7 hours in.  And it's been a wonderful experience that I actively look forward to coming back to when I'm not playing.

ToME is a turn based Roguelike that focuses on high fantasy.  The world you're in is still recovering from the Spellblaze, a cataclysmic event that rocked the entire planet, and beyond.  Whether or not you care beyond that is entirely up to you for the entire first half of the game.  The story is all told in lore snippets up until you find a certain artifact that kickstarts the true plot, and it's up to you to read and understand what the world you're travelling around is like.  Until the plot does kick in, you are Random Adventurer #4765108, who starts in whatever dungeon your race/class combo starts in, and then just explores the continent for loot and fun.  The race and class pool is shallow to start so as to not overwhelm you with choices (and a lot of the more complex ones are locked at the start to encourage you to learn the base mechanics first) and you unlock the others by playing.  Witness a summoning event to get summoners.  Save a Yeek being attacked to unlock Yeeks.  Some are straightforward, others aren't.  Every class plays different from the others, and races add flavors to what you're playing making for hundreds of combinations.

The gameplay is turn based and (as someone who has never played a roguelike and therefore has no other tile-based roguelikes in my past to draw from) feels a lot like a combination of the difficulty of Crypt of the NecroDancer with the dungeon style of Pokemon Mystery Dungeon.  It's a great style, and the depth of the combat system is something I only realized when I started asking why my mages all sucked, only to find out that while I'd been doing well on stats I'd neglected spellpower focus, rendering them useless later due to resistances.  The RNG nature of dungeon creation and enemy types/spawns means every playthrough is holding something unexpected, but this can also hurt the experience...if your luck just isn't working out some night, you can have no character get past level 2 due to poorly timed rare enemies.

The game is entirely single player, but there's a chat that everyone is automatically in, and this is honestly one of the best features of the game for me.  ToME is complex, you're going to have questions, and the wiki for this game is nowhere near up to date.  But, you have several hundred other players, most of whom are likely to know the answer to your question, and generally people are happy to answer (I've been on both sides of this).  The developers are active in chat often as well, and several of my questions were answered directly by them without any prompting.  When compared to the big wig developers, it's truly nice to see the support the devs have for their players.

...I'm trying to think of any real cons, and I guess the only one I can come up with is that the default interface isn't great, and while you're allowed to move things as you want, the things you'll want to move may have their move icons hidden when you unlock the interface (my advice, change the talent bar so it's two rows deep, you'll want it, and that requires moving the chat and log up, which is the hard part due to the chat move icon being hidden behind another thing).  Otherwise, the only thing that even is kind of a con is not every track in this game is a winner, and some themes get a little grating (I love Kor'Pul's theme for two loops a night, then it just bothers me)

This game is great.  If you're on the fence about getting it I seriously suggest doing it, and getting the DLCs too...the added classes, races, areas, and events are worth it at a fraction of the cost a larger developer would charge for the content.  It's a great game, and I'm looking forward to continuing to explore the world of Eyal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121243641', 'num_games_owned': 2405, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1152, 'last_played': 1662938711}
review:
**Rogue-like Overview:
I originally just bought this game because I love RPGs, it was cheap, and the reviews were Overwhelmingly Positive. I actually didn't know anything about "roguelikes" at the time, although I've now become pretty fond of this long-standing genre, all thanks to ToME! So, in case you may be a newbie like I was, this game is a "traditional" rogue-like, which means it has turn- and grid-based combat, "procedurally generated" (random) dungeons, and "permadeath" (once you die, your character is no longer playable, and you must start again from the beginning). And you WILL die -- a lot. In fact, this is what many people most enjoy about the genre. Beating the game is actually pretty rare and typically reserved for skillful, knowledgeable players, who have cut their teeth on the corpses of many past characters.

This genre inspired many of the rogue-"lites" that have exploded in popularity in recent years, for example Binding of Isaac, Rogue Legacy, Dead Cells, etc. Its influence is also clear on ARPG titles such as Diablo and Path of Exile, once you know what you're looking for! The whole idea of "learning by dying" also lives on in Dark Souls, and by extension all of the "souls-like" imitators. That makes this a highly influential, but niche genre, that will probably appeal most to players of CRPGs, MMOs, or especially old-school MUD veterans.

**Tales of Maj'Eyal:
With that in mind, what makes Tales of Maj'Eyal (ToME, or ToME4) itself unique? What we have here is a modern, streamlined, and accessible rogue-like title that does a great job welcoming new players, while still retaining the core features that appeal to genre purists. This makes sense when you consider this game was released in 2012, giving it as much as 30 years+ of collective "lessons learned" from some of its major competitors... and it shows!

Combat is WAY more complex/tactical than most other rogue-likes, with significantly more abilities available (not just "bump, bump, bump" combat like some of the others). There is deep, complex character development as well, including talent trees to invest in as you level-up. Itemization is also fantastic, equipment being generated right from the beginning with random stats, properties, tiers, etc. There is also later game, powerful "artifact" gear to be found all over the world. WoW or Diablo players will be right at home with these aspects of the game.

Did I mention there are TONS of classes and races, many of which are unlocked by previous playthroughs? Combined with, I believe, literally the most Steam achievements of any game on the platform, it helps to give some limited feeling of persistence/progression even after your character dies, which is a very welcome addition in my humble opinion. In-game chat and the online character vault are two more awesome feature that help the game feel more modern and "alive". Oh and fully visible equipment is a huge plus too, making every character that much more unique. Plus, ToME has done away with some of the "resource management" mechanics from past rogue-likes which some players may consider outdated, e.g. hunger/thirst, etc. This game really has a look and feel all its own that stands apart from its competitors like ADOM, Dungeonmans, Rogue Empire, etc. I dig it!

On the other hand, there are a couple things I think ToME could do better. For example, other rogue-likes such as ADOM seem to have more depth overall, maintaining a certain sense of scale and mystery that is hard to match. Similarly, although ToME's world is certainly rich in lore and immersive in its own right, it does not have any central storyline to drive it forward, and the quests that I've seen so far are somewhat generic and bland. Comparing to ADOM again, while ToME does have some difficulty and gameplay settings (like modes which limit or eliminate permadeath), it is missing some of the more complex configuration tools such as monster scaling, drop rate tweaking, etc.

**Conclusion:
ToME is probably my top pick so far as I have been playing around lately with numerous rogue-likes. Admittedly I am still a relatively inexperienced player, but overall this game just seems to appeal strongly to my gaming sensibilities, so to speak, offering many modern conveniences which I really appreciate. As a life-long gamer, especially of JRPGs, CRPGs, ARPGs, tactics & strategy wargames, MMOs, and even some MUDs, I was honestly pretty surprised to discover this genre I'd never really given a proper shake before. That said, I've had a lot of fun and would certainly recommend rogue-likes (including both ToME as well as some of the others I've mentioned above) to other gamers with similar tastes to my own.

Hope you enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069464479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 49931, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30399, 'last_played': 1640208957}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal is an amazing game that has kept me playing for years. Each class is so unique and if you asked my favorite i honestly couldnt tell you and theres a great deal of customization (but sonetimes its kinda rng based like with escorts(cuz escorts can teach you skills or increase your stats)) and brotherhood potions. I understand that roguelikes are hard and it can be frustrating to lose a character because you where walking through a dungeon (this has happened to me even on dungeons i'm over leveled for) and you turn a corner and see 20 tallent effects, a loading bar, and then a floaty guy telling you you died (Summary: got killed by an overpowered randomised enemy in one turn without even getting a chance to see it without some kind of vision spell or item). This game is not "fair",the gap in power between normal and rare and unique enemies is massive! Aside from the escort rng (that i guess is there to promote odd builds and this game does this well, although through all the expansions only one more escort has been added over the base game ones and escorts are very important to making unique builds(add more plz PX)) and the surprise insta kills i can't really find any qualms with this game. The game has easier modes if the permadeath is not your thing (like me)(and they also have a harder mode if you are some kind of masochistic psycho). I also find the expansions to be well worth it and every one has been interesting. The cult x-pac has a necklace that is actually a parasite that will replace your head if you die while wearing it and a bone staff that you can talk to (but apparently refuses to offer it's special services unless you are a necromancer) loot matters. Buy, try, die, cry, return, learn.... then make them BURN!

review: I really fun game that's really horribly imbalanced. You could seriously end up fighting a level 20+ when you're only level 5. This, coupled with permadeath, makes the game nearly impossible on the "normal" level game mode. I've permenantly lost like 4 characters. My first attempt got me to level 10. After that I progressively did worse. My last attempt didn't even get me past level 5. I permanently died by the first boss. Really cool game but I wish I was better at it or something. 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198098282099', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 22526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17254, 'last_played': 1701033298}
review:
我一直以来都觉得，垃圾游戏由于槽点和问题多多，所以其评测很容易写，一般都能够写的又欢乐又充实；而相应的，越是优秀的游戏，其评测就越难写。而到达了ToME这种水平的优秀作品，则几乎让人写不出什么东西来了。想要赞扬，却会因为优点过多、不能名其一处也，而让人无从下笔。

所以单单只说它的一个方面，说一下它极其丰富的游戏内容吧。
该游戏具有10+1（第一个dlc）+3（第二个dlc）+2（第三个dlc）个种族，28+2+3+2个职业。这么庞大的种族和职业数目，在其他游戏中你能够想象吗？而且不光如此，它还不像某些声称拥有若干不同职业、实则各职业大同小异的游戏，该游戏的各职业、种族异质性是相当高的，玩法和技能各有不同的侧重、各有不同的优势和弱点。如此丰富且异质性极大的种族、职业、技能所交织出的是几乎无穷无尽的build策略和游戏体验。
并且基于这些丰富的内容，游戏提供了两类难度，使得“体验派”和“挑战派”这两类玩家都能得到满足。你想要体验式的游戏享受？在普通难度和探索模式下试试不同的build和风格吧；你想要挑战性？噩梦和疯狂难度将迫使你规划出build和战术上的最优解、最高效方式。
此外，游戏的世界观庞大而独特，它并不是类dnd体系或托尔金体系那样的传统奇幻，而是原创了一个相当奇诡的科幻与奇幻交融的世界，拥有别具一格的魅力。游戏中有着大量关于Eyal世界形形色色方面的lore碎片等待你去发现。你喜欢《黑魂》或者《空洞骑士》里那些优秀的碎片化叙述？并且你认为自己脑洞很大、头脑灵活，能够通过各个叙述碎片提炼和整理出整个世界观？那么你同样也会喜欢这个游戏的。

其他的就不说了，游戏时间证明一切。并且我觉得我还能在玩300小时。

另附本人翻译的frame-rate站对于ToME作者的采访文章：https://tieba.baidu.com/p/5008791494

author: {'steamid': '76561198107549494', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2741, 'last_played': 1690712292}
review:
Despite ToME having a fairly linear story (you can choose which order for the most part to do things in, but you're always going to the same locations) it's replayability and enjoyability are high, with;

- Alot of classes and races
- Multiple builds for each class
- Extra classes and races that are unlockable through game challenges or story events
- Randomized layouts every run
- A metric shit ton of achievements if that's your thing

The art style is a bit all over the place in my opinion, but it's not really why I play roguelikes so I don't mind. You might.
Likewise the music and audio, while alright, can get very repetitive after a while and certain sound effects are very annoying (looking at you, doors)

Overall it's still one of my favorite roguelikes and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys this type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060078411', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1698637391}
review: dont look at the graphics, the system looks confusing, and it seems boring. thats what i thought at first when i played now being about 15-16 hours in its a really good game. the combat can be fun and the story actually isnt half bad. the dlc even enhance the game by adding more classes, races, and more content to explore. An example of base game is like you have to save a town from a deadly thunder storm that spawns torrnados that shoot lighting. The only way to stop the storm is to talk to a Arch mage by finding the hidden magic town in the mountains and having them teleport you to the location. THIS QUEST GENERALLY KILLS ME!! But thats okay because by the time you get there you will have experienced things and hopefully will come to like the game like me. Theres at least 100 hours or so of content and if your bored, alone, and tired of playing other stuff id say play this game.

Why this game tickles me the right way:

author: {'steamid': '76561197998178980', 'num_games_owned': 1062, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 53279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18614, 'last_played': 1677878880}
review:
Pretty much a "must buy" if you are into rogue-like games.  It is fairly newbie friendly if you aren't (thanks to in-game chat function, so you can talk to other players if you have questions and are logged in).

[b]Pros:[/b]

[list]
    [*]Streamlined controls / UI: really easy to grasp controls. This tends to be an issue, especially with older roguelikes. There is still a bit of a learning curve but it is not a chore and pretty intuitive.

    [*]Lots of races and classes, and they all play very differently. Even with in the basic grouping of "melee/ranged/magic" you get distinct differences. Playing a shadowblade is very different from an archmage. It is hard to explain but the class design is amazing.

    [*]Great music and solid artwork. Some roguelikes suffer from the pasted over graphic packs, not an issue here

    [*] Deep... DEEP game play. A single run can take days (I have yet to win with over 300 hours in). The map is the same but dungeons and mini bosses change. There is also an insane amount of lore in the game which is well written

[*] A solid roguelike with some unique features: namely you don't have to worry about food / water or carting gear to sell to merchants. Don't worry, you will still die horribly embarrassing deaths, this game just focuses more on combat

[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]

[list]
    [*]Min/maxing: you can really go down a rabbit hole and try to create the best character

    [*]Perma death and the mighty RNG: you can switch off permadeath (or play with limited revives) but if not be prepared to eat it to random highlevel bosses that pop out of chests. Pretty common in this genre so if that isn't your thing this might not be the game for you
[/list]

If you enjoy this game (there is a free demo version out there), buy it full price. It is definitely more than worth it.

Update: 760hrs in and still no wins, still playing though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182786001', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 18437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3699, 'last_played': 1710009658}
review:
Haven't played a game this much in years. It is great. I like the unlockables, the gameplay and not so much the dying. Diablolike skill trees and tons of races and classes to play promise hundreds of hours of gameplay if you are willing to invest them.

The game is actually free but if you buy it you support the authors. So download it from www.te4.org and if you decide that you like it buy it on Steam and you get some supporter bonus content and a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021518548', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1683936775}
review:
Первым делом хочу отметить, что люди зря нагоняют страху сложностью и необходимостью потеть над билдами. Человеку, знакомому с рогаликами (или даже просто рпг) разобраться будет не сложно. Благо тут есть настройки сложности и вы можете вообще отключить пермадед, спокойно вникнув в механики. На более высоких сложностях уже будет резон подбирать нужный шмот и целенаправленно качаться.
А если не вникать особо в сюжет/лор, то базового знания английского и гугла хватит сполна. Плюс всегда можно повтыкать в ролики на ютубе.
 
В целом - отличный рогалик. Пожалуй один из лучших. Щедро падающий лутецкий, разнообразные враги, интересные бои с боссами и, порой, даже с "элитками" или "рарками". Случайные (Или не очень) события доставляют особенно, т.к. подразумевают не обычную зачистку данжа, а приключение и диалоги с вариантами выбора (!). В результате которых вы, скорее всего, получите лут, способности или разблокируете класс/расу ну или все вместе.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995078695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 25672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23095, 'last_played': 1574330950}
review: Maybe the best roguelike ever made. You can murder the whole orc race bare handed. Has tonnes of races, classes and game settings with which you can tweak the game to your liking. Even if you don't win the game, and you won't since it's a hard game, you'll still constantly unlock new stuff and it keeps the game feeling fresh and rewarding even when you lose. It has only few bugs and runs overall pretty solid as far as Roguelikes go. I would recommend to anyone interested in the genre as it is relatively easy to dive in and has actual UI that looks decent enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130281834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11401, 'last_played': 1703093369}
review: One of the best if not the best rogue-like on the market. Constant patches and new content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059605835', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4752, 'last_played': 1677338751}
review:
Данный рогалик действительно стоит считать одним из лучших рогаликов.
Большое количество рас, классов, билдов и рандомность большинства событий позволяют получить довольно высокую реиграбельность, вкупе со сложностью.
Здесь есть несколько режимов сложности, так что чалленж своих способностей присутствует в полной мере.
При этом данная игра абсолютно бесплатна(на официальном сайте можно скачать клиент и играть себе спокойно не вкладывая денег), есть возможность открытия контента самому. 

Что еще нужно жаждущей душе? Однозначно рекомендую к прохождению.

review: 這遊戲很奇怪，前面玩得好好的，後面莫名其妙王就會高你個20級，這就算了，遇到會放狀態的王，被冰起來就被玩到死，有什麼樂趣，難怪評價高，卻沒幾個人玩。玩無限命模式都想罵髒話了，玩有限命的是給時間多的人玩吧。

author: {'steamid': '76561198017246905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 2293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1490, 'last_played': 1685714166}
review:
It's ok. I bought all the DLC to support the game i thought would be good. Unfortunately it's not for me.

Few reasons why i downvote and won't waste anymore time here.

1. The interface is rubbish, the invetory screen is horrid and the tooltips are so hard to read, all the workshop mods to make things more readable are out of date. Everything about the interface is hopeless when playing with only keyboard. Bugged, can't effectivly swap between interface, you will be forced to use the mouse at points.

2. The game is all over the place and you have no idea where or what to do next unless you read guides or just die over and over again through trial and error. DCSS is much more like chess, go down levels and finish branches. 

3. You die but it only shows you the combat log of like 20 lines, i died and the enemy was ofscreen somewhere and 1 shot me, go and check the combat log and all you see is "something hits you for xxx damage" yeah thanks for being so informative.

4. Everything takes too long in the early game.

5. Loot is like an RPG with shops and selling loot and bleh.

6. World map yuk.

7. Combat is boring

I Just didn't like the game. I payed for it and i didn't like it. It's that simple, i would not recommand this game and think the reviews are a little overblown.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049427471', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 3283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2114, 'last_played': 1556313596}
review:
One of my favorite time wasters. Runs can last for a significant period of time, and since you unlock classes and even new styles of skills and magic as you play (by defeating certain enemies and completing certain quests) each run has the potential to unlock even more replay value. I've gotten a significant amount of fun out of the game and I don't even own any of the alternate campaigns (at time of writing).

It can be a bit dense at the beginning but once you get the hang of it you'll breeze through the early game every time. I'd give it a recommend as long as you're willing to get through the early information slog.

review: One of the very few roguelikes where every class feels unique with its own special playstyle, rather than being some sort of starter kit that all homogenizes to the same thing by the end game. author: {'steamid': '76561198044634050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 33950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21240, 'last_played': 1700314650}
review:
На сцені стоїть гидко разкрашений кіоск з продавцем-огром внутрі, біля кіоска стоїть купка мудил. Раптом прибігає захеканий мудило і врізується головою в кіоск.

Мудило в ржавому шоломi. Што такоє? Што, спокойно ходіть нє можетє?
Захеканий мудило (лежачі долі). Там [b]лута[/b] дoxyя!
Всі мудила. Де?
Захеканий мудило. Там! (Помирає).

Вбігає другий рога-мудило, він кулею прошиває стоячих мудил і зникає.

Мудило з двуручним мечем (шуткує). Скорость охуєвающа.

Мудила, які стоять поруч, тупо сміються та помирають вiд бєкстабу.

Мудило в блєстящєму магічному ковпаку та нічній сорочці (впевнено і різко). Там [b]ЛУТА[/b] дoxyя!

Мудило в блєстящєму магічному ковпаку та нічній сорочці зникає в напрямі, в якому, по його підставі, знаходиться дoxyя [b]лута[/b].

Мудило в кольчужних штанцях з авоською. Людвiга, шо ми стоїмо? Щас, знаєш, скіки долбойобів набіжить?

Мудило в кольчужних штанцях і Людвiга зникають.
-
Всi вмирають у баштi нєкроманта.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974756212', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 3849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3779, 'last_played': 1676947969}

author: {'steamid': '76561198048785147', 'num_games_owned': 1629, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 45793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14680, 'last_played': 1660482266}
review:
pros:
- tons of classes, races, skills, randomized dungeons, and modes makes for a VERY replayable game. You can even make completely different builds for each class, and there are over 30 of them, so that makes for a LOT of potential gametime.
- interesting, unique class and race mechanics with lots of buttons to push
- does a good job of alleviating some tedious tasks (transmog chest, autoexplore, autorest, etc.)
- has pretty decent theme with lots of variation
- better art than almost every other true roguelike
- sound is actually very useful
- lots of features to unlock
- lots of mods

cons:
- although the game has been beaten by every class on Insane (not by me, obviously), class balance is still a big factor in how well you do if you're not an expert
- graphics aren't great. monster design can be cool, but it's hard to really appreciate them when they're so small
- very steep learning curve. Oh, you want to play a rogue? Prepare to get 2-shot by the first rare mob you encounter.
- gear can be problematic. On certain levels, you want a lot of lightning resist. However, your best gear probably doesn't have lightning resist, so you'll have to carry around a spare set of gear. On other levels, it's fire. You also want a constitution set to level thick skin. You can only carry so much gear, though. These are easy problems to solve in comparison to figuring out which gear you need to actually win the game with, though, and it varies for each class. I've beaten the game, and I still don't feel like I have a good handle on which gear to wear. I do know that +HP at low levels and max stun resist throughout the game is a good place to start, though.
- random rare mobs can be harder than bosses. I know this is an intentional feature. It's just something I wish was different.
- perhaps a bit too long for a roguelike. If I'm going to lose my character forever, and I probably will, I'd prefer not having invested quite as much time into each one.

Experience:
I played on normal adventurer, starting out just trying to unlock as many features as possible, and had a great time with it. After unlocking almost everything, I tried beating the game. Took a few tries, and I actually got pretty discouraged at one point, but I managed to stumble on an OP build by accident (Doomed) that was basically invincible and had great damage. Other classes felt really weak, in comparison. It starts off slow, but once you reach a certain point in the build, you can faceroll your way through to the end.

DLC:
They're cheap and worth it. You get new classes, races, zones, items, prodigies, talents, and even a new campaign.

All in all, time well spent. I'm sure I'll be playing this game for years to come. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970632671', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 112976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52550, 'last_played': 1694085288}
review:
This is one incredibly good Roguelike, but I think what keeps me playing is the in-game chat. There is no multiplayer here, but there is a very active and beginner friendly chat on screen at all times. It also shows achievements and deaths for everyone playing. You feel like you're playing online, but you don't have to deal with dumbasses or the stupidity of anyone (besides yourself). Like any of the top tier Roguelikes, the main challenge is yourself. If you get lazy, then you will be dead, impulsive...dead, go too fast...dead, get too distracted reading the interesting conversation going on in the chat...dead. But all that said, this is not a hard game to play, you just have to not f*ck up. I have so many other great games in my library that are collecting dust as I'm going on [strike] 4 [/strike]8 years of TOME. Also, the music is amazing. There's also something to be said for the sound effects and ui which are definitely above par for any game, (imo) let alone a Roguelike. All praise Darkgod....
Updated for The Labor of Love Award

author: {'steamid': '76561198413111864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 11364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10974, 'last_played': 1539191809}
review:
Wow. Simply wow. This game is blowing me away. So much depth. I was a little aprehensive of the obvious learning curve, but you get the jist of the basics in about half an hour of play. As for the combat, I really dig it. It's turn based, but fast paced. There's all manner of characters you can play as, and even more to unlock. Dying kind of sucks, considering much the time it's simply becasue you went to he wrong place at the wrong time, but you learn to avoid certain areas. On the whole an amazing game I have no doubt I'll be putting a hundred hours or more in.

Update: Tales of Maj'Eyal is so good, so addictive, I uninstalled it. I only ever had to uninstall a game for such a reason one other time. For those of you on the fence whether to buy, keep that in mind. You're gonna have a good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026225027', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3626, 'last_played': 1700283148}
review:
This game seems very complicated and complex at first, and in some cases it is. For the longest time I did not play it because I was intimidated by it's complexity, but after giving it a go, and giving it a chance, I can say without a doubt that this game is incredible. 

It grows on you, don't pass on buying it if you love RPGs. Especially if you can get it on sale. Even then, it's still worth it full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198184802503', 'num_games_owned': 1161, 'num_reviews': 330, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1591742274}
review: You get what you paid for, 1.7K achievements at minimum price. If you’re an achievement hunter looking to increase the number of achievements on your profile showcase, then I highly recommend buying this. Else don’t waste your money. This is not a game, it’s just a way of distributing achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023927907', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 2807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 415, 'playtime_at_review': 2737, 'last_played': 1711808243}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is an incredible journey of epic proportions.  This is without a doubt one of the very best Roguelike/RPGs available today.  
  The lore...wow, the world building here is so good.  One thing that always upsets me with some roguelikes and/or rpg games that look low budget, is that when you have new armor or weapons, you don't actually get to see them on your character.  Not here, this attention to details... the immersion is so much better.
  There is a mind boggling amount of class/race combinations available to the player.  There is a really good skill tree and countless items, armor and weapons to be found.

  I am an old school gamer, graphics [u]DO NOT[/u] make for a great game, I've played plenty of garbage games that looked beautiful.  Game-play is what makes a good game, and it is here in spades.  
  If you're looking for a top-notch Roguelike/RPG, look no further...it's available right here and at a very reasonable price too!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198110523269', 'num_games_owned': 2375, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 38695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25804, 'last_played': 1683800378}
review:
드디어 한글패치!!
취향만 맞다면 최고의 게임이 될 것 입니다!

정통 로그라이크 방식의 게임이며, 
다른 정통 로그라이크 비해서 '상대적'으로 편의성이 높습니다. 

다양한 종족, 직업으로 입맛에 맞는 캐릭터를 키울 수 있고
직업마다 플레이 스타일도 꽤나 다릅니다. 

첫 진입장벽이 어느 정도 있긴하지만 그것만 넘어서면 시간가는 줄 모르고 플레이할 수 있습니다.

플레이 타임은 로그라이크 치고는 꽤나 긴 편으로 
죽지 않고 플레이를 한다고 해도 최종보스까지 15시간은 넘게 걸립니다. 
물논 죽으면 처음부터죠!
하지만 초보자를 위한 배려인지 
죽어도 계속해서 부활할 수 있는 탐험
일정 레벨마다 목숨을 주는 모험
1목숨인 로그라이크
취향껏 선택해서 플레이할 수 있습니다. 

로그라이크를 좋아하신다면 한 번 쯤 해보시는걸 추천드립니다.

review: Simplesmente o melhor roguelike (roguelike de verdade, não desses por aí que se dizem roguelike só porque têm a morte permanente) que já joguei. O jogo é muito rico em elementos, muitos ambientes, classes para jogar, inimigos, história e humor. Cada classe exige uma estratégia totalmente diferente para jogar, o que aumenta muito a rejogabilidade Já jogo há muito tempo baixando diretamente pelo site e resolvi comprar aqui de tanto que gostei.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009501307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1227, 'last_played': 1680043751}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045381877', 'num_games_owned': 557, 'num_reviews': 2587, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1528502451}
review:
Maj'Eyal seems to me like a pretty great rogue-like and, at least in my opinion, is much closer to the classic rogue-like experience than most of the ''rogue-lite" games released nowadays. That being said Tales of Maj'Eyal will definitely not be for everyone. The games most casual mode still feels more "retro" than most modern rogue-like games, and the visuals leave something to be desired. Maj'Eyal is definitely more for the gamer who enjoys a variety of game mechanics running in a detailed procedurally generated world, over someone looking for a game that looks modern. 

The game has a large variety of races and classes and modes to chose from, plus mod support! This ensures that you will have tons of content and replayability something very important for, and a staple to this genre. If you are a fan of rogue-like games you very well may be a big fan of Tales of Maj'Eyal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120135745', 'num_games_owned': 1546, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 15008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6229, 'last_played': 1683378075}

author: {'steamid': '76561198367361512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 40456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15093, 'last_played': 1639757676}
review:
Play a game on Normal difficulty, have a bunch of fun dying a lot.

Eventually, you'll get used to it, and then you won't die. You'll go to Nightmare difficulty. You'll then die over and over and over and over.

Eventually, you'll get used to it, and then you won't die. You'll go to Insane difficulty. You'll never live past level 20 ever again.

Great game. 9/11, would die willingly again and again.

And yes, all of the deaths will be stupid and rage inducing. The graphics are terrible. Nothing makes sense for the first 100 hours you play the game. It's still great, because you can be a skeleton-time-travelling-archer-dual-wielding-swords and accidentally die to some machine-gun-wielding-poison-ivy-shrub-that-puts-you-to-sleep-after-teleporting-you-to-an-alternate-dimension-that's-filled-with-lava. Or you could be an ogre-dual-wielding-a-famous-troll's-tree-trunk-and-a-magic-staff and die to a sandworm-which-made-a-tunnel-to-hunt-you-down-underground-and-then-froze-you-and-the-tunnel-collapsed-and-you-don't-have-a-teleportation-rune-and-now-you're-suffocating-while-buried-alive. Or you'd just an archer that one-shots everything, and you shot an arrow at a corruptor, who then swapped places with you, diseased you and now you can't move, and your arrow hits you and you one-shot yourself.

Because that's just how things go when you're an idiot adventurer who thinks it's a good idea to wander around crypts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009352377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 9366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3864, 'last_played': 1642473478}
review:
Today I protected a village from raiding elemental forces, unlocked Eldritch technology from a long-dead society, raided snowy peaks populated by ice dragons, tore the heart out of a sandworm queen, and survived an onslaught of mutated creatures experimented on by a mad scientist. 

Hands down the best roguelike/RPG I've had the pleasure of playing in the last 10 or 15 years. Combine an incredibly smooth interface with great music, a huge number of items, numerous classes and abilities, interesting ability trees, rock solid lore, loads of unlockables, great tile art, and quick gameplay and you get Tales of Maj'Eyal. An awesome place for beginners interested in roguelikes and a great place for more experienced RPG players to try their hand at building a unique and viable character in a challenging environment. 

Can't recommend this highly enough.

update after 100+ hours: this the best game in my Steam library

author: {'steamid': '76561198004132377', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1194, 'last_played': 1676670170}
review:
This game has surprised me and I am now unsure how I will find the time to play it without sacrificing other recent great games !
Steam recently ran their 'Spring cleaning event' and it was one of the tasks of this event to play a game that was previously downloaded but not played for a long time.
I cannot even recall how/when I downloaded this game but according to the player profile webpage that all registered players receive I have had this game for over 2 years !!
I am stunned that I have not previously discovered the games immersive lore and quest plots coupled with the ever addictive nature of procedural loot drops.
As a veteran gamer the graphics do not give me any cause for concern at all.... it is the addictive gameplay that offers genuine opportunity for strategy and planning during dungeon runs.
Many games out there in this genre tend to be completely unforgiving with the use of RNG and procedural encounters and quckly destroy all your time spent efforts in one ridiculously overpowered encounter...this may help with the sales of keyboards and monitors after they get trashed but it is not my idea of fun.
ToME is also at times very unforgiving but as you quickly discover there is always opportunity to overcome seemingly unbeatable encounters once you delve into the incredibly deep skill/talent/stat trees.
There is a great community ingame constantly discussing builds and strategy... (no barrens chat witnessed)
The community is clearly a mature and helpful one.
There is also a discord channel as well as a player profile webpage that makes superb reading and analysis for the number crunchers and stat heads.
This game takes me back to one of my favourite games ever... Amberstar on the Amiga
Although both games are rather different in many ways the reason I make this association is that since Amberstar I have yet too find a game that has lit my RPG furnace fuelled by stats and progression and a genuine sense of achievment...
By discovering Tales of Maj' Eyal I think I have finally found that game I have yearned for so long !!
Unbelievable value and amazingly addictive !
Guaranteed to be cited in future divorce cases...probably mine

author: {'steamid': '76561198087455477', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 3939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3894, 'last_played': 1581370191}
review:
Warning! Addictive game. 

Tale of Maj'Eyal is a complex/hard/fun rogue-like game with:

- A lot of races with subraces and classes to unlock.
- Dual class & Multiclass. 
- Unique racial skills.
- Open World.
- Online chat.
- 1746  achievements.
- Replayability.
- Alternate starts.
- Cheap base game and DLCs.
- Updates every few weeks.
- Retro Graphics.


10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198080977663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 1406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1406, 'last_played': 1527495278}
review:
Un très bon RPG old school très complet.

Graphisme : 1/5. Bon par contre, c'est moche... Retour aux années 90.

Son : 4/5. Les bruitages sont pas géniaux mais les musiques sont de bonnes qualités.

Gameplay : 5/5 . Juste énorme. De très nombreuses classes, une quantité monstrueuse de capacités différentes, des stats dans tous les sens, un mode énorme, un background très riche... bref vous pouvez y passer des mois !

Rejouabilité : 5/5. Tellement de classe à tester, tellement de défis à relever....

Immersion : 2,5/5. J'ai eu du mal, tout est en anglais et pas forcément accessible pour les gens qui ont un petit niveau comme le miens. Pas de patch fr. Dommage (pour moi !).

Difficulté : 2,5/5. Le jeu est difficile, normal c'est un roguelike. Mais quand vous avez des heures de jeu dans les pattes avec un perso, et que vous vous trouvez dans une situation sans échappatoire.... plus qu'à serrer les dents et recommencer...depuis le début !

author: {'steamid': '76561198055440694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 153104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 295, 'playtime_at_review': 40698, 'last_played': 1712022127}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is one of the best roguelikes I have ever played. It frequently updates, and its classes are fun and interesting. 
Plus, if you're not so fond of permadeath or trying to understand a new class, there's an easier mode in which permadeath is disabled. Absolutely worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096037233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 54621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 726, 'playtime_at_review': 4041, 'last_played': 1712254664}
review:
TL;DR Buy it, it's fun, tons of classes and races, and gives an actual feeling of loss when a good run gets stomped to death by a boulder-throwing giant.

This isn't some review of the pros and cons of the game, but just an explanation of one experience I had with it that I think is not only worth sharing, but might convince at least a few people to get the game.

In my time with ToME, I've not gotten very far at all, never really made it even halfway through, but I had an experience today that made me feel like I [i] needed [/i] to write this. I was playing as a class that, in my experience, tends to exceptionally hard to kill, but not very strong. 

Being one of the Chronomancer classes, it uses Paradox, and I'll spare you most of the details, but know that if your Paradox gets too high, weird things (called anomalies, which can be minor or major) start happening, like summoning time elementals, teleporting you randomly, protecting you from harm, [b] summoning Dwarven lumberjacks to your aid, [/b] etc. etc.

Now, I was fighting a mini-boss in an otherwise empty level, and being my nigh-unkillable self, I was confident I'd win. This behemoth, though, kept healing and shielding and just being too hard to kill because of its own abilities. I wasn't going to just give up when it got tough, though, so I kept at it. Even once my Paradox started summoning time elementals, wormholes, and literal rifts in the spacetime continuum, through which all manner of nightmares flooded out. None of that could kill me at that point, so why just give up because they were there? Just fight around them!

Things got more and more chaotic as my Paradox was getting higher and higher, summoning more and more things, and both myself and the mini-boss were teleporting around both of my own volition, and because of the Anomalies my excessive Paradox was causing. This went on for a solid 35-45 minutes, a fight that seemed like it would never end, because both participants seemed to be unkillable. 

It felt like one of those horribly cliche bits of fantasy lore where two immortal gods are locked in an eternal battle, but where one god was RNG'd up by the game, and the other wasn't even halfway through the game. Without taking into account every possible build and playstyle, no game without RNG enemies is going to even have a chance of giving you that kind of battle.

Simply put, if you want a chance to be locked in a battle against a creation spawned from your own bad luck, in a battle that wouldn't end without giving up or fleeing, then buy Tales of Maj'Eyal.

P.S. That battle I had? I fled from the level. I have to go back to the [i] mini-boss fight of eternal anomalies [/i] later in this run (if I don't die).

author: {'steamid': '76561197996525805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 40364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16990, 'last_played': 1590960748}
review:
Probably one of the more approachable roguelikes, with a nice swathe of mods you can apply to tinker with the experience as you see fit.

Coming from more conventional experiences like Nethack and DCSS, ToME is kind of weird. You play actual classes that have, like, talent trees. You don't necessarily only have one life. There's an overarching plot, for better or worse, with a procession of quests you go through each time (unless you're playing one of the Other game modes).

That being said, the game does a rather good job with most of the classes in it. Each one, generally, does SOMETHING special, and certain and more powerful ones on runs that lucked into ideal gear can make you feel like an utter badass on even the highest (well, second-highest) difficulties. Have you ever played a turn-based, top-down single-character RPG and longed for the ability to spit deadly globules of ooze at people, while negating attacks by undergoing binary fission AND making friendly backup oozes at the same time?

No? Well, pretend you have. This game has that!

Overall, it's a roguelike that has some more conventional RPG elements layered on top, and it works out rather beautifully. The DLCs add worthwhile things, but even the base game's perfectly serviceable and gave me hours of enjoyment before I caved.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218303145', 'num_games_owned': 79, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 30813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1255, 'last_played': 1706067076}
