review: Out of all the rogue-likes I've had the pleasure of playing over the past two years this in MHO is the king. Amazing levels of customization, awesome stroy, unforgiving gameplay. if you're looking for your first or last roguelike this ... THIS is the GAME!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198119638825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 2650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1170, 'last_played': 1676846743}
review: This game is special. There are so many races and classes and builds that you can spend the rest of your life with this game and still find a new way to enjoy it, and that's without going into modding. The developer puts a lot of work into keeping the game updated and balanced, and if you're looking for a top-down dungeon crawler that feels like a single-player D&D experience, you won't have any regrets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035054806', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1427251766}
review: Pretty good dungeon grinder. Though the graphics are on the crude side. The character mechanics are rather good. I'd use a coupon, but it's worth buying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077792064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 5172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1699371189}
review:
Ein sehr sehr geiler Dungeoncrawler! Eingehüllt in einem richtig großen RPG-Umfeld mit unzähligen Equipmöglichkeiten, Epics, Legendaries, usw. . Bosskämpfe, Skillsystem, tolle Dungeons. Verschiedene Spielmodi mit mehreren Leben aber auch mit nur einem Leben. 
Habe diese Perle durch einen Aktionskauf für sage und schreibe nur 1,49€  erworben. Auch für paar Euros mehr ist dieses Spiel definitiv eine Kaufempfehlung. 
Ein sehr hoher Wiederspielfaktor durch Lernen und durch das Auswählen verschiedener Klassen. Bogenschütze? Wilder? verschiedene Magier? verschiedene Nahkämpfer? hier wird echt einiges geboten.
Frustration durch Tod? 
Egal, im nächsten Leben machen wir alles besser :D. 

11/10 würde mich wieder ins nächste Kampfgetümmel schmeissen!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968176907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1214, 'last_played': 1488483914}
review: Fantastic!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007423887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 11925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4945, 'last_played': 1531820536}
review:
After making a powerful Psionic Dwarf, I journeyed into the high mountains, slaughtering an entire tribe of storm giants along the way. Upon finding the Giants' cheiftan, we clashed in a massive struggle, neither gaining much advantage. Frozen, battered, bloody, and desparate to end it, I delivered a final headbutt (thanks to my iron helm) to the Giant and cracked his skull, killing him instantly. On the next turn, a huge boulder hurtled at me from behind an outcropping, flung by a survivor of the battle. I died on the spot, surrounded by a dead tribe of the slain.

11/10 - A GLORIOUS end to a heroic tale. Would gladly do it again and again.

BUY THIS GAME!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970861139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 40824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9253, 'last_played': 1706819793}
review: A fun roguelike, and more accessible than most.  There are a lot of interesting character options to unlock, plenty of flexibility on how to build each class, and a big, flavorful world to explore.  Plus, alternate game modes can be unlocked, like the arena and the infinite dungeon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048615656', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 25610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2856, 'last_played': 1666706921}
review:
I am probably not doing it right,playing on exploration mode with unlimited respec but... the game is challenging enough with an interesting combat, but so far I prefer infinite lives and just being careful not to die unnecessarily to the challenge of permadeath. The very fact that this, supposedly, roguelike, allows this, fills me with joy cause otherwise it'd definitely be too hardcore for me to continue playing past couple of first(miserable) runs.

The graphics are minimalistic but class diversity and meaningful loot more that make up for it. Unlocking and trying new stuff is definitely fun in here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161247786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3135, 'last_played': 1535132048}
review: Gaem is gud.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983672075', 'num_games_owned': 1442, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 114877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5807, 'last_played': 1688362168}
review:
This game is well worth the asking price.

[b]A "roguelike" game that is actually [i]Balanced!!![/i][/b]
Most devs think that's an oxymoron and use "roguelike" as an excuse to be lazy and put out a sub-standard product, but not the dev of this game. You're totally free to blunder into areas and enemies way out of your league and get horribly murdered, as I just did, but you can expect [i]most[/i] of the enemies in an area that are your level to be beat-able.

But even if you go to another starter area you might get swarmed and over-confidently die.
It's tough and challenging but with the right tactics, equipment, power selection, and a little luck you can make it fairly far and play for a while. Then you'll open a sealed door with an unspeakable horror too powerful for you on the other side and die, but be so amused and enjoy it so much you pick another class and try again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089652452', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 5576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5092, 'last_played': 1452995389}

First of all you will die a lot, the game is hard and one wrong move will kill you. But I really really like this game, You have to think about each move and if u just rush in you will die easily. The Graphics are minimalistic but do their job just fine. The Story is ok but the world in it self is very well thought out. But the best of all is The looting and the skill system which reminds me of Diablo 1 and 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019388822', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 5758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2373, 'last_played': 1460186831}

author: {'steamid': '76561197967060605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 10369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1480, 'last_played': 1689118724}
review:
This game is all the best parts of turn-based RPGs mixed with the nostalgia of the old sprite-based top-down roguelikes of old. I have been playing it pretty constantly for a couple days. It trends towards the hard side of difficulty (even on Normal) but it only serves to encourage me to try more stuff like the classes and class abilities you unlock for later characters.

Simply put, this will occupy my time for the foreseeable future!

author: {'steamid': '76561198145776265', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 25545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1553, 'last_played': 1566719279}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal (ToME) is a roguelike game that has been around in various forms for several years but until the more recent versions might have been a little too oldschool style for many modern gamers. I'm going to try to be unbiased in reviewing this game but it might be tough since I started playing when it was called Pernband.

Graphics: 3/5 The tiles in this game are very well done and for the most part, everything is pretty easy to identify. In some areas it may be hard to see a monster next to an obstacle but this may be by design. It also has ASCII mode for old school roguelike nerds like myself.

Sound: 3/5 Not horrible but not great. The music mostly fits the areas but some of the sound effects just sound wrong to me.

Difficulty: 5/5 Like most roguelikes, this game is not supposed to be easy. ToME does have adjustable difficulty levels to appeal to a broader audience. You can start with a set number of lives or go typical roguelike style permadeath. You can adjust your experience from casual gaming to pulling your hair out.

Gameplay 5/5: ToME is different than most roguelikes in that it has a somewhat open and explorable world as opposed to a single dungeon and maybe a town. The player starts in an area that depends on the characters race. These areas range from simple to brutal. The story is decent and there are plenty of other quests to occupy your time. This game is controlled by keyboard and/or mouse. This makes it easy for an experienced RL player or a novice to jump right in after the brief tutorial. The level generation is done well enough to make each playthrough feel unique and the battles require just the right amount of strategy to keep the game interesting. There are various unlocks that range from things you will do in a normal game to tedious quests.

Overall: 4/5 If you are an oldschool rogueliker, then you are probably already familiar with some version of ToME. If you are newer to the genre and want to play a difficult dungeon crawler with some exploration then this game is worth looking at.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966533518', 'num_games_owned': 1248, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1427157889}
review: Nope, just not my kind of game, I guess. Another opinion I'll be in the minority on, I'm sure, but this is just too dull for me. That's my vote, and I'm sticking to it. I think I really need to stop assuming I will be able to see past the bare minimal graphics of games such of this. I don't have the imagination to get any fun out of them. I can enjoy many retro console games even today, but the archaic PC game visuals and RPG gameplay style just bores the hell out of me. Uninspired. Now go ahead and downvote me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970792307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 5797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3553, 'last_played': 1504311461}
review:
This is an amazing game forget the new COD this 2d tile-based Roguelike is 1000 times deeper and more addictive. 

I'm currently playing a character whos skillbar contains: Teleportation mines, Wormholes, Teleportation , time travel,  archery, commanding a pack of hounds oh and splitting reality into three.  This is just one of many character types with wildly different abilities, skill tree choices and playstyles.

Being a real roguelike this is a difficult game but incredibly rewarding if  you invest the time in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994666064', 'num_games_owned': 3746, 'num_reviews': 611, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1426808418}
review:
Um jogo feio, porém muito profundo!

Indo direto ao ponto, esse é um jogo que deixa bem claro do que se trata e filtra imediatamente o seu público, ou seja, o povo ver as screenshots dele e logo pensa "Nossa, que gráfico mais feio!", isso descarta imediatamente aqueles que buscam por jogos apenas pelos gráficos, deixando assim os jogadores que vão além e buscam saber mais sobre a jogabilidade, e assim apresenta uma baita de uma experiência profunda no termo de RPG e mundo medieval, uma enorme quantidade de raças e classes que podem ser combinadas e formar os guerreiros mais esquisitos, para depois serem colocados em ambientes aleatórios. A quantidade de configurações que se pode fazer no jogo é imensa e o torna robusto demais, sendo assim aqueles que estão atrás de um RPG e querem algo com uma quantidade imensa de possibilidades, certamente vão se apaixonar por esse jogo. É como voltar aos tempos de RPG de mesa onde não se espera algo visual, mas sim intenso, e aqui você se vê em uma aventura onde existem surpresas constantemente. E assim, como os que vão analisar são os que se deixaram passar além da experiência gráfica, o público alvo do jogo é completamente bem definido, não é atoa que o jogo está marcado com opiniões "Majoritariamente positivas", realmente não é qualquer jogo da steam que consegue chegar a um nível desse nas análises. Enfim, se quiserem saber mais detalhes, fiz um texto detalhado aqui:

http://www.nerdmaldito.com/2015/03/tales-of-majeyal-um-roguelike-mais-do.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198043865189', 'num_games_owned': 881, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 17833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14685, 'last_played': 1682364525}

review: Perfect, been playing rogue-likes alot lately and this one is by far the best out of them all, Faster then Light and Binding of Isac included

author: {'steamid': '76561197983432651', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 2773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 861, 'last_played': 1503534474}
review: Dont get fooled by the LAME graphic and arts , this game will surprise you!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972654162', 'num_games_owned': 644, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 14606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4045, 'last_played': 1619358515}
review:
I can't recommend this game enough!  It's got full keyboard support, so you rarely need to touch the mouse which makes moving and navigating menus much faster. There's a ton of mods if you feel the out-of-the-box experience needs a little spice.

This game is a true rogelike where every move matters and every level is preparing you for the next. You'll study each death to consider how your next run will get you a little further. With each run you get a little further and a little better.  All along the way ToME is and unforgiving, yet fair game. This game is mind-candy, not eye-candy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093104528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1427051095}

author: {'steamid': '76561197995089520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 5489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1820, 'last_played': 1514578312}
review: I want my life back

author: {'steamid': '76561198046624424', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1516632879}
review: I cannot get past level five yet, but I will. I'm drinking my milk and soon I'll hit level 6! This game is harder than Darksouls and a better story. It seems really in depth so far and I love the turn based combat. It reminds me of old school rpg games from my youth; Ultima 4, the old SSI TSR games. I reccomend this game with all of my blackened heart! Play, PLAY IT NOW!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032050649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1710121891}
review:
ToME is pretty addictive: make a character, wander about, unlock secrets (quite a few unlockable races and classes), feel powerful, realize you aren't moments before your death becomes inevitable, and repeat.

I only have 20 hours invested, so my opinion is pretty limited. A game like this is usually epic in scale, but I can already tell I will get more than my money's worth out of ToME.

I already have memorable experiences like the time I was chasing a rogue down a hallway in a creepy ruins when suddenly the ruins dissapeared, replaced by the Plane of Fear; a vast sprawl of smouldering wastes and demonic hosts. Did I not see a portal? Is this a trick? Can I disbelieve? Sadly, Conan the Berzerker died moments after realizing he was screwed, but it was a Super Cool death and we are amused.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036138886', 'num_games_owned': 2800, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1426916143}
review:
So let me tell you about the last char I rolled.  He ran around the dungeons barefoot for a few hours, then I noticed a shiny gold chest in the corner of a dungeon, I thought maybe there'd be some shoes inside so I go to open it.  Four dudes and a monster that looks like ramen noodles pop out and have me surrounded, they gangrape me until I die.

How big was this chest I opened, that it could hold four dudes and a pack of ramen?

Anyways, pretty good roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013005714', 'num_games_owned': 6683, 'num_reviews': 632, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1543377314}
review:
要素超级丰富的老式RPG，基本就是鼠标点点点，而且还有自动探索功能。
在战斗玩法上简单，基本就是算数值，天赋系统当然也有，不过也是数值向的养成。
亮点是有各种物品，事件以及任务，这些都是随机出现并分配在随机地图里的。
这游戏适合那些喜欢刷刷刷的人，我看下面评论里有人玩了2000+小时，简直佩服。

麻雀虽小，但五脏俱全

author: {'steamid': '76561197994363082', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1428198845}
review:
This is like the Dwarf Fortress of single player turn based rougelikes.  So much has been poured into it's universe and lore, and that's just the offical main module for the game.  TLDR: Buying this game will be the best thing ever for your rougelike, turn based, strategic, leveling, rage inducing needs.

The world map is consistantly the same, but the dungeons and places are randomized classic rouge dungeons that have themes, leveled content, and many many trolly rougelike goodness waiting inside.

Skills and healing are on turn cooldowns in addition to costing mana/stamina to use, making the whole game really strategic.  The fact everything is turn based yet updates in an instant means the game plays at exactly the pace you can keep up with it.  If you are taking your time reading stats, the game won't do anything till you take action.  But if you pretty much just want to wander down a few hallways to that old room, a single click will instantly have the game "run" you over there, and if anything happens along the way (such as enemies coming into view) the game will stop and go back into "single turn" strategy mode.

Race and Class are seperate in character creation, and all play different enough that you'll be playing a totally different tactic, yet are based on the same stat and skill tree like system, so you'll know exactly how to figure out the new class.

Add in workshop support for many modded race/class/modules, the open nature of the modding, and the existing website's large community of players and creators, and you'll quickly see why this is one of the best things you will ever buy if you are even remotely interested in rouge-like games.

It's also sufficently rage inducing when you die.  Just a fair warning.  It does follow the rouge game logic of "learning by death", so don't become too attached to your characters.  Much rage, followed by "I really shouldn't have done X" moments.  You can start as the same character on death, and the gameworld has ways to get "lives", even in permadeath mode...so it's a tiny bit more forgiving then your usual rouge.  But only a tiny bit.

It should be noted you can play this for free (with some limitations) from the website of the game.  Paying for the game on steam gets you the "Donation" version, with all the limitations removed, same as donating through the site directly.  The steam version can log into an account made with the free version.  So if you are on the fence, give the free release a go for a few hours before coming back and buying the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991562490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1365, 'last_played': 1642797337}
review:
Simply put one of the better roguelikes out there, and a steal for the low price they're asking for it. You get quite complex mechanics, a decently sized world with tons of well written lore, constant updates and most importantly the game scratches that roguelike itch that makes you want to recreate a character and start a new playthrough just after you've been murdered in one of the thousand ways TOME will try to kill you.

It's great and you should feel bad if you don't own it yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991063713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1627053971}
review:
Es macht spaß, wirklich viel spaß.
Typischer Rougelike Dungeon Crawler. Erinnert mich sehr an ADOM, Nur ist es viel einsteigerfreundlicher und es scheint mir auch mehr tiefe zu besitzen. Das herumgehen ist anfangs schwierig weil man ständig von bäumen geblockt wird, aber man gewöhnt sich schnell dran. Die Steuerung funktioniert auch super, besonders die Gestures gefallen mir gut.
Grafik ist auch nett gemacht, jedes Ausrüstungstück, dass man anzieht wird am Charakter angezeigt was besonders hübsch aussiert.
Ich empfehle das Spiel jeden der mal Lust auf ein nettes Rouglike Spiel hat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997530348', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 23902, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2866, 'last_played': 1688446537}
review:
Honestly, some of the most fun I've had with a roguelike, can only name a few that I'd rank higher than it. Unlike most roguelikes, there's an overworld with towns, said overworld and said towns are not randomly generated, but have fixed layouts, only the dangerous areas that would loosely define as "dungeons" are random in layout. Each option feels quite different, and usually has a somewhat unique play style, with race choice as well as class. The game doesn't exactly feel unfair until mid to late levels when the adventure starts getting into ridiculous territory.

Visuals for something as lightweight as this and static sprites are quite nice, there's some 3D effects and 2D effects based on special abilities being used, the sprites are large and detailed enough to know what you're facing before you mouse over it.

Controls are fairly simple, opting for an action bar where you can slot all your different items/abilities, which may deter some of the hardcore players of roguelikes. There's also mouse support, and right clicking on your character or other things allows one to play mostly with the mouse if one prefers.

Sound is present, there's music for every area, sounds for different attacks and special abilities, nothing to really write home about, but it's not bad.

Game mechanics are fairly solid and scale up to the point of more or less halfling going toe to toe with kaiju god-slaying robot of death, though quite a few of the mechanics are not 100% intuitive, difficulty is pretty variable with lots of options. Achievements are a colossal pain in the arse though, as a result, as getting an achievement in one difficulty setting doesn't unlock it for any others, and a lot of the achievements have 12 variations or so based on difficulty settings. Will say that some randomly generated enemies can be impossible to kill, I had an issue with a named bone giant who was impossible to kill at the level cap with ridiculously strong abilities as a summoner.

The game also has a plot and rewards you for being a nice person or a total jerk as well. It's not super deep, but it's enjoyable.

The engine's moddable as well, I recall the official site having an eastern fantasy campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987130317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4870, 'last_played': 1601440729}
review:
One of the most addicting, in-depth, strategy filled games I've ever played. While I'm sure the game is mainly known to fans of roguelikes, in my opinion this game transcends that genre. It's not only one of the best, if not THE best, roguelikes I've ever played, Tales of Maj'Eyal is one of the best strategy, rpg, indie, and whatever other genres apply to the game, that I've ever played.

I randomly picked it up during a steam sale after seeing it mentioned around the internet so frequently and when I finally got around to giving it a try, I was instantly sucked in and addicted.

DarkGod has given me hours upon hours of fun for a measly $2....and he's still constantly adding new content! This is the first game I've ever written a review for in my 10+ years on steam and it's for a reason folks. I was/am blown away by this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067608332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3266, 'last_played': 1696685576}
review: There is something truely amazing about this game, from the amount of character creation to the in depth story and lore found throughout the game. Every class in unique in it's playstyle, every race adds a little something to that playstyle, the weapons and armour have enough stats for you to look at almost every peice you pick up to see if it is better than what you are wearing. I have to say that this gives you the most meaningful character progression that I've ever seen in any game. The key to success is paying attention to every enemy no matter how weak they seem at first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055362132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 43224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12491, 'last_played': 1696657416}
review: It may not be as good as DCSS (although it is better in some ways), but this is definitely the best roguelike on Steam

author: {'steamid': '76561198085050806', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1426709684}
review: I have only played a little bit of this game and from what I've played I have really enjoyed it. Granted, the graphics reminds me of games from windows 95. However, I am in love with the characterization and the way the game plays. Its a pretty old school type of rpg and there is nothing wrong with a game witht his kind of style. I picked it up on sale for $149 and I am grateful for that. Its a real deal but if you miss the sale that is going on then the $6.99 is still worth the game. I recommend this game to old school pc gamers cause this is right up their alley. It is a fun and intersting game and I think other people should play it as well.

review: I've been playing roguelikes since I was a kid, starting with Rogue and Nethack, and over the years, I always come back to them. Maj'Eyal is a TRUE roguelike in a genre filled with (cough Diablo) wannabes saturated with good graphics and not much else. It's what I wished roguelikes were like when I was a kid. I love all the content that exists for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085194075', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2740, 'last_played': 1572295067}
review: This game is weird, a good weird, the sort where you can call on aid from a future version of yourself, and where the demons have a space platform in orbit over the world. And that's just scratching the surface, there are a ton of different classes that can each play in very different ways, from killing people with the power of hatred to triple weilding swords by holding the third with your mind, to a summoner who can generate energy swords, and so on. My only real complaint with the game is that I haven't had time to play more of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069398579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 63477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4306, 'last_played': 1705365477}
review:
This is it. 

This is, in my opinion, the best roguelike on the market. ToME is an incredibly deep and strategic RPG/roguelike which takes place in an insanely lore-rich world of classic high fantasy. 

The game is strategic in that time moves in "turns", meaning time ceases to move between actions or movements. This allows you to carefully plan each action, rather than requiring twitch reflexes. If you want fast paced action, look elsewhere. Animation is minimal, yet the graphics are extemely charming, and convey quite clearly everything that is happening.

Character creation is rich, deep, and super flexible, albeit extremely complex. I've played the same class a million times, but the result is always different depending on how I lay out the stats and skill points, which is probably my favorite part. I am constantly finding fun and oddball builds which get a million times farther than I expect. If you like making characters for tabletop rpgs you'll love this shit.

The difficulty is pretty brutal, but it always feels fair. There are ways to turn this down for chickens, or up farther for masochists and vets. As you play, you get better at making characters and becoming better at survival. But there are a TON of things to unlock too. There are different classes, races, and starting items to unlock in addition to "campaigns", which are essentially different game modes. If you get bored of adventuring around the continent, turn on endless dungeon mode. Tired of that? Arena mode is a blast too. 

Basically, this game is insanely fun, super challenging (and therefore rewarding), and the world is written with a very tasteful degree of seriousness. Humor can be found in dialogue but it is subtle and never breaks the immersion (no memes thank the lord.)

If you enjoy roguelikes and don't have this game, do yourself a favor and cop it! If you like it, go get that dlc too. My best character so far has been a halfling doombringer. if that doesnt convince you I dont know wat will

author: {'steamid': '76561197992574717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 22882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1647923633}
review: Hell this game aint bad at all. But also, it's not great. There's a lot to do and it all works together pretty well but it's way fiddlier than a polished gem like Crawl, Sil, or Brogue. 3.5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198043355246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 22085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4428, 'last_played': 1680395649}
review: I bought this game after playing the free version and I was just blown away at the depth of this game. This game has grasped my attention more then any other game that I've played. The graphics and UI may be simple but the lore, quests, and random events are just amazing. I've managed to unlock some races, classes, and talent trees and still have a lot more to go. After 40+ hours on a dwarf bulwark I only managed to get to the far east and ended up dying in a orc den. If you enjoy rougelikes this a must. Can't beat the price for hours of replay value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131931712', 'num_games_owned': 1765, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1517699013}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040904362', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 16014, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7407, 'last_played': 1708915533}
review:
Has got to be in the top 3 best RPG/Roguelikes I have ever played! Hands down, truely a hidden GEM. Beware... DarkGod will have his just dues paid in blood (You will DIE.... alot) But still the game is so very simple and complex at the same time. You don't have to play with Perma-death if you don't want to. (I have tried all the modes) rouge-like (perma-death) is where the real challenege is. The story and lore is great, a bit of read at times. I'm sure for most who play, its no biggie. I really like that there is a global chat and network while your in game. It broadcasts when someone dies and how, or when someone gets an achievement. I have found a few tips and tricks just by reading some of what other peeps were saying.

Overall: 
ToME is great and a must have if your into rougelikes, and not a bad start if you want to try more of them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089299679', 'num_games_owned': 7216, 'num_reviews': 392, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1608566342}
review:
1370 Achievement. I cannot believe my eyes when i saw that. That's an insane amount of work needed to get all that.

Yes i have tested out the game and Yes It's great. 

It remind me of 20+ years ago when i roll the first dice with my friends in school for old school DND and Realm of Despire TXT base game that i use to play on my 486.

Fan of old day DND is in for a treat for this game. 
It may not have graphics but it's one that you will enjoy greatly.

Just one question to the developer though. Have you calculated how many estimated hour needed to get all that Achievments? Is it even possible?

Once again. Recommend to all old school RPG fans. You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053061950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 108000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57442, 'last_played': 1661816205}
review:
The game has been "improved" to the point where in the long run it no longer seems fun or worthwhile to me. In particular the old necromancer class was revamped but so were the necro based bosses who got 10 levels harder (at least) but there is no compensating way to level up to match them now. 

I can't possibly say I don't recommend it because I do if you are a masochist and have tons of free time to learn the game. It isn't too hard to pick up the basics (play roguelikes to find out what I mean) but the gotchyas will chase you for decades. That said, any game that can go a decade+ and keep itself moderately interesting can't be bad. Despite the reduction in fun for some people. 

On the one hand it is grand effort by an independent developer (surrounded by a pretty cool modding community and fans willing to pitch in to get things done) and its rich history as a descendant of rogue itself via Moria and Angband  into an evolving original tactical roguelike role playing game with tons and tons of lore is hard to dismiss just because bitter salt from losing to what seems like unfair odds yet one more time. On the other hand, of my friends I seem to be the only one who didn't find the brutal start too hard (or probably more likely too time consuming and tedious) to last long enough to have this final complaint of feeling that it has been over polished to the point of frustration. 

I will say this, if you get stuck, and you will. The chat community is pretty good about (eventually) helping you find answers and unsticking yourself. And if you dislike aspects of the game but love others you can mod the game pretty completely. (You can seriously break it with the amount of things you load at one time.) 

Bottomline this game is *not* for everyone. If you are willing to work at it you might find it highly enjoyable and you should go ahead and get it and all the dlcs for its really cheap price. (The price is really a way of paying DG, the dev a little back for his hard and continuing work.)  If on the other hand you hate dying and starting over and being frustrated by hundreds of gotchyas (and the occasional game busting bug - that gets squished but in the meantime ends your run) before you "win" a run then probably this isn't for you. 

I've played over a decade and have a couple handfuls of wins on Normal difficulty. (The difficulties go up to Insane and get progressively more unforgiving a long the way.)
****
The above is quite out of date. The game is a solid one, despite things I don't like in it. Everything I typed was true at the time and some of it still is. I did manage to do Necromancer ascendance and a few others on nightmare as well. I think the game for its cost is an amazing deal if you get 1/100th the time I have in it (don't let steam fool you it has been far longer than my listed hours.) I would call this a labor of love though I did vote for Terraria this year. The competition in that category for some reason didn't not include Tome. I expect at some point I will get back to it once more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169498775', 'num_games_owned': 2931, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 48835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13848, 'last_played': 1606403691}
review:
8.5 / 10

这几年来对独立游戏真是情有独钟，多年前玩Elona的时候就对这游戏感兴趣了，看来rogue like类的游戏对我是真有吸引力，虽然像某些大作也玩了不少，但始终只是通关一次就删除了（老滚5玩的久一点，毕竟mod太多花样），而TOME4光是职业解锁就花了我100+小时，还有技能解锁，各种build，以及大量增加可玩性的mod（如无尽之路），游戏的成就又多，算是认真玩的游戏里成就最多的了（某些喜加一除外）。

另外说下，不知道是服务器原因还是怎么回事，游戏中连接服务器有时候会莫名断开，一段时间后才能连上，这游戏的角色是可以上传的官网的，可能中国连国外服务器始终距离是硬伤，这个只能无奈了。

于2019-11-27编辑：1.6太香了！

review:
It's hard to recommend this game, in some ways, as people will either like it and spend far too much time on it or just not like the genre.

Anyone that likes roguelikes or their descendants (e.g. the Diablo series) should at least give it a try.  It's not a fancy game, but it has a lot of depth, a huge variety of classes, and a reasonable difficulty curve.

review:
Verdict: Ok game, for what it tries to be.

ToME is all about character-building and fantasy combat. It delivers well enough on the first account, with interesting choises and hard priorities. The combat soon becomes repetitive, but it's ok until it gets booring.

ToME does not deliver an enganging story, personalities or anything of interest beyond combat and character-building. Nor does it attempt to.

review: 毫无疑问这款游戏是一个经典的地牢探险类型的游戏，游戏中包含了各种种族以及职业，这样就使得同一职业不同种族由于天赋不同玩法也会不一样这就使得整个游戏的可玩性大大提高。玩家可以尝试不同的组合来进行游戏。值得一提的游戏本身除了难度上的选择外还提供了另外的3种模式可供选择就是玩家在探险的过程中可以复活的次数，分别可以选择可以使用不限复活次数、有限的复活次数以及仅有一次生命的模式这使得玩家可以选择较为休闲或者紧张的方式来探险。总之是一个耐玩的好游戏。

review:
Inside, inside your head you're wasting away.
Away right in front of my eyes,
You're scared, so weary and worn the fuck out.

Your burden is life.
It's made you weak and,
Shake in the knees.
This is not,
This is not you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972395003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1474857110}
review:
I have sort of conflicted feelings about Tales of Maj'Eyal. In short, if you judge it purely as a roguelike, I don't thing it don't hold up too well. Part of the reason I may think that may be my preference for NetHack influenced roguelikes, and my lack of familiarity or appreciation for Angband influenced or Ancient Domains of Mystery influenced rogelikes, but I am not sure how much Tales of Maj'Eyal's design is based on those games.

On the other hand, judged as a RPG Tales of Maj'Eyal does a lot of things right. It has a rather interesting tactical battle system, lots of different character creation options, many ways to tweak and customize your skills, any many items to find that offer a lot of tactical death. It's story, while perhaps presented in a way that relies too much on finding and reading lore text, is at least interesting and presents a few dark twists on the standard high fantasy setting. 

No mater how you judge it, the interface is great, mostly easy to use but able to do a lot, the battles are fast-pasted and fun, and it can be very addicting. The graphics are simple but more then functional enough for what they are, and there are enough interesting special effects and visual flare to make up for the more static sprites. The music is generic but memorable and sometimes can actually be pretty fantastic, even if it is more or less all part of free game music packs. 

I think that is all that really needs o be said, but here is some more detail about how I think about it as a roguelike:

The big problem with Tales of Maj'Eyal's design as a roguelike is simply that the game is too long, story heavy, and not random enough. There is variation in the loot you get and the monsters you face, but the over all world is basically set. Same world map, same town, same quests. The layout of a lot of the random zones are different but the basic themes of the zones are set, and each zone has a set rank for items, a set number of floors, a set list of enemies and possible bosses. Due to how the game is balanced and how enemies never respawn except in a few cases, it's basically required to repeat every zone and sidequest each run or you end up drastically underleveled very quickly, and due to each zone having fixed level requirements you can't even vary the order that much.  

Although you actually have multiple lives before dieing in the default mode, permadeath still is a problem and when it happens you have to start over from he start and go through the same old stuff you already saw again. There is a mode where you can simply have infinite lives, but I kind of wish there was some kind of middle ground, perhaps a way to start over with a new character but with a number of story events that carry over and alter the world. There is a unlock system that adds new races, classes, skill trees, and other things, and that helps, but it still only adds so much and may of the unlocks are obscure or tedious.

I also have a problem with a lot of the streamlining or elimination of a lot of roguelike staples potions and scrolls are gone, and instead characters can equip a number of infusions or runes that can be used over and over again but have a cooldown timer between uses (actually every skill and magic spell in Tales of Maj'Eyal uses cooldown timers, I am not really a fan of them but it works). Wands and other tools work in a similar way as well. This eliminates stockpiling of consumable items, but also eleminates the sort of careful rationing of your resources you need to worry about in other roguelikes.

It's only logical because of this that the whole item identification game is gone and no items have overall negative effects, eliminating the kind of risk vs reward of using items in a panic. Many people may not like needing to worry about identifying stuff but the feature exists in roguelikes for a reason, the same reason randomized levels exist, to make sure you can't just win with rote memorization, and so every action you take has to be done very carefuly. Roguelikes since the original Rogue have always been about exploration and experimentation and the whole idea with unknown items was a big factor in that. 

But again, despite all of these things I don't like about it as a roguelike, I still think it's a really good RPG. Maybe there isn't really that much of a difference, most roguelikes are basically RPGs after all, I just thought I would share my feelings on the subject.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970406584', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 44092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4196, 'last_played': 1702042289}
review:
Probably the most fun Roguelike out there, it's got a huge variety in classes and races, almost no two combos play the same, a huge variety in enemies and areas, and unlike a lot of roguelikes, there's more for "physical" classes to do than simply bump into enemies over and over, and you rarely die without having yourself to blame.

When you die, you can't blame the RNG, really only yourself for getting cocky or careless.

There are a few rough edges, sure, but the game is still getting balance upgrades and content additions even though it's already got more than a lot of games that cost ten times as much, and the developer and those helping him actually care about making the game fun.

I'd recommend this game for anyone who likes it when a game grinds their face in the dust, because it makes them look forward to returning the favour some day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044811904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 19773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9366, 'last_played': 1678388113}
review:
Absolutely great game, really brings alot to offer for a turn-based Rogue-like adventure.

Several of my favorite features include the ability to unlock different races/classes, depth and diversity of artifacts, and the satisfaction of clearing another dungeon dispite the boss and other traps held in store. These make playthroughs similar enough to not have to read every ability twice before even starting the character, yet different enough that finding a new artifact that you never have seen before in 50+ playthoughs gives great joy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997923979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 11955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4045, 'last_played': 1702511015}
review:
This game is the most rewarding roguelike I've played in quite some time.  It combines many beautifully nostalgic concepts from rpgs from the good old days.  Talents and "feats" and stats will all be very familiar to the bearded rpg appreciators and  can be picked up quickly by any newcomers that might happen upon this game.  All the traits and talents and character stats all have very in-depth write-ups when you mousover them, and since the game is true to the turn-based concept, you can truly play at your own pace.

This game comes closest to the feel of that old game I spent so many hours on back in the days of "shareware", Castle of the Winds.  I personally have been looking for a game that brought that wholesome turn-based, warm, fuzzy feeling in my gutty wuts for the better part of two decades, and it would seem that I have found exactly that.

There is some kind of patch/crack/thing that can unlock all the races and classes without having to earn them properly, but I haven't implemented it yet after however many hours I've played, and I don't think I'd enjoy the game more without having to earn the unlocks.  Get the DLC.

I can't recommend this game highly enough.  Pour in the hours.  Keep em coming.  Drink deep.  This is a gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051220038', 'num_games_owned': 789, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2618, 'last_played': 1695331609}

author: {'steamid': '76561198090700228', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2213, 'last_played': 1555251381}
review:
看了王老菊的视频才了解到这款游戏的，感觉还不错，价格也比较便宜。玩起来还是很带感的，虽然画面比不上一些其他的游戏，但是内容却是十分的丰富，真正玩下来几百个小时的游戏时间是绝对没问题的。
缺点也是画面看久了眼睛会比较花（也许是我眼睛不好吧）。总的来说是一款，对我这种第一次接触这种类型游戏的人来说还是很有趣的游戏。
好了我不多说了，我要去玩 妈个鸡哎呦的传说了。看过王老菊的大家来赞一下吧，233。

author: {'steamid': '76561198009656695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 3331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2076, 'last_played': 1681773851}
review:
[u]Awesome[/u] 
[AW-suh m] 

[i]adjective[/i]

1.
causing or inducing awe; inspiring an overwhelming feeling of reverence, admiration, or fear:
an awesome sight.

2.
exhibiting or marked by awe; showing reverence, admiration, or fear.

3.
Slang. very impressive:
[i]That new white convertible is totally awesome.[/i]

4. 
The most accurate descriptor for Tales of Maj'Eyal

--------------------------------

When it comes to Steam games, I'm a compulsive shopper. I buy anything and everything that tickles my fancy. About a quarter of my purchases are terrible, horrible mistakes (The Guild II, 7 Days to Die, etc.) that never get more than an hour's playtime before I uninstall them in disgust. I always regret buying those games, but that's the price of window shopping.

Then there are the games that are decent for a playthrough, maybe two, before I move on and forget about them. They tend to be solid games (Shadows of Mordor, Two Worlds II, Shadowrun, etc.) but nothing to write home about. They make up a good 65% of my library.

The last 10% are absolute masterpieces, that I will never tire of playing. I'm happy to say that ToME fits snugly into this category. I purchased it due to its aggregated review score and its resemblance to Dwarf Fortress, expecting that I'd get a week or two of enjoyment out of it before I got bored and moved on. Well, let me tell you, that is [b]not[/b] going to happen.

In a nutshell, I'd describe ToME as [b]a streamlined version of Dwarf Fortress adventure mode, with the emphasis shifted from proc-gen content to coherent and enjoyable adventures[/b]. Now, I know that some DF purists will be turned off by that description - after all, procedurally-generated worlds and histories are a big part of DF's appeal, aren't they? - but bear with me.

Whereas DF uses proc-gen to determine EVERYTHING, from cultures to the landmass to [url=mikaelisaksson.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/DF_Cheese.jpg]an individual's fascination with cheese[/url], ToME uses it sparingly. The world map, quests, and bosses stay relatively constant from playthrough to playthrough (though there are occasionally some small variations in the last category). This has allowed DarkGod (the one-man dev team behind ToME) to build an extremely long, complex, and open-ended plotline that will see players through 50 experience levels - and for the record, if you play roguelike mode, you'll have a hell of a time even breaking 20.

Where proc-gen is used, it is used very gracefully. All dungeons randomize their layouts (and to a lesser extent, their themes) for each new playthrough, and gear, with the notable exception of the rare, unique items, is also random. Minibosses, which randomly appear throughout dungeons after the initial quest has been completed, are all named, given a random race (anything from masses of worms to furry little Ewok slave-drivers), and given an arbitrary group of abilities. To put it simply, though the broad strokes of the game are fixed, the details of every run will be distinct and unique.

There`s one more aspect of the game that bears mentioning in reference to encouraging multiple playthroughs, and that`s character design. When you first start the game, approximately 75% of the classes, 50% of the races, and 66% of the game modes will be locked. Mind you, that still leaves you with something like 7 races and a dozen classes to choose from. As you complete certain events, various aspects of the game will be unlocked for future playthroughs. There`s nothing more exciting than unlocking a class encouraging an entirely new playstyle after a long, epic campaign.

Even within a single class, the room for freedom of choice is incredible. Every class has somewhere between 30-60 skills associated with it, each of which has five levels of expertise. In addition, you receive another 30 or so skills to choose from based on your race. Considering that even in a perfect playthrough, you`re only likely to get 160 skill points or so, you`ll never be wanting for new ideas for character builds. It bears mentioning that on top of all of this, there are ways to learn the skills of [i]other[/i] classes too.

I'm going to end this review with a quick pro/con list, since those are all the rage on Steam these days.

[b]PROS[/b]

-Nearly infinite replay value
-Strong RPG elements
-[b][u]Farscape references[/u][/b]. The world needs more Farscape.
-Moody, atmospheric music
-Incredibly detailed character creator
-Moddable
-Dedicated community and dev
-Lore-a-licious. If you like fictional worlds with a lot of backstory, you'll enjoy your time on Eyal.
-Surprisingly complex combat system, even for boring old sword-and-board builds
-No shortage of humour, without being a farce
-The option to play as a latex-clad Dwarven gimp with a wooden paddle

[b]CONS[/b]

-Most people will count the tile-based graphics as a con, though I find them pleasantly nostalgic
-Less complex than DF (pretty sure that applies to every game, though)
-The initial dungeons become old rather quickly for roguelike players, despite being randomized each time
-The randomized mini-bosses can occasionally feel a little unbalanced (in either direction)
-I can't play it 24/7

author: {'steamid': '76561198018528658', 'num_games_owned': 854, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1349, 'last_played': 1497297764}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal occupies a special place in my library among the best roguelike games that exist to date. When factoring in that this is made almost entirely by one person, the level of quality and detail on exhibit seems amazing. There are many unique classes, races, and items to use while the gameplay itself is random enough to stay interesting and rewards you enough to keep playing again and again.

[table equalcells=1]
	[tr]
		[th]🟦 What I like[/th]
		[th]🟥 What I dislike[/th]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]+ Immersive world, lots of class combinations and unlockables[/td]
		[td]- LOTS of inventory management required alongside the general tactical combat[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]+ Tons of dungeons and enemies[/td]
		[td]- You will die. A lot.[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]+ Cheap and deep[/td]
		[td]- Pixelated graphics may turn off some players[/td]
	[/tr]
[/table]

This game is hard to put down, and manages to just hit the sweet spot between difficult and rewarding combat. Make no mistake, while there are words on the screen at times, there's not much of a story or many boxes of text to work through - this project seems to be all about delivering on the gameplay experience, and manages to pull off a masterful example of roguelike ARPG games in the process.

[table]
	[tr]
		[td][b]Content/Replay[/b][/td]
		[td]High - This is one of those labor of love games, and the constant small changes and tweaks have largely served the game for the better, making it an easy standout in a genre flooded by products.[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td][b]Pass, Sale, Buy?[/b][/td]
		[td]Buy - Even with little interest in the genre, this is a great game.[/td]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td][b]Overall[/b][/td]
		[td]Score: 4.5 / 5.0 - Almost Perfect, but small quibbles, the lack of a coherent story, and some occasional issues stop this from being accessible and recommendable to everyone.[/td]
	[/tr]
[/table]

[table]
	[tr]
		[th]🖥️ System Specs[/th]
	[/tr]
	[tr]
		[td]Intel i5 3770k | NVIDIA GeForce GTX 980 | 16GB RAM | 1920 x 1080[/td]
	[/tr]
[/table]

[i]Updated: Formatting changes.[/i]

review: Ein simpel gestaltetes, aber sehr komplexes RPG/Roquelight. Die Story ist nicht umwerfend, aber das Kampf- und Itemsystem sind komplex, aufleveln macht Spaß und viele Klassen bieten eine Menge Spielzeit für wenig Geld.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993815421', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 10510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1279, 'last_played': 1681868415}
review:
TOME is basically a fantasy based roguelike with crazy deep character customization and story that you just wouldn’t expect from its simplistic interface and graphics.

So let me first start off by telling you where to download this for free. TE4.org.  Its missing a few features the steam client has but totally worth the price of free.  The game is made off of an open source game engine and is being pretty much devloped by a single dude. If you like it, like I did, then picking up the steam version is a great way to donate to the continued development of the game and get some extra in game swag.  I’ve been very surprised by this little gem and would recommend it to anyone that enjoys games like ftl, risk of rain and rpgs.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960652705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1422696553}
review:
Ok, I bought this game because of the positive feedbacks but wtf I just dont understand why people make them positive. wwttffff seriously how is it possible that so many people love this game that's impossible.

The game : respawn, move 1 square, die, respawn move 1 square die, respawn move 1 square die. And normaly you have max 3 lives, after this, your character is deleted. There is a mod hardcore with 1 life only and the mod infinite life but even the infinite life is useless. There is nothing to do in the game that's fuckign ridiculous. Like, if u make a dward you end up lv 7 and the next zone after this is lv 12 wtf. You can fight white/normal mobs but as soon as u cross a rare or unique one it fucking 1 shot you no stop, you ahve to die 1000 times moving 1 square at a time trying to find the exit.

The interface is very basic, some talent are useless (like we can dig to open ways but there is no secret rooms to find). You have to explore the world to unlock new class/race/cosmetics but you don'T want to do this. What you want to do is rage as loud as you can till you decide to go uninstall that fucking piece of crap useless wasting your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983858425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 6167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4839, 'last_played': 1699590448}
review:
I'm in a love/hate relationship with this game. I suppose that's the mark of an excellently crafted roguelike. Often when I die I'll want to exclaim how that was such bull puckey, that the game is unbalanced and it was totally unfair. That there wasn't any lesson I could have learned from dying that way. Yet somehow, I find I'm slowly getting an intuition about how to play the game. I play so that each time, I can get just a little bit further. That's the thing about roguelikes. They aren't about learning to play the game, and then playing it. You can't be said to know how to play the game until you've won.

For a game I've never gotten past the first third despite having played it for over 70 hours, I can't really claim that the sameyness keeps me from playing. I don't feel stuck or feel the need to consult strategy guides; the process of learning in ToME is rewarding. It'd be awesome if levels had more variety and the worldmap was randomized, but I don't think that would make it more replayable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994601982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 2322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2227, 'last_played': 1420553561}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018131933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 1347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1071, 'last_played': 1603484775}
review:
I waited a while before reviewing this game. I didn't want the "starting" excitement to overwhelm me.
After having played this game with several characters, I can say that every playthrough, I get more and more excited about this game. For me, this game is difficult and hardcore, I am not that experienced with rpg's but this game makes me want to be and every playthrough, I feel like I have learned new things.
For the first time, I carefully think about choices I make, what should I level up, how should I handle this enemy. For the first time, I take my time for every turn (usually with this kind of games, I rush through my turns as if it was real-time). The game makes me want to use my skills and intelligence and for me, this is a first-timer.

The funny thing is, I had this game marked as "Not Interested" originally, but came here by reading a review under another -not so good- game. That other game had much better graphics, but I don't care about graphics. On the other hand, because I had mostly been dissapointed by roguelikes with low-quality graphics (although TOME actually has relative good graphics for its genre) I had never looked at this game in detail. It was after that other review and seeing that people have actually spent a whole year in playtime on this game that I got interested.

That's sad... because this game is REALLY worth it. And it certainly is worth the price. I bought it at -30% and now I feel like they could easily charge 3x the price (and even more) and it would still be worth it. This game needs a commercial boost :-)

I am really enjoying this game, dying all the time and stuff like that. I prefer adventure-mode because I can die several times before it is game over, but I still don't want to die (like you could play through in exploration mode) so it still makes me try to play it roguelike (which is too hard for me at this time).

I also like how this game builds up unlocks: especially for me, being not that experienced, I like that in the beginning not all character types can be played and must be unlocked. It makes me build up my knowledge about the game and probably only when I am ready to learn about new types of character, they will be unlocked.

I wonder if I will stop buying other games on steam now for the next year because if I look at other people playing this game (2500 hours of playtime), it seems like I will never get bored with this game and will never need another game :-).

I think I can safely say that this game is for all kinds of RPG players: the beginners and the very experienced.

Buy it! Buy it now! :-)

Edit: I forgot to mention: it has a very very very good community. In game, you have chatrooms and when you have a question, you can ask it there and there's almost always someone who answers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995169868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2085, 'last_played': 1464491884}
review:
I have played this game long before it came out on steam and it has only been improved with time.  The creator "DarkGod" is constantly fixing issues and adding content.  I have had to delete the game in order not to get wrapped up for hours at a time.  Just seeing the desktop icon is like a beacon heralding tales of past victories and unbelievable random situations that may never happen again on another playthrough.  This game is well-suited to first time roguelike players as well as posing a challenge for seasoned vets.

Side note:  This game has been free for years through the developer's website and the option to donate was vailable.  This is one of those rare games where you WANT to donate to the creator because they deserve it and the game yields more hours of enjoyment than most.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993272875', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 21914, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1568, 'last_played': 1681099755}
review:
This game is extraordinarily addictive and well-made. It is a Roguelike, and as such revels in procedural generation, a difficulty curve with occasionally brutal unfairness, and permadeath (which is optional but encouraged). 

There are a huge number of unique classes that all feel different and special. Each subclass has access to an enourmous unique pool of skill branches and very few branches seem useless.

If you can enjoy the roguelike flavor at all, you can love this game. This game is going to be a favorite of mine for a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047571239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 41168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 926, 'playtime_at_review': 18305, 'last_played': 1712205731}
review:
I never played any Rouge or Rouge-like games before, and this game is _dangerouly_ addictive. Despite the linear questing and story line, each time I played it with the same race and same class, I experienced different ways to advance my character. Never was I using the same game play style in any instance I played thus far as it offers enough randomess to keep you playing for hours and hours. I only played two classes right now and I learn something new on each roll.


There is no more complex and fullfilling hardcore RPG game like this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058305818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1420375370}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971236263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 2974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2045, 'last_played': 1654867525}
review:
Une évaluation pour ce rogue like.... Difficile à faire...

Pourquoi ? Je pense qu'il s'agit d'un des meilleurs et un des plus difficiles. Ce jeu vous fera pester mais vous y reviendrez.

Quand vous commencerez à y jouer, vous verrez que de nombreuses races et classes ne seront qu'accessibles qu'après avoir effectués certaines choses dans le jeu. Je ne vous en dis pas plus pour vous laisser le soin de les découvrir.

Comment commence le jeu ?

Vous choisirez donc une race et une classe comme bon vous semble et l'aventure pourra commencer.

A vous de bien gérer votre équipement et vos talents afin de vivre le plus longtemps possible. J'adore le fameux Fog of War modifié par certains objets. Vous pourrez détruire les donjons à coups de pioche si le coeur vous en dit. 

Un plus aussi par rapport aux autres rogue like du moment est la communauté de joueurs. Vous serez en permanence connecté avec les autres joueurs. Vous pourrez discuter, montrer des objets, voir leurs réussites et aussi la mort de leurs personnages.

Un de mes meilleurs jeux de ma bibliothèque. A ne surtout pas rater.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988975932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 2349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1519, 'last_played': 1500847567}
review: This game is fantastic. Every single class I have tried has been incredibly interesting, and there are 27 classes in the game right now. The graphics are simple, yes, but they are very easy on the eyes. My only complaint is that some information is unintuitive and hidden, for example switching control between controllable characters takes a turn. That doesn't really make sense, and the game doesnt indicate it anywhere, you just have to figure these things out on your own. There are many little moments like that.  But nitpicking aside, this is one of the most interesting RPG's I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992091857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 18690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5493, 'last_played': 1650714254}
review:
Must... put.... down... mouse... long enough to sleep, eat.

This is by far one of the most addictiove games I have played in a log time. And it's hard, very hard.

Okay, so its a roguelike. But it has options to make it less unforgiving, up to a mode where you can just play en die and respawn untill you have enough. So, the casual player is catered to. Then there's a mode where you have limited lives - you can respawn, but only a few times. And of course the real roguelike - one life. Die, you're out of luck.

It's huge. I have been playing for hours and hours and so far have only made it to the 'second half' of the game twice. I am estimating that running a single game end-to-end will take you at least 4-6 hours. Though, I moght be a slowpoke - perhaps better, more experienced players can do it in a few hours less.

It's got possibilities. Like, there are so many ways to develop a character. So far I have been fiddling around with one class to see what get's me farther and farther into the game and that is working. You play, you die. Think, why did I die? Adapt in the next character.

It has a very smart way of lulling you into a false sense of security by allowing you to kill most critters on your path, then hit you from behind with some nasty rare radom boss.

There is mods out the various orifices too - enou8gh to adapt is to a format you like better.

Oh, I'd also like to add that there is a massive fanbase on the formums where the (I do believe it's one guy?) developer DarkGod hangs out too - and he actually posts, listens and helps out when you are in trouble.

Trust me - if you are into roguelikes or like fiddling around for aeons with character builds, this is something you want.
If you are not the masochistic type, it has ways of lettign you in gently and be much more forgiving.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982493025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 1458, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1701384254}

author: {'steamid': '76561198017710151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 10778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8543, 'last_played': 1678285178}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal. What can I say about Tales of Maj'Eyal... I don't trust ANYONE who tried but didn't like Tales of Maj'Eyal.

What can be said about this game? No, not a game. A poem. A playable poem written by one of gaming's best developers, DarkGod. Truly a masterpiece, with infinite replayability, amazing storyline and lore so deep that if an Eyal book was ever released I would buy it instantly.

For me, this is the best roguelike game to have ever graced my computer screen and one of the best games I have played in my life, perhaps even the best one overall.

Thank you, DarkGod, for making me a believer!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060527161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 76122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7820, 'last_played': 1697658365}
review:
NOTE: This review has been modified since posting. It was originally posted in January 2015 as ‘negative’, and is from March 2015 onwards rated as ‘positive.’ In addition, the content has been altered to reflect recent changes to the game.
First of all, know that this is not a ‘rogue-lite’. I have yet to see the final level, and there are others on the forums who have played for hundreds of hours and have yet to win the game. 
For the TL;DR people: The game is amazing, but completing it on normal difficulty will take hundreds of hours because the learning curve is steep, and end-game balance depends on creating the most powerful build you can – theory crafting is a must, and if you don’t, the game will become unwinnable 30 hours before you realize it. For the rest of us, read on.
ToME has 26 classes at the time of this writing, all of which feel and play very differently. Like most RPGs, skill points are gained upon leveling and can be used for both active and passive effects. The skills for each class are unique and allow players to develop their own playstyles, though generally each class has its own style of combat and a playstyle that rewards sticking to their class-specific strengths. Summoners draw hordes of creatures to overwhelm opponents, archmages channel elements to great effect over an area, and rogues set traps and use stealth to outmaneuver or outwit opponents. There are even more creative classes in here, like a time warden (or time mage) that specializes in temporal effects and paradoxes.
The world has tons of surprises and interesting levels/areas to explore, acceptable story and interaction (for an old-school roguelike) and though nothing ever changes, the vast variety of mechanics assured that the game did not get old for me after 100 hours of gameplay, and likely will not for another 100 hours.
But Tales of Maj’Eyal does have its problems. The first and perhaps least bothersome is a learning curve that feels more like a cliff than a slope.
The tutorial explains a little of the game's mechanics, but understanding is better gained by blundering through the world and slowly learning what each of the many confusing formulas and statistics mean, and how important they are to the core gameplay. It takes dedication to keep coming back when mountains of unknown skills and abilities assail you from every side, and through trial-and-error, learn to slowly overcome that mountain. Perseverance does pay off – I actually enjoyed the game very much once I crossed the barrier between hopeless bungler and still-hopeless-but-educated noob. 
The larger problem is that in order to win the game, the player’s character must be designed for perfection – built to optimal capacity with a full understanding of the many talents, stat formulas, status effects and saving throws present in the game engine. It’s not enough just to go with the most damage, or discover the best damage reduction, or center your build around strategic options – you must do all of these things, and do them with the dedication of a crazed League of Legends professional gunning for the gold.
This is where the game fell apart previously –it can become unwinnable very early on, and new players will never even know. They may even feel overpowered for a while, as they make one-strike KOs against hordes of enemies and pass tens of dungeons without a serious challenge in any of them. Rares, elites, and bosses fall without challenge - then suddenly, a belligerent abomination of a boss-class monstrosity strikes, and they find themselves hopelessly outmatched, their only recourse to grind for levels.
So they go to a new dungeon – and it happens again. Another new dungeon – wait, were the normals this hard before? And why can’t I use my spells? My abilities? Where did everyone go? And… how did I get one-shot by THAT? 
Players be warned: No matter how many lives you have, you can make a mistake in your character build early on and not realize that your character is doomed until late-game, when you have already invested thirty-or-more hours into their development. With permadeath, obviously, you may not live long enough to realize your character build is impossible to win with. But even with unlimited lives, you will eventually reach the point where the bosses are impossible, and no matter how well you fight, how clever your tactics, you have no option but to die – or quit. Before the 1.3.0 update, this meant that you must start the game over again from the beginning.
This is why my review changed from negative to positive. While limited and full-permadeath players will still have to deal with the intense frustrations of sub-optimal builds, there is hope for those playing with unlimited lives after the 1.3.0 update: Full talent re-spec is available at all times, so if you’ve created a build that seems sub-optimal to your playstyle or eventually becomes self-defeating, you can easily change your skills to accommodate your newfound knowledge or equipment. Be warned, however, that stat points and category points are still permanent, so consider playing a Cornac (+1 cat points) your first time and keeping some stat points in reserve for future use while you learn the ins and outs of your chosen class.
Also, be warned that there is no way to carry multiple save files for your character in this game. The game will save on entering and exiting a dungeon, as well as upon making most major decisions, and you will have to live with the consequences of your actions. 
So to recap: Tales of Maj'Eyal as it is an interesting game that supports a wide variety of skill sets and play styles, though impressive knowledge of the game mechanics that can only be acquired through vigilant study required to develop a successful playstyle. Full talent re-spec alleviates (but not eliminates) the steep learning curve, but if you like RPG roguelikes with unique classes and deep strategy, investing your time in this game will reward you with probably the best roguelike you’ve ever played. Just be prepared to invest heavily.
*Full disclosure here - I played the game on 'normal' difficulty for every playthrough. There is an easier difficulty that decreases the monsters' strength/abilities by 30%, but it does not give classes, races or achievements and so it does not appeal to those like me who want to feel they are accomplishing something while playing.
developer_response:
Hi, thanks for taking the time to do such a write-up, feedback is always good :)
To address some of the points more specifically:
[list]
[*] "Easy" difficulty mode only bars from achievements and those few unlocks tied to them. Most of the unlocks are not though.
[*] No way to do multiple saves is one of the defining features of Tales of Maj'Eyal, and roguelikes in general. Though I fully understand that this may not be for every player, but no game is :)
[*] If you have in mind specific scenarios where playing becomes impossible due to some choices, I would like if you could take some time to make a list on the forums. This is the kind of things I'd rather fix than let go stale
[*] Last but not least, this makes me realize that there is indeed a need for something else. What if in Exploration mode (infinite lives), full talents respec was always available ? This is a special mode designed for players that want to casually see the game / story so this would not impede on the most hardcore players.
[/list]
