author: {'steamid': '76561197980564223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 2567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1287, 'last_played': 1527056443}
review:
This game is a roguelike with a modern UI (ascii tileset available if you prefer) that gets rid of all the annoying aspects of roguelikes and leaves you free to do your best until you die or beat the game (though as of this review I have not beaten it so I don't know if gameplay ends or continues at that point).  

Some examples of things that have been annoying, but in this game are not: you can 'auto-explore' to make sure you haven't missed anything on a floor of a dungeon.   You can also use auto-explore to go from floor entrance to floor exit and vice-versa when navigating any floors you might have already cleared.  It can be played entirely using just the mouse (keystrokes are still available for most actions and mapped to keys by default but you can remap it all to whatever you want if you like).  You also unlock items that make inventory management easier, which you then will start with from 'birth' on future playthroughs once acquired (example: an item that you get early on during first playthrough which automatically picks up items in any tile that you run over, and anything auto picked up like this isn't counted against your weight allowance; you can take any item out and keep it in regular inventory)  You can use a "tag" feature to flag any item with whatever keyword(s) you type in, and the game will not sell/drop the item.  There are no cursed items.  All items are automatically identified once picked up.  You can "sell" items anywhere/anytime due to item spoken of above so "town runs" are not necessary for inventory management purposes.  There are HELPFUL tooltips for everything that you hover the mouse over.

There is a very well-done tutorial (accessible during character creation) which explains most aspects of the games' combat/magic system.  There is still a lot of detail left for you to explore/examine/ignore at your leisure/peril, but you're given a good gameplay explanation via the tutorial.  I feel it is worth mentioning and applauding, because unlike other roguelikes I could just start this one up and with the exception of 'dungeon order' (see end of review) I have not felt the need to seek help about gameplay from the internet yet.

You start the game with a couple of race choices, and a few more class choices (rough mix of melee and magic).  Through gameplay you unlock additional races and classes to choose from in future games.    There is a very high variety of loot, that can give you bonus abilities that are activatable or are used when you hit an enemy, or when you land a critical hit on an enemy (and even more than that that I haven't used yet, I've mostly played the 'melee' side of class choices).   

You get various ability/skill points per level to assign to 'class' and 'general' skill trees, and a couple stat points per level to assign to your stats like strength, willpower, magic, constitution, cunning, dexterity as well.   Abilties in the skill trees have level and skill point requirements before they can be used, but if you are the min/max type, what is unlocked/available to put points into depends on your stat points from base points and equipment modifies "at the time you kill the enemy that levels you up".  This means you can plan ahead and stack your strength skill at level up time by wearing a bunch of equipment with +str on it, if you are playing a mage class but want to put points into a strength ability without sacrificing permanent points, to a degree.

Dungeons don't respawn; therefore, "grinding" isn't a gameplay consideration.  Dungeons are randomized in layout/monster placement but the monster types within each dungeon are the same every playthrough.  The world map/overview seems to be the same each playthrough but it's a small part of the overall gameplay and after a few playthroughs it's nice to know where the dungeons are each time.

Overall this is a very fun roguelike game that has great replay value due to skill/class/race combinations and the enormous variety of loot drops.  


I've added some gameplay tips for dungeon order if you buy or are playing the game, below (credit not mine).

---

Based on the suggestion of someone else I've done the dungeons (after the tutorial and starting racial area dungeon) in roughly this order:

Trollmire 1-3, 4 if you are feeling strong for the final troll boss
Norgos, then Trollmire 4 if not done yet
Heart of the Gloom
Kor'pul
Arena
Scintillating Caves
Rhaloren
Lumberjack Village
Assassin Lord
Maze
Sandworm Lair
Ruined Dungeon/Golem Graveyard
Old Forest + Nur
Daikara
Urkis
Dreadfell

author: {'steamid': '76561198109436972', 'num_games_owned': 978, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1577983153}
review: A Rogue-like with Turn Based style and deep character customization. Best RPG Game i've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066586430', 'num_games_owned': 1016, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1577302311}
review:
Harsh, unforgiving, and addictive.

ToME is one of the few rogue-like RPGs that gets me frustrated over its unforgiving difficulty and harsh gameplay. And I love it because of it. The game gives a feeling of challenge and forces you to learn all of its mechanics and tricks. Fail to remember any and you will quickly lose all of your lives.

Did I mention that this game is a rogue-like? ToME is a game which has you create your own character picking one of the several races and classes. You can be a human warrior, an elven rogue, or even a halfling mage. The choice is yours. But don't get too attached to your character as they will very easily die. By default, your character is given only a few lives. Run out of them and it's game over. You either have to restart your character's entire story or make a new one. If perma-death or limited lives aren't your thing, there is an option to have infinite lives. But this removes a lot of the challenge in the game and you will not be able to get much of the game's NUMEROUS achievements.

While this game has very minimalistic graphics and mostly comprises of still images for characters and objects, it gives a very reminiscent feel of old rogue-like dungeon crawlers. The art-style is a very interesting one but might not appeal to all people. Overall, the game is very well design and made. It has the right amount of challenge and design put into it. The game even has its own lore set and a very interesting world to study and explore. And if you are worried about any lack of replayability, there is a ton of it. All of the dungeons are randomly generated. There are a wide variety of ways to play this game and interesting combinations of characters you can make. And the number of achievements will have completionists at their desks for days trying to get them all. If you feel that the game is lacking a certain something, this game does have Workshop support. So if you wish to make a Vampire race or even make one of the enemy races playable, then you can. This game is very open to mods and highly encourages it.

All in all, this is a very well-made game that will have on the edge of your seat as you try to keep your character alive. I recommend it to anyone who loves a good old fashioned dungeon crawler or anyone who is looking for something new in the swamp of games that is the Steam store.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012955961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1430453158}

author: {'steamid': '76561198109553978', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 2115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1053, 'last_played': 1452732807}
review: This game is alot of fun, its not graphics heavy. It is welll done. The storyline and plot are well thought out and interesting. The quests are nonlinear, you can go explore and choose what and where you wish to go. You get to choose which quests you want to do or not do. There are multiple endings. The game system is easy to learn and logical. I have found no glitches, lag or crashes. It has great replayablity.  There are assorted classes and skills and new classes open up as you play. There is an achievement list. Different levels of difficulty and hardcore death or not as you desire. There is minimal loading on world map and only a bit between areas in dungeons. It is a good solid game and well worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998167902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 36346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2028, 'last_played': 1683037436}
review:
I have played the game for about 300+ hours before it got to steam and I have yet to complete the main storyline! If you want a game with an easy-to-learn, hard-to-master, deep and complex skill/build/tactic combat, this is it. This is probably the only game where different classes are.. you know, different. You can pick a mage and make any kind of damage increase your mana instead of decreasing health and spam as many spells as possible to spend it faster than you gain it. You can pick a wyrmic and swallow the goddamned freaking troll boss whole! You can be a shadowblade and regularly attack 4 times faster than most foes while being invisible and redirecting any damage taken to a foe you particularly dislike. There are very complex classes and even among the most experienced players there is no single opinion on how to play overall and which combination is the best.

The game is free. You do not have to pay a dime for it if you download it from the homepage. Yet I highly encourage you to support the developer, he's very responsive and is trying very hard to improve the game in the way community wants.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991786093', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1558624708}

author: {'steamid': '76561198004368051', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 43328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 20, 'playtime_at_review': 27647, 'last_played': 1711827328}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is one of the bigger Roguelikes that along with Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup and Dwarf Fortress help set the standards for what makes a good Roguelike. 

Unlike the two other roguelikes listed above you'll find an actual story being played out along with Lore and Monster Details that really tell you about the world your character is playing in; while not getting in the way of in-game play. Game Mechanics are plentiful but they are spelled out and not hidden from the player. User Interface for the most part is easy to get into and use.

There are a couple of hurdles one will need to commit to however in order to play this game - like any Roguelike there is the overall Game Depth and Learning Curve and Tales of Maj'Eyal is no different. Character skills sort of level up similar to what you might find in an MMORPG or Diablo-like, but skills themselves are also much like their counterparts - not descriptive enough to tell you what they do and requiring you have to test them out or read up on them. 

For people coming from other Roguelikes, you may be thrown off by the sheer Tactical Nature of combat, Additionally it is worth noting that the game is meant to be played in Adventurer Mode - IE, Multiple Lives, not One. Lastly, the game is long - very long. A full run in the original Age of Ascendancy Campaign (The Main Vanilla Campaign that the game started with) from start to actual finish is probably going to be longer then most other Roguelikes bar a few.

All in all though, this is a very enjoyable game. Once you get past the couple tidbits that might hold you back or throw you off you'll likely have lots of fun playing with multiple races and classes in separate but distinct ways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044323597', 'num_games_owned': 11258, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 28667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10290, 'last_played': 1703710590}
review:
[b]9/10 - Un bon roguelike complet.[/b]

[u]Les + :[/u]
- De très longues heures de jeu pour un prix très attractif.
- De très nombreux éléments (classes, ennemis, objets, sorts, possibilités d'évolution du personnage…).
- Les développeurs semblent proches des joueurs (forum actif, courtes discussions in-game avec ceux connectés).
- Des enrichissements sont à attendre (nouvelles zones, races jouables…).
- En jouant connecté, de petits événements se produisent régulièrement (petits buffs, ouverture temporaire d’une zone...).
- Les add-ons de la communauté ajoutent du contenu supplémentaire.
- Des originalités intéressantes comme la zone "Sandworm Lair".
- Un programme stable : aucun crash ou freeze en près de 100 heures de jeu.
- Les classes de personnages demandent des tactiques très différentes. Cela accroît l'intérêt à recommencer une nouvelle partie pour les découvrir.

[u]Les - :[/u]
- Tout est en anglais. Pour lire les nombreux “Lores” (informations historiques, journaux d’aventuriers, poèmes, chansons…) dissimulés un peu partout et donc s’imprégner de l’atmosphère de cet univers, il est préférable de maîtriser un peu la langue de Shakespeare.
- Comme pour beaucoup de roguelikes, les graphismes ne sont pas la priorité. Ici, ils restent acceptables, mais basiques. Ils ne perturbent en rien la jouabilité et l'ambiance.
- Le monde étant très ouvert, il n’est pas rare d’entrer dans une zone avec des adversaires beaucoup trop puissants. Je pense au destin tragique de mon premier personnage (level 6) : une quête l’a amené à combattre un boss level 20 accompagné de créatures (élites ou rares) level 27.

[b]Ajout du 28/03/2014[/b]
Le jeu est très difficile à maîtriser surtout avec les rencontres que peut faire un pauvre level 10 (il n'est pas rare de croiser fatalement un ennemi ayant 15 à 20 levels de plus que celui de son personnage). Je joue en difficulté normale avec permadeath (une mort et c'est la fin de la partie) et je dois avouer que dépasser le niveau 15/16 avec un personnage est déjà, pour moi un petit défi. Je n'ose même pas penser aux difficultés plus ardues proposées.
En outre, il est actuellement extrêmement simple de leurrer le programme en trichant (je ne vais pas dire comment) sans avoir de compétences en informatique.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021782092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 13750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2040, 'last_played': 1634439620}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969244395', 'num_games_owned': 637, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5972, 'last_played': 1604100551}
review:
This is a great roguelike. It is more accessible to inexperienced players than most roguelikes. It has several difficulty settings, and characters can gain extra lives as they gain experience. In addition, you can always reallocate the last four talent points you have spent. As a result, players can be successful by experimenting in-game rather than finding the optimal build online. 

That's not to say the game is not difficult. Expect to die many times before winning. However, there are so many races and classes to try that the game never feels stale. Tired of going toe-to-toe with swarms of monsters as a sword-and-shield wielding Bulwark? Try altering the flow of time as a Paradox mage. A large number of classes, races, and talent categories are available to be unlocked as you play as well. Your character sheets will be uploaded to te4.org if you are logged in in-game, and you can search the repository for other players' characters. This is a great way to get some idea of how to play a class well if you don't want to go in completely blind.

Classes aren't particularly well-balanced, but you can be successful with any of them with enough experience playing. The difficulty can also feel a rather inconsistent throughout the game. Most enemies will be trivial to defeat, but then you might be rapidly taken down by a rare monster in a couple turns. Despite some short-comings, this is still an excellent game. If you're not convinced it is worth buying on Steam, it is available for free from the developer's web site minus some donator benefits and the convenience of being on Steam. The game is actively being worked on; I can't wait to see what new features and abilities are introduced in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968936717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3534, 'last_played': 1451031770}
review: Tales of Maj'Eyal (TOME for short) is a in turn based roguelike that at first glance is something many would pass over but it comes with an amazing amount of character customization, story and enjoyable difficulty. This game also has, at the time of this review, the most achievements of any game on Steam. There is also an explorer mode which allows you to enjoy the story, up to Insanity mode to maximize the pain. The Steam edition also has a connected community chat in game which allows you to share death messages or interesting finds to talk about. The community is wonderful, the developers also update the game with new features. If you are still unsure about the game you can download the game for free at the developers website. If you like it, consider picking this up on Steam and supporting the developers!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970801959', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1487641524}
review: Best approachable roguelike I've played in years. Doesn't jam permadeath down your throat, but after a few character deaths you'll get hooked into trying. Deep class trees and gear/skill customization.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047621671', 'num_games_owned': 159, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 18627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11435, 'last_played': 1710448428}
review:
Fun, Tactical, Varied, Challanging, and in depth. I have been looking for a RPG like this for a long time.
Not for the Faint of heart or Thought deprived person. You need time, patience, and a desire for building a legendary character. learning the tools, environments, and "infusions" takes a little getting used to, but all in all, I love this game.
9/10 if you know what you're getting into.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971320635', 'num_games_owned': 4983, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 2155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1004, 'last_played': 1455041715}

author: {'steamid': '76561198022246931', 'num_games_owned': 1134, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 23338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2910, 'last_played': 1707753656}
review: Best Roguelike I have ever played. It gets rid of some of the unnessesary junk like hunger and identifying items, but sacrifices none of the gameplay depth. It focuses on hardcore dungeon crawling action mixed with questing. Most of the classes are initially locked, and while I thought this sucked at first, looking back on things, it actually got me to try out classes I would have never tried otherwise. As it turns out, I actually liked those classes and had a fun time playing them. All the classes play entirely different from each other and have a wide variety of different skills to choose from. There are also many races to choose from, each with their own bonuses and unique skill tree. Thanks to the numerous skill and race choices, playthroughs of the same class can play quite differently.  The game is incredibly fleshed out in these respects, keeping each play fairly fresh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042604808', 'num_games_owned': 878, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 9730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1606167370}
review: Ah, an old favorite of mine. It's good that it's finally come to Steam. The easiest way to describe Tales of Maj'Eyal would be to say that it's a roguelike in the classical sense done right, but for every feature that serves only as a refinement of the genre, there are twenty genuinely original ideas that help this game become so much more than meets the eye. Like any game in the genre, you won't enjoy it at first. It'll phase between confusing and boring for a while, but when you get the hang of it and things pick up, you'll forget there ever was a world outside of Maj'Eyal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068711169', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 39512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10860, 'last_played': 1632762733}
review: Cool hard game, hardly finish it in 172 hours)

author: {'steamid': '76561198088103020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1416091109}
review:
A bit difficult at the start but very addictiing and fun to play! I think this one is one of the best roguelike-games here in Steam! And for those who want to class diversities, this game is for you as it holds a lot of different classes and different races that can be unlocked as you progress through the game.

What's more fun to this game is that you can choose modes which has permadeath and non-permadeath, meaning, you can choose either to explore the game or to challenge yourself! 

Buy it now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051322981', 'num_games_owned': 3807, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 2223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1125, 'last_played': 1688628383}
review:
职业的设定非常像《魔兽世界》，各种职业特色鲜明、打发均有不同，非常自由化的天赋设定，丰富的武器，值得让人一晚在万，而且本游戏有汉化Addon哦，大家去3DM找找下载就有了，无需打补丁。

非常非常耐玩，这几天《上古卷轴5》都放下了

author: {'steamid': '76561198023592763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 18907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11710, 'last_played': 1691038857}
review:
Massive amount of content. Tons of unlockables. Great character customization. Immensely strategic turn based combat. Retro graphics. Fans of classic games like Exile and Avernum will enjoy this game immensley. Permadeth mode best of all!

So after a year of playing and almost 200 hours put into the game, I feel secure adding some more comments about the game. I can say, hands down, that this game is AMAZING! There is an unbelievable amount of content and lore that only keeps growing due to an active modding community and DLC from Dark God. I'm still discovering new, unexplored, areas of the game. I haven't even unlocked all the character creation paths yet. Best of all is the difficulty of this game. Any boss encounter will prove to be a challange, every encounter will become one if you raise the difficulty at all. One word of warning, this game is ADDICTIVE. I literally haven't been able to put it down since the DLC was released. Each class feels completely different. The only true drawback of the game is it's UI. At times the interface can be difficult. Some actions, escpecially in the inventory, take to many key strokes to accomplish. The menu hot keys are oddly selected too. Item information is displayed in a pretty hard to look at format. It seems the game's interface was designed with the keyboard in mind and not the mouse. The item filters need to be more specific. Being able to view the items based on armor type or weapon class would be handy. The hotbars get pretty confusing torwards the end of the game, when your character starts having more abilities than theres convinient room on the hotbar. Two, or more, active hotbars could alleviate this a little. It definitely takes some getting used to to become adept at interfacing with the game efficiently. Overall though, I would give this game the highest marks on content, lore, gameplay, and challenge!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023003091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 2437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1406132143}
review: A lot of stuff to read in the first hour or so, but the gameplay is fun. The more you play and read/know about rules, items and the game in general, the better it gets. This is a tiny investment for a game that has the potential to outlast many other roguelikes I've acquired on Steam (look at my games inventory to know which titles I refer to). If you're looking for a roguelike, prefer this over the others. It's definitely the deepest of them with actual RPG rules, not just shallow click-fest rules.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971135177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 5638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1932, 'last_played': 1703897788}
review:
The best, and most varied rogue-like I've played.

The gameplay changes between classes, combined with the unlocking of new races and classes up the replay value immensely.

I love not having consumables in this game; too often consumables in my games turn into a collection that I never touch, unless absolutely needed. In ToME4, the only consumables are some quest rewards that bestow permanent bonuses on your character.

The default adventure mode is a great mix of allowing some mistakes while keeping the fear and excitement of life or death common to rogue-like games.

Muti-platform support combined with an awesome, active, open-source developer puts it over the top.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095449935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1406792787}
review:
I've always been a fan of roguelikes, and Tales of Maj'Eyal is a steal at 7 bucks. Even better with a sale.
Simple to play, hard to master; the classic roguelike formula with a modern twist.
I only wish some of the maps were larger. XD

author: {'steamid': '76561197966966254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1537815752}
review:
Great game. I purchased it because it's cheap and to pass the time till some games I'm waiting for come out, and I am completely addicted.

The value for what you are paying is huge. If you are, or ever have been a fan of Roguelike games you MUST have this game. It is very deep, but is newb friendly. You do NOT need to know the details of the game in order to get started or to enjoy it.

I'm glad Steam picked this up, I wouldn't have found it otherwise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996866336', 'num_games_owned': 1934, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 8816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2085, 'last_played': 1704098993}
review: I played this for 12 hours straight last night.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008758688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1577595968}
review:
A very fun and very accessible rogue-like, loaded with content and numerous class/race/item unlockables you earn just by playing.  Has a large number of races and classes that all feel different from one another, different difficulty settings (how many lives you get) and unlockable bonus campaigns (such as an endless dungeon and arena).  The game is free on their site, but buying or donating gets you a few extra perks, such as transferring items between characters, a dwarf-only class (Stone Warden) and an infinite lives mode.

The game doesn't hide anything from the player, so you'll know exactly what each stat point and skill does, what every piece of equipment will do for you, and exactly how strong each enemy is.  It's not gonna stop a wayward lightning bolt from ruining your run, though!

I already put dozens of hours into it before buying it, and have already put 2 dozen in since.  Wholeheartedly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001937013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1698674158}
review:
A great Roguelike that makes it easy to get into the genre

Just like Dungeons of Dreadmore of SWOTS: The Pit, this game eases you into the idea of a Roguelike gently so that you can try it out without it being quite as brutal as, say, Nethack or DoomRL. The graphics are not a selling point in this title, but the gameplay should be. With tons of unlocks, lots of ways to stat and build characters, castes and quests to choose that will vary gameplay widely, and a big variety of enemies, if you've never gotten into a RL before but would like to try, get this.

If you're like me and more experienced in the genre, I still recommend it as this does some interesting things with the forumula--the capacity for kind of rogue-like not-quite-permadeath; the ability to (for example) forswear all arcane magic in exchange for joining a new faction of the game and learning magic-disrupting powers; the fact that one school of magic is powered mostly by paradox (and you can meet and kill yourself! ?.?) means that this is much more in-depth a game than the RLs of the 90s. Sure, you can pick this up free on the developer's website, but you should pay for it (here or there) just to support the effort. 

8.5 out of 10--which back in the old days on PC Gamer, meant that this is a classic well worth your time. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197991706883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 2530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2313, 'last_played': 1484406578}
review: Probably the best roguelike ever. Tons of classes, tons of loot, tons of quest... and astonishing amount of content and fun for such a low price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007449787', 'num_games_owned': 2309, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 8278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2528, 'last_played': 1604214891}
review:
I still have fond memories of Omega and Nethack and Moria and Angband and Cthangband and Pangband. And this one is better than all of them.
Plus there's music and sprites (if you want them) and achievements and randomish online events and unlockable races and classes to give it a sense of progression.
I can't say enough how great this thing is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974826346', 'num_games_owned': 1016, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 13558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1156, 'last_played': 1668381883}
review: I only just recently discovered this game, thanks to it being introduced to Steam, and my only regret is it taking me this long to find it. If the idea of the old Rogue/Nethack mixed with a little more RPG and the tiniest dash of MMORPG appeals to you, I highly suggest checking this out. You can try it for free from DarkGod's website (just search for tome of mag'eyal on google, and it should be the first link). Being a Steam addict, I'm glad it is available here however (I might not have discovered it otherwise). I enjoyed it so much after the first 6 hours, I donated 20 Euros on the website. I've already seen enough of this game to know I well get AT LEAST that much enjoyment. Obviously DarkGod believes in his game as well, otherwise it wouldn't be free to try as much as you like. I like that attitude in a game developer, and I hope everyone who finds enjoyment in the game feels it is worth rewarding as much as I do. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198035267196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1698808840}
review: A really impressive turn based roguelike with randomly generated quests, maps, and just about everything else. I have yet to dig more deeply into this game but I can tell its very good and has a whole lot of depth to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971321823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 18102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1423, 'last_played': 1685484190}
review:
I've been playing this game in its various incarnations since it was PernAngband in the 1990s, then Troubles of MIddle Earth, and now finally Tales of Maj'Eyal - free from copyright infringement and better than ever!

It's truly exceptional, and these days, comes with so many lovely enhancements that Roguelikes have traditionally lacked. Mouse control, skill hotkeys, unlockables and stat tracking, and global chat with other playters, MMO-style, in the game window.

Underneath all this is a game system that is elegant, varied, and will keep you occupied for hours upon hours upon hours. Each character plays differently and has a host of interesting skill trees to work through. The dungeons are randomly generated, of course, but within some boundaries that ensure that each has its own flavour and unique style.

Death is permanent, as with all roguelikes (although there is another little helping hand in "Adventure" mode which gives you a few extra lives to play with) but whenever I lose a character it's never a crushing blow - because now I get to enjoy starting over with a brand new one.

You can download this game for free from te4.org but it's well worth a fiver to support DarkGod and help him keep updating this brilliant title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045582308', 'num_games_owned': 751, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 4476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1067, 'last_played': 1481129487}
review:
If you're one of those people who believe their RPGs are not difficult until permadeath is included: This game is for you! :)

Tome (the core game's name, Tales of Maj'Eyal is the story arc included) plays out like a skill-based version of our old friend NetHack, minus the bloat and with deep character building (not to mention MODS <3).

If you've played NetHack or Dungeons of Dredmor, or games of that style, the gameplay should be of little surprise to you.
You fight on a grid, turn by turn taking down your enemies while snatching up all of the loot you see.

The beautiful part is, the developers seem to have known exactly where to change staples of the series and where to keep things.

For example, you have the Chest of Transmutation, which is where all of your loot goes into. Anything in the chest doesn't affect your encumberance until you take it out of it, and anything you keep in the chest when you transition between maps is transmuted into currency (don't worry, you are given a prompt to move anything you need on transition).
This keeps the inner loot whore in us all satisfied with grabbing everything, while also helping to keep the trash loot out of our inventories.

Little things like this make this game have all the fun of the roguelike genre without the busywork that just isn't fun at the end of the day.

With a -ton- of classes, plus steam workshop support, if you're into these kinds of games, you have no reason to not pick Tome up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004285507', 'num_games_owned': 1203, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 2918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1703314622}
review:
This game is a time sink, let alone.
Loads and loads of class combinations that you will eventually unlock as you play. 
Complete  control over the keyboard,old style. 
It's story / quest driven, depending on the class you pick, with random generated maps / dungeons. 
Nice clean interface as well. 
Well made descriptions for all items. 
Very active community and development. 
There is a free version as well, that you can pick and play. 
It has the "one more turn" and "what if" factors that keep you going, 
although the "main" campaign it's the only campaign there is. 
I hope community and developer add more mayor campaigns to the game 
(by the way, if you are so bad playing this game as  I am, it can take you forever the main campaign, 
but there is a "explorer" mode that is for dummies like me / Although I refuse to use it)

author: {'steamid': '76561198018466482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1389798592}
review: Interesting single player roguelike with global chat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073765481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1507136107}
review:
If you like Nethack, Angband and similar games, give ToME a go. The game is a roguelike with nice variety to races, classes and game mechanics, which you unlock as you discover and achieve new things in the world. Combat can be quite intense, with every turn and decision in a tough situation really making a difference, and lots of actions to choose from. The UI is mostly clear and easy to use with mouseover tooltips for everything that matters, there's a good tutorial to get you started, and the game also has some usability/playability improvements over other rogulikes, one of them being auto-exploring the current map until something interesting is spotted (or a ladder to the next level reached when everything else is explored). There's quite an active community pushing out addons, and the game itself is actively updated as well.

ToME can be played for free by downloading it from te4.org. Buying on Steam gives you Steam e-weenie growth (achievements), Workshop (not required for addons, but handy) and some features like the stone warden class. Also supports the developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044716919', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1563, 'last_played': 1603333268}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031234916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1402636467}
review: best. rpg. ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061542924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1400501931}
review: Fan of old school pen and paper rpgs?  Love turn based strategy?  Tales of Maj'Eyal has it all and more.  This game is not played for the graphics and therefore do not play a role in my review at all.   Tales of Maj'Eyal is very in depth and unforgiving turn based rpg, that offers tons of character customisation and replayibility.  Tons of classes and levels, to the point I find myself playing for hours.  Tales of Maj'Eyal also has a very active and friendly community with new updates and mods being added at a frantic pace.  Worth every penny, buy it, add me, let's play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968672499', 'num_games_owned': 1964, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 11589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8223, 'last_played': 1705302864}
review:
This game is amazing, I have put 137 hours into this game and still have yet to get bored with it.  There are NUMEROUS race and class combinations, just about every class has incredibly unique gameplay that differs drastically from others.

You got skill trees, you got stats, you got leveling, you got loot. 

This is EVERYTHING a good roguelike should be and NO ASCII art!

The story... well it's not bad by any means but it certainly won't be the reason you are playing.  You will be playing TOME because of how incredibly addicting it is and how wonderful the gameplay is.

If you like Roguelikes, or even RPG's in general, I HIGHLY recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063796400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 39299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11810, 'last_played': 1546319275}
review:
Have you ever bought a game you were unsure about, & quickly found yourself with buyer's remorse?  Yeah, we've all been there before.  Anyway, this game was the exact opposite of that.  Not too long after I purchased ToME on steam, I learned that there's a free version you can get from the website, & that what you see here is a 'premium' version that's also availble to donators.  Meanwhile, I don't regret a single penny I spent here.  

I'm somewhat new to roguelikes, & more preferred the fluff of swords & sorcery.  What you've got here is a graphically simple single-player turn-based tactics-style rpg.  Different modes include one life, multiple lives based on level, & infinite lives to learn how to play.    Certain features are unlocked with different achievements, including specific classes, races, &, oddly enough, redheads.  Every class I've tried has been a new experience, promotes a different style of play, &, most importantly, has been fun.

The support is amazing; every issue or bug I've faced has been addressed, worked on, & fixed in less time than it takes for me to get ahold of a real person on most customer support lines.  The player base is helpful with in-game questions.  Oh, & the game's creator has a fun habit of giving out random buffs or extra dungeons to everyone online when he's feeling squirrelly.

Overall, I'd have to say this has been one of the most satisfying game purchases I've made on steam,  or anywhere, for that matter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048717321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 19426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6720, 'last_played': 1629214930}
review: One of the best Rogue-Like,RPG game.If you didn't play this game you need too play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041361835', 'num_games_owned': 600, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 35627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3469, 'last_played': 1685569186}
review:
I've only had this game for a few days, and it is utterly enthralling and fantastic so far. I've truly been blown away by the quality of the experience ToME offers, as you can see by the crazy amount of time I've spent after only a few days of owning it.

ToME manages to stay incredibly faithful to the roguelike genre, offering the big three parts (turn based gameplay, randomized maps, and permanent death) but providing it in a way much more relevant to today's gamers; there are varying levels of difficulty, allowing you to play with extra lives or turn off permadeath (at the cost of not being able to earn achievements or upload your character to the server to show off) and it comes pre-loaded with a beautiful graphics pack so you needn't play in ASCII if you'd rather not.

The amount of content in the game is fantastic and the randomization handled well to provide excellent replayability and a truly enjoyable experience; it can also be tuned to provide that insanely grueling challenge that Rogue and Dwarf Fortress survivors like to call "Fun."

If you're a fan of the genre at all (or have been interested in the past and have been turned off by some of the more hardcore features), I find myself unable to provide eloquent enough words to praise this game's virtues- get it! One of the best games I've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025300870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1497628661}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047884970', 'num_games_owned': 5719, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 4763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 941, 'last_played': 1482098397}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960696798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 13481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1894, 'last_played': 1632192980}
review: A very good traditional-style roguelike.  Its free if you don't get it through steam so there is no reason not to try it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997754810', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1688157405}
review:
TOME (aka Tales of Maj'Eyal aka Tales of Middle Earth aka PernAngband) is ye olde roguelike that moved out of its' parents' basement and into it's own two-bedroom in the 'burbs. It has graphics. It has an intuitive interface. It has friendly people in an integrated chat system (which, I'll admit, surprised me the most.) I've been playing Pern since it was released all those years ago on Thangorodrim and I'll keep playing this, the best incarnation of all the Angband clones and, to my knowledge, the only one of them to move out of their parents' basement.

Congratulations Dark God. You made it, buddy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007497106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1604781758}
review: One of the best roguelikes i've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044715229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1334, 'last_played': 1403374105}
review:
After 20+ hours on this game, I still haven't managed to get through all the second set of dungeons.
This game is brutally hard...but every time you die, you realize it typically is because of your own incapability, or cockiness that gets you there.

And that is what makes this such a great game.  So many options for building a character, and a lot of crazy ways to die.  They most likely will come from you just trying to explore the game world and stumbling upon something you had no business messing with at the time.  

Every single time I've died, it just makes me more revved up to try to beat it my next go around.
If you're a bit of a masochist, and love rogue-likes, you gotta give this game a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198000678121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1710814157}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971689544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1610, 'last_played': 1589167584}
review: This game is fantastic if you are into roguelikes and/or old school RPGs. I'm somewhat OCD about saving all consumables in games like this, to the point that I never end up using them, so I LOVE the fact that they don't exist in ToME! Instead you get limited scroll/potion slots (infusions) that function the same, but work of a cooldown and therefore don't make me feel guilty at all for using them. Many parts of the game have reveal similar attention to removing non-fun parts of the genre without resorting to over-simplifying it (or indeed simplifying at all, this is still quite a complex game!), such as the fact that when you begin you still have the similar loot/encumbrance/return-to-town-to-sell cycle, but before too long you get an account-wide unlockable item to instantly sell anything that you pick up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120755955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 26863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1456271155}
review: A great next step beyond the older generations of TOME.  Monstrously complicated to figure out but I think this will be the rogue-like of choice for quite some time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005767569', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 359, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1574471612}
review:
Very deep yet easily accessable turnbased roguelike. With a butt-load of options, settings, mods, GUIs, this game is perfect for jumping into and easy to stay in. And with different races and classes to unlock, over a thousand items, armor, weapons, achievements, on top of the lore and stories that Maj' Eyal can tell. What more could you ask for?

People Who'd Like This Game: RPG/Roguelike Fans
Why?: Great interface that is fully customizable with hotbars and maps, deep character building and number padding, but not too much as to overwhelm.

People Who'd Hate This Game: Simple-Minded RPG/Button Masher Fans
Why?: Can be confusing to understand what you are looking at if you aren't a fan of RPG's, or would prefer being dropped into the action/powerfulness that you would be too bored/confused to do alone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007664202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 12206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 998, 'last_played': 1579794114}
review:
A really solid game. Turnbased roguelike style RPG, random loot, somewhat random monsters and a slew of classes and races to play around with. Also you can get it free here http://te4.org/download and carry over any progress to the steam version if you choose to buy it later.

You can choose if you want to play with a single life, multiple lives (getting more as you level) or infinite lives (if you're a chump). It's easy enough to die if you're not sure what you're doing or get in over your head but most deaths feel fair, with the rare RNG reaming thrown in.

There's a fair few classes to choose from (easily 20-25), ranging from your typical sword and board fighter or fireball slinging mage to disease spewing filthmancers or combination time-mage fighters, though many of the more interesting classes need to be unlocked. A bit of exploring will get you most classes, with some being a bit harder to find. There's also 8 or so races, each with their own advantages and disadvantages, and it's easy to bounce back from each death with a new character or a new build in mind.

This game's a great timesink, it's easy to get into and do decently well without knowing half of what anything means or does and the developer's very active, with new updates being fairly frequent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027592215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 11903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6779, 'last_played': 1698960653}
review:
Fun, challenging and it keeps me coming back for more. I have put more time into this game that I would have ever expected. I actually heard about this game a while ago when it was based in Middle Earth but I never gave it a chance. I missed out. I finally decided to try the free version and I loved it and figured I'd buy it on steam.

For starters, this game is HARD. If you have never played a roguelike before this is at least more inviting with decent graphics, but it packs all of the challenge. In a roguelike, if you die you stay dead. However, there is a more forgiving adventure mode, and even an unlimited lives exploration mode. In my opinion, exploration mode should be ignored. You need to learn to value your character and every move it makes, and being able to die over and over spoils that.

The main campaign is long and hard. It has a level cap of 50 which will just barely be reached by some races, and not hit by others due to experience penalties. Don't worry though, those races bring great bonuses along with the penalties. You can be a Yeek, a little while furry creature, and summon other yeeks or move faster than one turn allows. You can be a more traditional elf, summoning trees to your aid, or a dwarf that gains bonuses from hoarding his cash.

How hard is the campaign? You might die on your first map. You might die to your first enemy, if you're unlucky or unskilled. However, you will get better. Of the starting classes, the berserker has the ability to fight all the way to the end and survive, while learning the ins and outs of the game. The alchemist is much more fragile, but can summon a golem to aid him; it's nice to have a friend along for the tough journey. New classes, races and categories are unlocked by accomplishing various goals, from killing a certain boss to dealing one million fire damage.

There are abundant side quests, and they offer much needed bonus experience and items. The game has a randomized loot system and powerful uniques, like many modern RPGs. The skill system is deep and rewarding. You will think hard about how to distribute each precious point, and when you die you will look back at where you went wrong and how you can correct it for the next run.

My first character was a Higher (noble/special human) alchemist, and I died on the second zone that I entered. The enemies were higher level than I was, and it was just the wrong place to be in. Second I tried a Cornac (common human) berserker, and died in the game's final battle. That was a painful loss, but I went back to the drawing board and came in with a Wyrmic; a dragon-based character with the power of nature on his side. This time I made it, and managed to unlock almost everything along the way as well (except for the aforementioned one million fire damage, which took me a lot longer).

The game is offered for free, with the paid version offering very little additional content. However, I have to strongly recommend purchasing the game here on steam. This game deserves recognition, it's a really great and lovingly crafted roguelike/rpg. The more purchases it gets, the more it will gain prominence and the more work will be done on it. According to his website, the developer has many more campaigns in the works, including one that lets us play from the side of the villainous (or downtrodden and misunderstood?) orcs. I'm looking forward to more and this game has rightfully earned a spot on my favorites list.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023587238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 8377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1678435380}
review: Let me get some things out of the way first. No, this isn't a great looking game. If you're looking for smooth animation, amazing visuals, flashy effects, etc., you won't find them here. The music isn't great (I play with it muted and one of the many video game and movie soundtracks I have on itunes playing in the background), and sometimes the ambience is a little annoying (whoever owns the dog that barks nonstop in every city needs to put a muzzle on it or something). Now, for the good things. The gameplay is hard as nails, unforgiving, confusing at times, and all around frustratingly hard, as any good roguelike should be. You have to option to play with more lives, even infinite lives, but I always play on the "roguelike" mode, where you only have one life, unless you find more. Knowing what is happening around you at all times is a must in this game, as losing focus of even one enemy can mean death, as I learned the hard way in my most recent death (opened a door, orc necromancer on the other side, managed to escape at first, but on my way back to see if I could get around him, was flanked by his summoned army of skeletons and ghouls). This is a true roguelike, with everything happening in turns as you wander through forests and dungeons, killing everything in your path, picking up loot, buying weapons and armour, and, when you make a mistake, dying with no continues or reloads (at least on roguelike mode). All in all, a really fun game full of challenges and endless replayability. 7.5 / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561197982668260', 'num_games_owned': 1395, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 5104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1185, 'last_played': 1558891557}
review: Would recommend it to any roguelike fan, but if youre even slightly less hardcore than that then you'll drop this game instantly cause it bears all of the default roguelike flaws like poor balancing of classes (some of them faceroll, some of them hard to survive even on the low lvls), playing boring first lvls over and over again, cause the exploration part is pure trial and error, you can easily get to impossible to beat encounter without any warning, faceroll locations with bosses that will oneshot you, pretty hard locations with bosses which easier than regular monsters (i guess it's overall poor balance and design). If you don't mind all of the above, then it's pretty nice game you can enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031565864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 6330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2630, 'last_played': 1495899868}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996251590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1453854097}
review:
Rougelike done right.

I love Rougelikes. They're swimming in options and strategies and are playable in either small chunks or long sittings, their random nature makes them highly replayable, and they're just generally nifty keen.

That said, they also tend to be cruelly unforgiving and really frustrating in the early levels, combined with obtuse interfaces and extremely unhelpful in-game information.

Tales of Maj'Eyal takes the good and throws away the bad. It has more starting options than any roguelike I've ever seen, and has a fleshed-out world for you to explore. The interface, while not flawless, gives you all the information you need to make good choices and the early levels get you used to adventuring without killing you because you tried to mount your horse from the east instead of the west, or whatever.

I highly, highly, highly recommend this title to anyone who likes any other titles in the genre, or anyone who is at all curious about them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987270895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 3830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1701196490}
review:
Tales of Maj'Eyal is an old-school ascii-roguelike game with a tileset as it's skin. This means that the game offers huge amount of content, almost cluttered UI but for a patient gamer opens up as a solid option for those that want to experience the deep roguelike setting with some improvements. 

First of all, Tales of Maj'Eyal is a free-to-play game, by buying it you will receive some improvements/add-ons to it but the core gameplay remains same. As a Steam fanboy and a roguelike fan it was enough for me that the game was on Steam but I'm not 100% sure if it's enough for those counting their last dollars since you can enjoy this game legally without paying, though it's always nice to help the developers ;) 

In Tales of Maj'Eyal you pick a race (Human, Elf etc.) and a class (warrior, wizard) with some unique options not seen elsewhere. You begin your quest in pre-determined area (dungeon) and after moving through it you get to the world map and are free to go wherever you desire (although you will get killed in most of the places you *can* go). There are several difficulty options to choose from between few extra lives and permadeath. 

You can also unlock new races, classes and quests by achieving different things in-game (no spoilers here) but it will take some time to get to that point since the game is rock hard. By the time I'm writing this I've played something like 6,5 hours and haven't scratched the surface yet so there's definitely a huge amount of content and replayability here.

If you have ever played/enjoyed ADOM this is a game for you. 
If you want to see what those old roguelikes would be today this is game for you.
If you hate dying this *might* be a game for you. 

Pros
-Graphics
-Hardcore difficulty
-The amount of content
-You can use mouse and/or keyboard

Cons
-Graphics (some people concider tilesets ugly)
-Difficulty (it really is)
-The amount of things you will have to read and learn (Steam guides help with this one)
-You can get it for free

Overral
Pretty much the only solution for "true" roguelike with graphics 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198008258575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 17996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13113, 'last_played': 1671641316}
review:
This is my favorite rogue-like of all time. 

If I was stranded on the proverbial desert island and had only one game to play this would probably be the one I'd pick due to the sheer replayability.

Pros:
+ Tons of classes and races to pick from. Even choosing the same race and class through multiple playthroughs you can select different skills and builds for a very customizable character.
+ Abslutely no re-skinned classes. Each really is unique in the way it plays.
+ Huge game world to explore with tons of different enemies and items to discover.
+ In-depth lore if you like that sort of thing.
+ Lots of unlockables give a sense of progress and persistence bewteen games.
+ Skill-based strategic game play
+ Scalable difficulty. 
+ Modern mouse-driven interface.
+ Modern customizable UI and HUD.

Cons:
- Graphics are kind of meh.
- High learning curve at first.
- RNG can still screw you sometimes, but it's much less of an issue here than in other rogue-likes I've played.

Other:
= No consumables. All your abilities and items work off a cool-down system. I like this feature a lot, but if you enjoy potions and scrolls you may miss them here.
= Many races and classes are locked at the start. I enjoyed unlocking them and to me it makes sense that the more advanced options are locked at the beginning, but its a personal preference.

So if all of the above was free why did I buy it on Steam? Because I need this man to take my money and make even greater, more wonderful adventures for me to be utterly destroyed in.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980633237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 4978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2906, 'last_played': 1533144001}
review: If you are looking for a good roguelike with a great combination of the following: lots of classes, tactics, skills/talents/spells, items, workable mouse based UI and good tileset, nice story, lots of text to read (optional), then this game is your choice. The game is relatively difficult for beginners, so you'll have to learn the ropes by dying a few times (or few dozen times) before you can advance the story further, unlock more advanced classes, zones, etc. Rather complex gameplay mechanics doesn't help until you figure out how all the statistics work together. The full version is still free to download on the official site, so there is no reason not to try this awesome game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991140811', 'num_games_owned': 5786, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1527395094}
review:
There is nothing more to say than if you're a fan of roguelikes, buy this game now.

So many games now seem to call themselves roguelikes without actually having the core elements of a true RL but this captures them all and still manages to modernize the Genre.
There is an abundance of classes, races, skills, items, quests and more achievements than most people can dream of and with the randomly generated battles, loots and side quests the replayability is off the charts.
Like many RL's though, it can be a little challenging to get into if you've not tried the genre before BUT there is an informative tuturial and modes/features ingame to hep out those who have no played before, or those not so keen on the whole permadeath thing. 
Also, the in game community is 100% helpful and polite so if you're stuck with anything you can usually just ask in chat. 

But be warned, like ALL good RL's don't expect to pick this up and it be easy and you 'complete' it first time you try. You will die, many times, but every time is worth it.
With many many many hours of this clocked on Desura already this is way worth £5 (and more)

author: {'steamid': '76561198067545258', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 23807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9182, 'last_played': 1689457009}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966948377', 'num_games_owned': 1216, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 1393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1527522418}
review: This is, as of the end of 2013, my favorite Roguelike to date. I've really enjoyed things like Dungeons of Dredmor and Dungeons of the Endless but this one takes the cake. It has a much more varied world, a very complex leveling and progression system, and a multitude of races and classes to play as. The best way I can describe this would be as a D&D Roguelike (though it isn't D&D, it has that insane level choices and progression). The game has been out for several years, though it is new to steam, and the Devs are still releasing free content updates to this day. If you want a new roguelike, and one that you won't tire of quickly, check this one out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972244601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1579666988}
review: I can't recommend this game enough. If you have any interest at all in roguelikes or just RPG's, you must give it a try. The UI is excellent and easy to use, with a handy ingame chat. Graphics are simple but nice to look at, especially compared to other roguelikes. There is an insane amount of replay value here between the different races, classes, random loot and skills found in each playthrough, and most of all the different builds possible with each class. You unlock new classes and races by playing, as well as some other things that carry over to new characters, so even when you inevitably die you have something to show for it. The game is frequently updated with new content and features. The game is mostly free to play, but if you like it please give the devs some support by purchasing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027923551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 6395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1700531119}
review:
This is by-far the best roguelike I've ever played. Highly recommend! The difference between the free version on their website and steam is: 


Custom Tiles
A video being worth a thousands words, check it out there:

Donators Custom Tiles
Basically this will allow you to choose a custom tile for all your characters, so much more fun! Also donator's characters with custom tiles will show up on the character's vault!

Custom Tiles and Exploration Mode
Exploration mode is basically a game mode where you get an infinite number of lives, for those that want to see the story unfold faster.

Items Vault
For each 2€ of donations you gain one slot in the online Items Vault. This allows a character to send items to the vault and an other one to grab it from there. This feature can be accessed through the Fortress ingame.
Stone Warden class

Donators get to enjoy a special class: Stone Wardens. Only dwarves can be Stone Wardens, they are a melee class that dual wields shields and is both proficient in arcane and nature. While most of the world thinks those two forces are opposite, the dwarves have found a way to merge them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965069079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 21139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1625551062}
review:
While ToME is technically free if you go to the website (and I encourage you to check it out there to make sure it is a game you enjoy), I am glad I paid the Steam price. It essentially counts the same as if you are a donator on the official web site, giving you the same benefits they get.

As for the game itself, it is a roguelike. That means randomly generated dungeons, items, monsters, etc... and permanent death. ToME actually has an optional mode where you get multiple lives also, in case you are new to roguelikes and want to ease into things. What ToME does that stands out from the rest is have a very interesting class and race system, which is very customizable to your taste. For example, as a Rogue you can choose to specialize in stealthy gameplay with devastating sneak attacks, deadly traps, or a brawling play style with dirty fighting techniques that give you the advantage when facing foes. The choice is yours, and in addition to stats, each race gives a pool of 4 unique abilities you can also choose to train up, making different race and class combinations play somewhat differently.

Another feature of ToME that I don't normally see is an overworld system. After clearing your introduction dungeon you'll be thrust out into the open world, free to explore and attempt to clear dangerous forests, dungeons, and hideouts of foes. It makes the game feel large, like your adventures are part of the world of Maj'Eyal and not just isolated to a single deep dungeon.

Finally, ToME is extremely mod-friendly. Don't want to unlock all the classes and races yourself? There is a mod for that. There are mods for new items, new classes, new dungeons, etc... You name it.

I am not yet very far into the game, but I have no reservations recommending it, especially giving it a try for free on their website: [url]http://te4.org[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561198014863727', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 28451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5142, 'last_played': 1422288645}
review:
I heartily recommend this game on several counts - especially if you have been disappointed by many of the more recent "roguelike" offerings.

The category of "roguelikes" has become rather broad and vaguie in the last few years, IMO primarily because the originals were so limited by technology that different gamemakers have tried different takes on what made them so fun.

ToME is probaly the very best game in this category since the original Rogue and Nethack, because it has the correct answers. there some real role-playing in it as well as some good tactics, so you can have fun all the way through the game. The balance between random generation and meaningful player choices is more even - you are unlikely to die because you never found the key kinds of items you needed, but every game even with the same starting character and overall strategy will play differently.

I also applaud these folks for releasing the dev tools and module source both to foster modding and to let more technical players track down fixes for data-based bugs.

review: While this game does have a learning curve the guides that have been posted will soon take care of that. You have to remember that this game is a roguelike and you don't need to act quickly, a little time spent looking over your options usually can get you out of a sticky situation. The quality of the game is superb and the gameplay great. This game is just what I want in a roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020567377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1488560851}
review:
If you want to get started on the roguelike genre, then this game is the one to start at. Unlike others, this one will allow you to change the difficulty level during character creation, so both new players and veterans won't feel forced to choose one or the other. This game also features a great deal of races and classes, most of which you have to unlock through gameplay, increasing greatly its replayability. The best thing about this roguelike, without a doubt is the lore, as it is really rich in detail and quite interesting.
Fans of roguelikes, buy this game, you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047657967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 6604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4319, 'last_played': 1462061208}
review: The only negative review for this game is get Dungeons Of Dredmore. A good choice for an alternate, I recommend you get that game also. I've been told this game is open source and you can get it for free also, but after playing it I would have just donated that amount anyway. This is a good solid game that looks like a mix between Ragnarok(also freeware but you might need dosbox to play) and Din's curse. This and ragnarok are two of the most true to form roguelikes I can think of as most have you go level to level with creatures at the same equivilent level to fight. in TOME you can blunder into a dungeon that is way to hard for your level or have just a random monster(s) in a vault that is way beyond your means. The only real complaint I might have at this point is sometime you can get killed by a creature offscreen and can do nothing about it(like Xcom). Of course I just take this as meaning I have to get better!! buy it and good luck, you'll need it!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987383437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2101, 'last_played': 1604588855}
review:
A wonderful roguelike! The food clock and challenge of identifying potions and scrolls has been replaced with a focus on tactical combat and powers triggered by a hot bar on the bottom of the screen. The game forces you to get into tough battles and have to really think about your actions to progress.

The classes (there are plenty of them) are a varied and interesting. The skill trees are intricate and forgiving by allowing you to respec the most recent points spent. There seem to be a good variety of builds of each type of class.

So far I've only made it to the mid-game with one of the fighter/mage hybrids. I was sent on quests, entered a handful of dungeons and had a really good time.

So far, as of December 2013, this is by far the best roguelike available on Steam. The only games for me that come close to this are NetHack, ADOM (coming to Steam soon) and Brogue (free). A big thumbs up.

review: A simple but additive rogue-like, with loot and unlocks and lots and lots of stats. Steam Workshop and DLC mean you'll never run out of new material. All this is great, but the crowning acheivement is the music. A triumphant soundtrack that can make flipping through inventory feel heroic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991563618', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 25096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9461, 'last_played': 1682026225}
review:
A pretty brutal roguelike with a very simple easy to use interface. All of the usual fantasy tropes present and accounted for as well as some other fun additions not commonly found in such games. Classes run the gamut from standard beat stick warriors and glass cannon archmages all the way to the strange paradox magi and psionic solipsists.

The game can be especially frustrating when playing low hp characters who can die in a single turn if you don't scout ahead so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone with a short temper, but if you're a fan of roguelikes it's a pretty solid addition to your library.

And if you're aren't sure you want to buy it you can play the game for free on the creator's website. You can't lose.

review:
If you possess the following:

-A passion (not just an enjoyment) for roguelikes and/or tactical RPGs
-Lots of patience
-A beard and/or hair on your chest (for women)
-The ability to accept perma-death without whining about the loss of your Mary Sue fan-fiction character that you jerk off to

Then buy this and prepare to watch time vanish faster than Julliane Moore's clothes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071503519', 'num_games_owned': 857, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1445774593}
review:
There aren't many games that fit the genre of roguelikes on Steam. [b]Dungeons of Dredmor[/b] is one of them, [b]Sword of the Stars: The Pit[/b] is another one.
[b]Tales of Maj'Eyal[/b] is a roguelike game in it's truest sense, however, it has some gameplay elements that I personally didn't see occuring that much in other RL games like [b]ADOM[/b].
For one, there is pretty much no division between activatable skills and magic spells (something like what [b]Dungeons of Dredmor[/b] does). The main difference between them is that different classes use different types of power points (warrior classes use stamina, arcane mages use mana, hate for afflicted classes) that behave differently (mana gets restored with time for magic classes while hate is only increased by hitting hard and taking damage).
Another major difference is the absense of magical potions or scrolls. Those are replaced by infustions. A character can store a limited amount of infusions that can be activated any number of times (those can be replaced by new infusions), except that they have a cooldown. This greatly changes the health restoration system other roguelikes and action-RPG games have. Instead of stacking with a huge amount of potions that you drink at will, you have to take note of how much health you have, how much you lose in combat, and how many turns do you have to survive until you can use another infusion.
The game itself can be downloaded for free from [b]te4.org[/b]. Buying ToME from Steam automatically makes you a donator, which unlocks an additional class for dwarven characters, a somewhat easier exploration mode that allows you to revive your character unlimited amount of times, and an ability to share a limited amount of items with your other characters.

review: It's just so awesome. hardcore RPG, Roguelike, has a classic style/feel to it, and for those of you who dont enjoy super punishing roguelikes, they have options to make it easier, not my style, but i like that it allows (for lack of a better word) noobs to play and enjoy the game while not ruining the experience for hardcore players, that is in my book, so important to games in general, but espically roguelikes. the combat is nice, and the UI is a little daunting at first, but i kinda like it. i dont like rating games based on numbers, but since thats how things are generally rated id say this is eassily a 10/10.
